data.title: The 27 best castles in and around Vienna

placeMetadata.name: Belvedere Palace

sources.snippet: Divided into two sections – the Upper and the Lower Belvedere – this Baroque structure is known for its well-curated French-style gardens and the permanent exhibition in the Upper Belvedere. The Palace was commissioned as a summer residence by Prince Eugene of Savoy, and today displays an impeccable art collection featuring Gustav Klimt, Egon Schiele, Claude Monet and Vincent van Gogh. The Upper Belvedere is also home to one of Vienna’s most celebrated paintings – The Kiss by Gustav Klimt.
sources.shortName: The 5 Vienna Palaces you MUST VISIT in 2025

sources.snippet: Österreichische Galarie Belvedere (Belvedere Palace; Vienna): On a slope above Vienna, this palace was designed by Johann Lukas von Hildebrandt, the last major architect of the baroque in Austria. Belvedere served as a summer home for Prince Eugene of Savoy, the country's greatest military hero. The palace was a gift from the imperial throne in recognition of the prince's military achievements, although he was (at the time) richer than the Hapsburgs.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles, Palaces & Historic Homes in Austria

sources.snippet: The Belvedere Palace Museum is composed of the Orangery and the Palace Stables. The Orangery is home of the world’s largest collection of Gustav Klimt’s artworks, including The Kiss, so this spot is ideal if you are traveling with someone who loves art. Many visitors simply stroll in the magnificent gardens and snap photos of the palace’s reflection in the pond in the front, so if you had your share of royal interiors, you can do the same.
sources.shortName: Royal Castles and Palaces to Visit in Vienna

sources.snippet: At the Belvedere you get two palaces in one: The Orangery and the Palace Stables. The Orangery hosts the world’s largest collection of Gustav Klimt’s paintings, including The Kiss – ideal if you’re visiting Vienna with kids who are into art. It’s perfect for people-watching too as many tourists and locals come here simply to stroll in the gardens, which are kept fit for an Emperor.
sources.shortName: Discover The Best Palaces in Vienna

sources.snippet: Belvedere Palace is a stunning example of Baroque architecture and a must-visit for art enthusiasts. The palace complex consists of two main buildings, the Upper and Lower Belvedere, connected by a beautiful terraced garden. The Upper Belvedere houses the Austrian Gallery, which showcases an impressive collection of Austrian art, including Gustav Klimt’s famous painting “The Kiss.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital
The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Baroque, 18th-century palaces housing art from Middle Ages to today, with notable Klimt collection.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Belvedere Palace is a stunning example of Baroque architecture located in Vienna's Landstrasse district. It consists of two grand palaces separated by a beautiful French-style garden. Originally built as a summer residence for Prince Eugene of Savoy in the 18th century, it now houses an impressive art collection spanning from the Middle Ages to contemporary works, including a notable collection of Klimt paintings.

reviews.reviewText:
This is a must if you're in Vienna.
The inside of the palace (upper side) is very beautiful and it offers not only Austrian art but also contemporary art. In the lower side you can find a different exhibition, this time they had different close ups of the most important works of art they had in the museum.

Visiting Belvedere Palace in Vienna is a feast for the eyes, particularly if you appreciate grand architecture and historic structures. The palace itself is stunning, with intricate interiors and elegant layouts that make wandering through its halls a visual delight. Even with parts of the building under restoration, the charm and grandeur of the palace remain impressive.

The exhibition, however, is less remarkable. While it has its moments, it doesn’t quite match the awe-inspiring atmosphere created by the palace and its architecture. Art lovers may enjoy it, but for those primarily seeking a “wow” factor, it may feel underwhelming.

A practical note: the queues can be long, especially on weekends. Even if you buy tickets online, you may have to wait for a later slot; when we arrived, our online tickets only allowed entry three hours later. Planning ahead and booking well in advance is highly recommended.

The gardens are fantastic and free to explore. Locals often jog, run, or just relax there, and it's lovely to see artists drawing or people chilling. Overall, the views and grounds make it worth avisit!

Overall, Belvedere Palace is worth visiting for its architecture and historical appeal, but don’t set your expectations too high for the exhibitions.

The castle was awesome.  Likes the gardens as well . Should spend more time there but we had only 1 hour as . Too many things to see here in Vienna for sure .
Like the way everything is put .
Gardens are not fully blooming as of now

Excellent collection of paintings. Beautiful garden and view from Upper Belvedere to Lower Belvedere. Not to forget about the Famous Painting of Gutav Klimt, "The Kiss". Easy access via local public transport. If you brought ticket go directly to the main entrance.

Belvedere Palace was incredibly stunning! It is worth coming here while you are in Vienna. The grounds and palace are beautiful as you would expect. Where it really shines though is the inside. The art collection is absolutely incredible and is something you should not miss in Vienna. It is so amazing to come here and admire works of art and to learn about the history of that art, and the artists behind it. The kiss is the main draw of the Belvedere for many, it is much more beautiful in person than what you would expect. I would definitely recommend buying tickets in advance and coming in the morning is the way to go here because of the crowds.

Went to Belvedere Palace mainly to see Gustav Klimt’s The Kiss, and it was absolutely worth it. The painting is even more breathtaking in person..the colors, the details, and the atmosphere around it make the experience unforgettable.

The palace itself is beautiful, with lovely gardens and stunning architecture, but my highlight was definitely standing in front of The Kiss. If you’re an art lover, this is a must-see in Vienna.

p.s: In my case, i only went inside the main building, which is why it greatly influences my review of the place....
(words cannot seem enough for me to describe how great this place was and how it made me feel..)
I remember the first time i walked past the gates of this magical place...
I was stunned.
The Lower Belvedere (the smaller building to your right when you walk through the main gate) was just a great glimse reflecting the grace, delicacy and beauty of the main thing which was just above your view.
Making your way up, walking through the gardens, the power of the sphinxs making itself known around your every step ; finally reaching your end where you stood just in front of the building and getting sad that your eye cannot capture the whole view in just a gaze.
This was about the back of the palace, you get curious and start looking around until you get to the front of the building.
I can describe looking at the details of the scene was like looking at a perfectly decorated piece of cake you dreamed of getting for your birthday.
The inside is just a whole another story written and built on it's own.
A fairytale coming to life, bringing its glory to your step and senses....
The carved stone making you not feel alone, the painted walls feeling like home and the pieces of art having your breath taken away for seconds....
Visiting the palace overrall was such a fulfilling and calming experience for me and everytime i make my way back to the city of Vienna, this place will be always waiting for my next visit.

Personally only visited the gardens and coffee shop both of which were lovely. The palace is gorgeous from the outside and if you've visited the other palaces in vienna and are not massively into art then I think that is enough for Belvedere.

placeMetadata.name: Hofburg

sources.snippet: Hofburg (Vienna): The winter palace of the Hapsburgs, Hofburg was the seat of an imperial throne that once governed the mighty Austro-Hungarian Empire. The sprawling palace reads like an architectural timeline of the Hapsburg family, dating from 1279 with subsequent additions continuing until 1918. Today the Hofburg houses everything from the offices of the president of Austria to the Spanish Riding School with its Lipizzaner stallions -- even the Vienna Boys' Choir.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles, Palaces & Historic Homes in Austria

sources.snippet: The Hofburg Palace is another important symbol of Vienna’s imperial past. For centuries, this sprawling complex was the main residence of the Habsburg dynasty, and today it houses several museums, the Austrian National Library, and the offices of the Austrian president. Visitors can admire the elegant architecture, explore the lavish state apartments, and learn about the fascinating history of the Habsburgs.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

sources.snippet: The Habsburg Empire ruled for centuries from the very center of Vienna and the magnificent Hofburg Palace was right at the heart of it. Today, the Palace has three museums under its roof: the Imperial Apartments, the Sisi Museum (telling a sad tale) and the Silver Collection. You can visit the Palace while seeing the landmarks in the city center, so make sure to set some time aside.
sources.shortName: Royal Castles and Palaces to Visit in Vienna

sources.snippet: Also known as the Imperial Palace, the Hofburg Palace was at the center of the House of Austria. It was not only the residence of the royal family, but also their place of governance up until the early twentieth century. Today, it is the official seat of governance of the President of Austria.
sources.shortName: The 5 Vienna Palaces you MUST VISIT in 2025
The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Habsburg palace complex with ornate, baroque interiors, imperial apartments & a silver museum.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Hofburg Imperial Palace, located in the heart of Vienna, is a grand complex that served as the residence and seat of power for the Habsburgs. This historic site, dating back to the 13th century, stands as a testament to the imperial history of the Danube monarchy. Today, it houses various institutions including the Austrian Federal President's office, museums such as the Sisi Museum and Court Silver Collection, and serves as an international conference center.

reviews.reviewText: We're able to explore outside after working hours, garden was so beautiful. This must be a full day as there are many attractions.

Beautiful historical building in the central location. Really enjoyed our visit there. Nice park to sit and rest during the hot Summer weather. Love Vienna so much and will definitely be back and visit a few of the museums. Walking distance to other attractions, lots of shops, restaurants and cafes around.

Impressive imperial palace complex in the heart of Vienna. Rich history, grand architecture, and well-curated museums make it a must-visit. Allow enough time to explore the Sisi Museum and the Imperial Apartments.

We didn’t have enough time to go inside Hofburg Palace, but even from the outside, it’s incredibly grand and impressive. The architecture is stunning. The palace grounds are vast, with beautiful courtyards and statues. It’s a lovely area to walk around, and there’s so much to take in, even without entering the museums.

absolutely amazing! The history and grandeur of the place are incredible, and it's so much bigger than you expect. Walking through the imperial apartments and the Sisi Museum is a fascinating experience. It's a must-see for anyone visiting Vienna.
One of the most beautiful castles in the world situated in the middle of a large area of magnificent buildings and lots of history. Very impressive and a must visit.

Magnificent, and even more so at sunset, of course.
One of the top 5 places to visit in Vienna.
I particularly recommend the National Library, absolutely unique and unmissable.

Sisi Museum is definitely worth the money and time. There you learn fascinating history of the empress and some misconceptions are cleared up. The royal apartment tour is also interesting. Sadly the silver collection is not open. Book the ticket online to avoid waiting.

placeMetadata.name: Schönbrunn Palace

sources.snippet: Schönbrunn Palace is undoubtedly one of the most iconic landmarks in Vienna. Built in the 18th century as a summer residence for the Habsburg monarchs, this Baroque masterpiece boasts over 1,400 rooms and stunning gardens. Visitors can tour the beautifully preserved staterooms, marvel at the exquisite frescoes, and explore the impressive gardens, which feature fountains, statues, and even a maze.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

sources.snippet: Built in 1642, the Schönbrunn Palace is the biggest palace in Vienna. It was listed under the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1996 and is a classic example of Austrian baroque architecture. Located atop a hill nearly 200-feet high, the Schönbrunn is famous for its vast gardens blooming with countless flower arrangements.
sources.shortName: The 5 Vienna Palaces you MUST VISIT in 2025

sources.snippet: Schönbrunn Palace (Vienna): This palace of 1,441 rooms was the summer residence of the powerful Hapsburg family. The great baroque architect J. B. Fischer von Erlach modeled his plans on Versailles, though he ultimately surpassed the French palace in size.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles, Palaces & Historic Homes in Austria

sources.snippet: They include several gardens (a privy garden and orangery garden), the Gloriette, a maze, a Palm House, a vineyard and a Zoo.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna
Royal Castles and Palaces to Visit in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: 18th-century summer palace with tours of lavish rococo ceremonial rooms, plus gardens with a maze.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Schönbrunn Palace is an 18th-century summer residence that offers tours of its opulent rococo ceremonial rooms and lavish gardens with a maze. The palace boasts beautiful Baroque and Neo-Classical architecture, reflecting Vienna's rich history as the town of Habsburgs and Maria Theresa. It is Vienna's most visited attraction, featuring 45 luxurious state rooms, ceremonial halls, and private apartments once inhabited by Empress Elisabeth and Emperor Franz Joseph.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing palace, we took the full access. The garden was breathtaking, and the palace was pretty.  The art collection in the palace was stunning. Definitely enjoyed it. I would recommend buying tickets online, as they are strict in entrance timing .

The palace is really gorgeous. The museums inside palace and certain portion of the garden can be visited only with tickets. But we did not buy any ticket and directly visited the garden behind the palace. The garden is really humongous and beautiful.  The center has beautiful flowers followed by fountain. Also beautiful place to click a photo or two.

As the garden is so huge I saw some people there for their morning stroll. Hey Perplexity, rewrite it and adjust the tone and grammatical errors.

The palace is truly stunning. Access to the museums inside and certain sections of the garden requires a ticket, but without purchasing one, it’s still possible to visit the garden area behind the palace. The gardens are vast and beautifully maintained, with vibrant flowers at the center leading toward a lovely fountain. The scenery makes it an excellent spot for photos. Given the sheer size of the gardens, it’s common to see people enjoying a morning stroll there.

Wow.

Hard to believe this was a residence a few hundred years back.

Stunning Architecture and Grounds.

Breathtaking Hilly Scenery.

We didn’t go in because of the Price and the Wait!

Packed on a Wednesday morning. Lots of Tour Bus Groups here.

A must see and bring your walking shoes because this place is massive.

You could walk the Grounds for hours it’s so expansive.

This should be a must see in Vienna!

Very nice experience visiting this Palace. It was educational, although we did the audio tour and there were many basic facts which seemed to be missing and I might therefore recommend a guided tour. Plan on spending at least an hour on the grounds, as they are beautiful and enormous.

Wow! What a beautiful place! I would say this is a must see for any tourists. The grounds are so incredible and have so much to do. If you have several days in Vienna I recommend at least half a day to see everything here including the gardens, zoo, labyrinth, Gloriette, and palace interior. The gardens and land alone are worth devoting at least an hour or two of your time to. As for the inside I would say get the palace pass unless you are wanting to see more of the palace. The palace pass gets you access to many rooms and a gift shop at the end and there is an audio tour available in several languages. The palace is decorated with authentic furniture to replicate what it would have been like at its prime. The palace was moderately busy but manageable and in the gardens you hardly notice most of the crowds. on the inside it can be hard to squeeze past people or move along when there’s a crowd, so I would recommend trying to go in the earlier morning when it opens. Buy tickets in advance if you want a planned time slot, but if you’re fine waiting for about an hour and a half, or more, buying tickets there is perfectly fine. Also… don’t stand on the grass or places that you’re not supposed to!

We didn’t go inside the Schönbrunn Palace, but just strolling around the beautiful grounds was more than enough. My boyfriend and I enjoyed walking through the gardens, hiking up to the Gloriette for amazing views, and even wandering into the nearby forest trails. Peaceful, scenic, and a lovely way to spend time together — we loved every moment!

A very interesting site to explore. What I really liked is that the audio guide provided by the museum focuses on the most important information and is very easy to follow. The gardens are also beautiful.

If you want to get a glimpse of how royalty lived, Schönbrunn Palace and its gardens are a must-see! This is one of favorite visits in Vienna. The Baroque architecture is absolutely magnificent, and the grounds are just as impressive. The massive garden stretches behind the palace with the Gloriette perched on the hill, offering one of the best views in Vienna. My tip – start your visit at the Gloriette first and snap some photos of the entire palace and gardens from the balcony. Then, take a leisurely stroll down the hill, through the fountains and perfectly manicured paths, and make your way to the palace entrance.

The inside tour requires a ticket, but it’s worth every euro. The lavish interiors and rich history give you a true appreciation of the opulent lifestyle of the royal family. We were in awe of the intricate details and grandeur of each room – it really transports you back in time. For even more context, check out the Netflix series The Empress before or after your visit – it adds another layer of appreciation. A must-do when in Vienna!

placeMetadata.name: Albertina

sources.snippet: Located in the Inner Stadt (First District), the Albertina is a palace now functioning as one of the primary art museums of Vienna. It houses distinguished European artwork ranging from the nineteenth to the twenty-first centuries. The collection includes paintings, sketches, and other pieces by Claude Monet, Pable Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Henri Matisse, Leonardo da Vinci, Egon Schiele, Michelangelo, Gustav Klimt, and more.
sources.shortName: The 5 Vienna Palaces you MUST VISIT in 2025
The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna

placeMetadata.description: 19th-century Habsburg palace with staterooms & collections of old master prints & 20th-century art.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Albertina is a 19th-century Habsburg palace located in the largest of the Habsburg dynasty's residential palaces. It houses an extensive collection of old master prints, 20th-century art, over 65,000 watercolors and drawings, and about 70,000 photographs. The museum features works by renowned artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Rembrandt and others.

reviews.reviewText:
Magnificent museum worth spending a whole day in. Once a residential palace , later transfomed into an art museum by Maria Christine ( daughter of Queen Maria Theresa)and her husban Albert, hence the name - Alberina.
Great collection of modern and contemporary art.  Albrecht Dürer famous Hare , Modigliani Female Semi Nude, some Picasso, Klimt are just a few highlights of the collection.
I was lucky to see Matthew Wong exhibition here. What a wonderful discovery! I enjoyed every painting of it.
Don't miss the terrace featured in the movie  The Tabacconist.
Loved my visit and would come back to enjoy more next time I'm in Vienna.

Visited Albertina museum this afternoon. What a treat to anyone who loves art. Top floor of Albertina museum hosts an amazing collection entitled From Monet To Picasso that is a home to many pieces by Monet, Renoir, Kandinsky, Kokoshka, and Picasso. Admission is reasonable: as of July 2025, children under 19 get in free, and my adult ticket was 19 euros. Audioguides are free for children and 5 euros for adults, those are available in all major languages. The museum building itself is absolutely georgeous.
Great museum with stunning Impressionist works and elegant historic staterooms. Not too crowded, easy to enjoy. A must-visit in Vienna!

What a delightful experience! I came for a visit on a Friday afternoon as the museum is open until 9 with less people.
I have to say paying the extra 5 euro for the audio guide you download on your phone was worth every penny. It gave me such a deeper understanding of the collections and paintings. The narrator connects big part of the paintings from the exhibitions with history, background and interesting tidbits of information about the artists. I felt totally immersed in one world at a time for each part I visited.
I started with the Matthew Wong (a Canadian artist I didn’t know about but was totally mesmerized by his art) and Van Gogh, this was such a moving exhibition especially when you learn about the life and struggles of both and connect this to their paintings.
The Monet to Picasso exhibit spanned many painters and touched on my favourite Impressionism.
Then I saw the fascinating exhibition on drawings on coloured backgrounds Leonardo -Durer, so interesting!
2.5 hours went by so quickly and that wasn’t even all of the museum. I hope to be able to return and see more exhibition at this beautiful place.
In summary, this is lovely place if you love art and it is well organized and presented. Get the audio guide and prepare to be absolutely immersed in a different world. Superb!

This is a great museum with famous colections, including some modern art. Small rooms, but spacious, seating benches, some parts include stairs, not crowded, but busy. We spent 2-3 hrs inside and It was worth it.

Good contemporary museum with regular changing expositions. Have visited the exhibition "From Monet to Picasso" exhibition this weekend, enjoyed contemplating quite a few fabulous pieces of art by impressionist and post-impressionists

My favourite museum, feels like you have visited 3 or more. You can get lost inside for hours... Magnificent interior, tons of famous pictures, beautifully arranged and curated. Definitely must visit while in Vienna! There's a great online "combo" ticket so you can explore this one and Albertina Modern. Not that the price is relevant for this experience...

In my opinion the best museum in Vienna.

It is a great example of a combination of classic and modern architecture both outside and inside. The cloakroom, lockers and the toilet are located before ticketing. Cloakroom costs some euro (can’t remember if it’s 1€ or 2€, only cash) but if you don’t have any money for it, the staff will give you token for the lockers - that’s really useful, thank you so much!

I recommend buying ticket online but it’s not a big deal cause queue was minimal (at least on Monday 12PM). After the ticket office area, you enter the exhibition, cafe and shop place. The staff is giving u some sort of sticker and if you want to came back to lockers or something they would know that you already bought a ticket.

The most impressive collection is the one located on level 2 - MONET TO PICASSO. The Batliner Collection. It’s a a comprehensive exhibition of the most important art of the XIX and XX centuries (names such as: Monet, Degas, Signac, Klimt, Matisse, die Brücke artists i.e. Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Karl Schmidt Rottluff, Munch, Kandinsky, Klee, Kupka, Magritte, Miró, Picasso). Don’t know why there wasn’t Francis Bacon and Marc Chagall on display.

On the first floor there are also quite charming rooms - Prunkräume, which could be interesting to people fond of this period - however everyone should see in the last of rooms works by Albrecht Dürer.

Prices in shop btw:
Magnet - 4,90€,
Postcards - 1,5-2€,
Monet to Picasso exhibition book - 19,90€.

placeMetadata.name: Wien Museum Hermesvilla

sources.snippet: Located in the Lainzer Tiergarten, a large nature reserve on the outskirts of Vienna, Hermesvilla is a charming 19th-century villa built by Emperor Franz Joseph I for his beloved wife, Empress Elisabeth. Often referred to as the “Palace of Dreams,” this romantic retreat is surrounded by lush forests and beautiful gardens, providing a peaceful escape from the bustling city center. Today, the villa houses a museum dedicated to the life and times of Empress Elisabeth, and visitors can explore the lovingly restored interiors and learn about the fascinating story of Austria’s most famous royal couple.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

sources.snippet: Empress Elisabeth called the Hermesvilla the “Palace of Dreams”. The Palace was gifted to Elisabeth by her husband Emperor Franz Joseph in the hope of persuading Elisabeth to spend more time in Vienna.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Hermesvilla, also known as the Castle of Dreams, is a picturesque rural retreat located on the outskirts of Vienna Woods. Built by Emperor Franz Joseph for his wife Sisi, this countryside villa was designed to entice her to spend more time near Vienna. Situated within the Lainzer Tiergarten wildlife preserve, visitors can explore the surrounding forest and encounter wild boars, fallow deer, mouflons, and red deer.

reviews.reviewText: A nice but small Museum that you're able to reach by a nice little hike. People there were friendly, the interior was really good.

Nice museum, which you can visit in 45'. Attention, for old people or invalids, there is a long stairway that gets you on the 1st floor of the villa from the ground floor  and that's where the museum starts.

Hint: Museum is in the list of free entry of Vienna museums every first Sunday of the new month.

I'm not sure how I feel about this place It's about a 15 minute hike before you can get to the location and then when you get there it's more of a hike in a park experience than it is for the musem / Villa I went on the first Sunday of the month which mean that it was free to enter But I can't imagine what it would be like to pay for that because it's quite small the Villa itself and it doesn't really have a lot of artefacts explaining the life of the empress So that kind of disappointed me. If you want to go you should bring some snacks Bring some water because they don't have the fountains that they usually have in Vienna In summertime And make a whole picnic out of it make the experience more than just the villa because it's not really ideal for Exclusively visiting the Villa and then leaving especially since it's so far away from the city. The park is stunning they have a lot of information about the reserve of the plants and the animals there's a lot of bugs so bring some spray there's a lot to do in the area but a few places are barred off and you can't walk through them. Schedule more time than you think you need because you'll probably want to spend time just to roam around the greenery.

It's a nice place. A bit of a walk through the forest from the bus stop. Pleasant walk. The building is currently under renovation outside, but is open for visiting. Interior is more cozy, not so overwhelming as the main palace in Vienna, but with an interesting twist, small gym, where Sisi fenced and did sports, spacious outdoors. Spend less than an hour.
It is not the biggest palace in Vienna,  but very cosy and nice. Not very touristik. Beatiful garden.
Nice little stroll in the park to get to the villa (about 15 minutes). Outside restaurant, lovely exteriors and interesting interiors. But explanations are only in German.

We went on the 1st Sunday of the month so it was free. Get ready for a walk in the forest to get there. The place itself is not as glorious as other Austrian castles and villas but it’s charming. It definitely is not worth it to go in a day when it’s not free. The nature around and the garden are beautiful.

Hermesvilla is a really beautiful place. Very peaceful and pleasant environment. The complex is surrounded by big forest. Gardens around the villa are nicely decorated with  beautiful flowers, different colors, and all kinds of roses and other bushes cut in different shapes. On both sides of the villa, you can see a few sculptures and fountains as well.  From the villa, you can use different paths for walking through the forest. In the forest, it is also possible to see wild animals. All recommendations.

placeMetadata.name: Palais Lobkowitz

sources.snippet: The home of the Theatre Museum of Vienna, Palais Lobkowitz is a celebration of the performing arts. This townhouse was built in the seventeenth century in the baroque style and is known for being one of Beethoven’s favourite venues to perform at. The palais has a grand concert hall named Eroica Hall, and displays a few permanent collections including Klimt’s infamous painting Nuda Veritas.
sources.shortName: The 5 Vienna Palaces you MUST VISIT in 2025

sources.snippet: If you’re stopping by the Kunsthistorisches Musem, Palais Lobkowitz may well be on your itinerary. This grand building encases the theatre museum of Vienna’s art gallery. In the early 19th century, Beethoven used to come and stay, and he even dedicated his Third Symphony to the owner at the time.
sources.shortName: Discover The Best Palaces in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Lobkowitz, located in Vienna, is a historical treasure with stunning architecture and a rich cultural legacy. This seventeenth-century townhouse, built in the baroque style, was a favorite performance venue for Beethoven. The palace features the grand Eroica Hall and houses the Austrian Theatre Museum, showcasing the country's vibrant theatrical tradition. Visitors can also admire Klimt's renowned painting Nuda Veritas among its permanent collections.

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful location for special occasions
Beautiful building

(Translated by Google) We only saw it from the outside because we were passing through. It is baroque but was modified in the mid-18th century. For classical music lovers: this is the house where Beethoven first conducted his 3rd symphony, Lobkowitz Palace, Vienna. Now it is home to the Theater Museum.

(Original)
Sólo lo vimos por fuera porque íbamos de paso .es barroco pero se modificó a mediados del siglo XVIII.Para los amantes de la música clásica : esta es la casa donde Beethoven dirigió por primera vez su 3a sinfonía,el Palacio Lobkowitz, Viena . Ahora es sede del Museo del Teatro.

(Translated by Google) One of the most beautiful Viennese palaces is located on one of the most beautiful squares in Vienna opposite the Albertina and houses the Theatre Museum

(Original)
Eines der schönsten Wiener Palais befindet sich auf einem der schönsten Plätze Wiens gegenüber der Albertina und beherbergt das Theatermuseum

(Translated by Google) An extraordinary building. Lots of art and culture events. The Theater Museum in particular is presented at its best and is very exciting. There is also the famous Eroica Hall where Beethoven once composed. But parking is difficult there.  It's best to come by in public. It's right behind the State Opera

(Original)
Ein außergewöhnliches Gebäude. Viel Kunst und Kultur Veranstaltungen. Besonders das Theater Museum ist vom feinsten und sehr spannend aufbereitet. Es gibt da auch den so berühmten Eroica-Saal wo einst Beethoven komponierte zu bestaunen. Parken ist aber dort schwierig.  Am besten öffentlich vorbeikommen. Ist ja gleich hinter der Staatsoper

(Translated by Google) The Lobkowitzpalais in Vienna is a fascinating historical gem with impressive architecture and rich cultural heritage. From the magnificent facade to the majestic main portal, this palace is a real eye-catcher. Visit the Austrian Theater Museum and discover the country's rich theater tradition.

Don't miss the opportunity to purchase sweet treats and unique gifts in the "Vienna Sweets and Gifts" shop on the Neuer Markt opposite the Imperial Crypt. Immerse yourself in the magic of Vienna and enjoy this cultural highlight!

(Original)
Das Lobkowitzpalais in Wien ist ein faszinierendes historisches Juwel mit beeindruckender Architektur und reichem kulturellen Erbe. Von der prächtigen Fassade bis zum majestätischen Hauptportal ist dieses Palais ein wahrer Blickfang. Besuchen Sie das Österreichische Theatermuseum und entdecken Sie die reiche Theatertradition des Landes.

Verpassen Sie nicht die Gelegenheit, im Shop "Vienna Sweets and Gifts" am Neuen Markt gegenüber der Kaisergruft süße Leckereien und einzigartige Geschenke zu erwerben. Tauchen Sie ein in die Magie von Wien und genießen Sie dieses kulturelle Highlight!

(Translated by Google) Current bouquet exhibition very informative

(Original)
Aktuelle Straussausstellung sehr informativ

(Translated by Google) THEATER MUSEUM Palais Lobkowitz
Lobkowitzplatz 2, 1010 Vienna
“FASHION for the STAGE” Monika von Zallinger
costume drawings

Heartwarming, imaginative, sparkling, lively, sensitive, well-founded. Monika von Zallinger's stage costume designs are simply fantastic.
You can feel that someone who was born with it is at work here.
My joy goes not only to Monika von Zallinger, but also to the wonderfully presented exhibition.
The Theater Museum is very fortunate not only to present a given theme, but also to stage it and that is noticeable. . .
But see for yourself. . .

(Original)
THEATERMUSEUM Palais Lobkowitz
Lobkowitzplatz 2, 1010 Wien
„MODE für die BÜHNE“ Monika von Zallinger
Kostümzeichnungen

Herzerwärmend, phantasievoll, prickelnd, lebendig, einfühlsam, fundiert. Einfach großartig die Bühnenkostümentwürfe von Monika von Zallinger.
Man spürt, dass hier jemand am Werk ist, dem es „in die Wiege gelegt“ wurde.
Meine Freude gilt aber nicht nur Monika von Zallinger, sondern auch der herrlich präsentierten Ausstellung.
Das Theatermuseum hat das große Glück ein vorgegebenes Thema nicht nur zu präsentieren, sondern noch einmal zusätzlich zu inszenieren und das ist spürbar . . .
Aber sehen Sie selbst . . .

placeMetadata.name: Imperial Treasury

sources.snippet: Another museum called Imperial Treasury is located in the Hofburg Palace complex, and it has a collection of the Imperials, such as the Crown of the Holy Roman Empire and the Austrian Empire.
sources.shortName: Vienna's Top 6 Palaces to Visit and Explore: Step into the World of Royalty

placeMetadata.description: Museum housing secular & religious treasure collected by Austrian emperors over last 1,000 years.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Imperial Treasury Vienna, located in the Swiss Wing of the Vienna Hofburg, is a museum that houses an extensive collection of secular and religious treasures amassed by Austrian emperors over the past millennium. It serves as a repository for the regalia of the House of Habsburg and treasures of the Holy Roman Empire. The exhibits are divided into a secular and spiritual treasury, showcasing objects with exceptional historical and decorative value.

reviews.reviewText: If you love history, then this museum is for you. It has jewels, regalia, clothing that the Holy Roman Emperor's wore, even the oldest crown in that museum which dates back to the 900's.

Correctly evaluating this museum is particularly difficult, as an Italian, i had the privilege of growing up in a country where the Catholic Church has filled the land with wonders of this kind, spread across countless museums.
That said, the Vienna Treasury Museum holds its own thanks to the sheer richness and opulence of its collection.
The displays are extensive, and the information panels are thorough and informative.
While the ticket price is on the higher side, it is understandable given the cost of preserving such ancient and valuable artifacts.

You could spent hours in this place looking at all the displays as there is certainly a lot to see. From crowns and sceptres to ceremonial robes and swords, ornate objects to religious artifacts, it contained a lot more than I was expecting.  Nice gift shop at end.

It was a bit hard to find the location. The exhibition itself wasn't huge. And although there were some precious gems, if you were to ask me if I really had to see this place, I'd say you don't have to.

This was one of my - unexpected - museum favourites in Vienna! If you are a history geek, this is an absolute MUST SEE. The imperial crown, the archduke’s crown … so much to take in with a very interesting audio guide (do take this one of you have the option - prebook online).

There are also some fascinating sources for anecdotes, like the unicorn horns - certified by the pope 😂😅

Easy to do in 1-1.5 hours. I will revisit eventually - just because it is a lot to take in during one visit. Easy to do on a calm Sunday morning. Or whenever you have free time.

Imperial Treasury… where do I even start. As a big fan of historic jewellery the Imperial Treasury was definitely one of my favourite experiences in Vienna. My absolute favourite object on display is the imperial crown of Austria, I consider seeing it up close as a vary big privilege. The museum itself is jot vary big but there is definitely a lot to see. You can see few crowns coronation robes portraits bejewelled crosses and swords some royal portraits… I absolutely recommend a visit to everyone visiting Vienna, from history enthusiasts to people not so interested in history.
This museum is awesome, it is included in Vienna's pass and you can visit different exhibits with the clothes, jewels and crowns of the kings. I real highlight.

This museum may be a often overlooked, especially when compared to bigger ones, but in my opinion was the best museum I visited in Vienna. The amount of artifacts displayed at the Treasury is astounding. From crowns, jewels and valuables to  the relics, it is just breathtaking. Definitely recommend visiting this place!

placeMetadata.name: Wien Museum Karlsplatz

sources.snippet: Franzensburg: Guided tours of the museum as well as up the Tall Tower and across the roofs; museum shop open daily from 10.30 am – 4.30 pm; ferry to the Franzensburg, Café Meierei with large terrace right by the castle lake.
sources.shortName: Laxenburg Castle Park - vienna.info

placeMetadata.description: Museum with exhibits on city's history from Roman times to the present, plus art by Klimt & Schiele.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Wien Museum Karlsplatz is part of a group of museums in Vienna that focus on the city's history. The main building, located in Karlsplatz, has been recently renovated and expanded to showcase the city's history from Roman times to the present day. It features a permanent exhibition with 1,700 objects spread across three storeys.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing museum! They have very interesting exhibits and the whole museum gives very interactive experience. You can open or close some stuff to see more or get additional info, play around with some things so it could be very interesting for children as well. The permanent exhibition is showing a chronological tour of Vienna, the history of the city, models, sketches, figures, etc. The entrance is free for the permanent exhibition and there is also a cloakroom where you can leave your belongings for free.

Free entry for this museum in Vienna.
It takes you along the history of the city without making you feel bored since there is something to look at in every corner.
Interesting exhibits and time skips through different periods of Vienna and how it became the city it is today.

Free admission
Duration time about an hour an half
Museum explain history from the stong age era all the way to the 1900s.
The museum itself explain  the history and the story of Vienna itself.
You will be amaze, and learn more about this city.

This museum is a must for anyone who visits Vienna for the first time. It is very interesting and engaging. You would see  Vienna from before humanity to our time.
I personally love museums of this kind - spacious but without choking amounts of artifacts,  so you can pay attention to every item on display.
Note that there are original statues from St. Stephan Cathedral in the museum. The ones that you see on the walls of the Cathedral are replicas.
My favorite parts were the Masonic section and Klimt.
You can easily spend a whole day here. Nice cafe on the premises will keep you charged.
Did I mention it's free? Yep! It's.

Incredible museum covering a wide history of Vienna, Austria, and global influence. Highly recommended museum, also it is an excellent architectural restoration.

If you have time, this is an excellent spot to spend 1-2 hours.

I only went to one part of the museum, the one with the reconstruction of Vienna and Austrian culture after WW2 and it was very informative and interesting. There is even a small movie theatre where you can watch films that were shown at that time. I also liked how the text is very interesting and at the same time easy to understand. I went in the morning on Thursday and it wasn’t really crowded. Definitely recommend visiting the museum.

One of the very few museums that is free in Vienna, as we all know that all museums here are pretty expensive to get in. This one is free for the permanent exhibition on three floors which could easily take you at least a couple of hours to get through them. So picture you have enough time to look through all these interesting artifacts.

I would say that the contents were all quite interesting but there's just a little bit too much of reading. At least they have translations in both German and English all over. But maybe the lack of curation pertaining to those who are not familiar with Vienna it is quite hard to understand the contents and follow what is going on.

But I guess these pieces of mental jigsaws will be completely put together as we move around the cities and keeping in mind what we have seen here at the museum, especially in the area of infrastructural building, cultural underpinnings, and a deep history of art and culture that is embedded within every fabric of how the city operates.

The top floor of the building has a really nice balcony where you can have wine and coffee. But you can always just come up here and enjoy the sightseeing and scenery of the bird's eye view of the central Vienna as well for free. So recommend that a lot to those people who want to find a spot to sit down and relax without having to spend money.

One of the most beautiful churches of Viena. You can visit paying an entrance tax. Are included the orga area, church itself and panoramic level by climbing circular stairs.
Nice view of Vien from above.

placeMetadata.name: Spanish Riding School

sources.snippet: The Spanish riding school in Vienna is the only institution in the world that still practice Classic equestrian skills. You can experience the performance of Lipizzan horses in perfect harmony with the music, which shows the centuries-old traditions. Füssen Stainless Steel Water Bottle
sources.shortName: Vienna's Top 6 Palaces to Visit and Explore: Step into the World of Royalty

placeMetadata.description: Riding school dating back to 1735 & training white Lipizzaner stallions, with regular tours & shows.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Spanish Riding School, also known as the Spanische Hofreitschule, is a historic institution dating back to 1735. It was established by Emperor Maximilian II and is renowned for training white Lipizzaner stallions. Located in the Baroque Winter Riding School within the grounds of Vienna's Hofburg Palace, it offers regular tours and shows that showcase impressive equestrian skills.

reviews.reviewText:
We had the privilege of visiting the Spanish Horse training school in Vienna, and it was an unforgettable experience! I watched the morning exercises of the horses, and I was mesmerized by their elegance and poise.

At the beginning they request everyone not to take photos and videos of horses during the entire show.

The training session was impressive, with skilled riders expertly guiding the horses through intricate maneuvers. The horses' movements were fluid and precise, showcasing their exceptional training and discipline.

What struck me most was the obvious bond between the horses and their riders. The trust, respect, and affection were palpable, making the experience even more enjoyable.

The facilities where the show was conducted were immaculate, with beautifully maintained seats and galleries. The Institution has an history of 460 years of horse training and breeding the pure lineage.

Recommended for: Horse lovers, equestrian enthusiasts, and anyone seeking a unique experience in Vienna!"

Please press ❤️ if you like my review

As someone who is an equestrian (and very novice dressage rider), this kind of place is a dream! Glad to have seen a morning performance and witnessed the skill on show.

Bought standing tickets on the right hand gallery, and arrived 30 minutes before the show. Fair amount of standing only had already started to find their places by that time, and we guessed somewhere in the middle would be best but equally think somewhere about a third of the way down each end would also work.

If you’re not interested in horsemanship or have never watched dressage, you might not find this show as “entertaining” but it really is lovely to watch.

Please note: taking photos is PROHIBITED during the show!
If, like me, you were looking forward to admiring the show while filming or taking photos... Prepare yourself for a huge disappointment (I was).
The show itself is enjoyable, but not exceptional.
You can see more impressive acts in a circus than at the Spanish Riding School. If you're expecting breathtaking pirouettes or mind-blowing tricks, you're in for another bitter disappointment.
Add to this the fact that prices range from a few hundred euros for a premium numbered seat to around 25 euros for an unreserved standing place (first come, first served),
and that's for only a 45 minutes show,
and that you have to wait in line for over 30 minutes to even have a chance of getting a good standing place...
It's up to you to do the math and decide if it's worth it.

I'll probably surprise you by saying it's worth it!
You're in Vienna, and the setting and atmosphere are unique.
After all, you're in a wing of the Hofburg, and the experience is priceless.

The History alone, related to this School, which continues 100’s of years later, is astonishing.

Is it pricey. Yup. But, worth every penny.

Amazing display of Horsemanship.

And of course Rider talent was at a level never seen by me before.

A bit confusing getting to the right section of stairways leading to the show area, but there is help around to assist.

Next to the ZOO this was my favorite Animal related thing to do in Vienna.

The venue is beautiful, but the training session was rather dull. Unless you are knowledgable in horse riding it is hard to appreciate the skill. The commentary was interesting and at a good pace. Our seats were also good and not obstructed by pillars. Would only recommend going if you really want to, otherwise skip it.

There are a number of options to visit. We selected the ticket at €26 (standing) each to see a 45 minute show which began at 11am.

Clearly there is emphasis to sell many tickets as there were so many people it was hard to move causing a concern if a fire started.

Staff could learn some manners by the way they talk to visitors.

The 45 minute show itself was in 3 parts and really the 3rd part was the best which I would call a show and not rehearsals dressed up to look like a show.

Oh yes, apparently you are not allowed (abruptly told to not do so) to take video or photographs so here is what I managed to take!

Viewing the stables does not cost anything.

Clearly counting on the fame of the riding school for people to book without any care for them.

A must visit either to see the stables on a tour or see the performance.
Be aware, If you want to see the performance book well in advance because tickets sell out very quickly.
I brought my tickets direct from Spanish Riding School and for my seat on the side it  was £90 ( Sept 2025 prices). Yes it's cheaper to stand and you get not a bad view but you get a much better view sitting down. Also no rucksacks are allowed inside the area, But i found  left luggage lockers at Vienna Central Station for my small rucksack for 2 euros ( Sept 2025 prices)
It only goes on for approx 1 hrs and 10 mins but so enjoyable in a beautiful area.
The riders were brilliant in their handling of the horses and the classical music complented the moves the riders made. The lippinaners are so strong and you even see some young lippinaners. The whole experience is just a lovely, feel good, watch.

placeMetadata.name: Palais Schönborn

sources.snippet: Palais Schönborn-Batthyány is a charming Baroque palace tucked away in Vienna’s Josefstadt district. Built in the early 18th century for the Schönborn family, this architectural gem is now home to the Museum of Folk Life and Folk Art. Visitors can explore the intricately decorated rooms and enjoy the extensive collection of traditional Austrian crafts, costumes, and folk art.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Schönborn is a Baroque townhouse in Vienna, once the residence of Count Batthyany and designed by the same architect responsible for Schönbrunn Palace. The Vienna Baroque Orchestra hosts regular concerts there, offering emotional and interesting performances. The staff is accommodating, as they rescheduled a late arrival without hesitation. While the coat check only accepts cash and refreshments are extra, VIP tickets provide prime seating.

reviews.reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this little concert. Going in, I didn’t expect much but it was a great selection of music pieces, beautifully played. Reading other reviews, there seems to be better price tickets on the street but I booked mine at full price from the official website.

I attended a performance by the Vienna Baroque Orchestra and was truly enchanted by the experience. Even though I’m not typically into classical music, I found the performance beautiful and easy to enjoy. The venue wasn’t huge, with just six musicians and two opera singers, so it felt intimate rather than grand, but the sound was still impressive.
I had a B-class ticket and was pleasantly surprised to be seated fairly close to the front, where I had a clear view. One thing to note is that in winter, coats have to be stored and they charge 1 euro per coat.
I purchased my ticket through an app, which was quick and convenient. Overall, a fantastic experience!

The palace is incredible.  I really enjoyed the concert by the Baroque  Orchestra.  Great selection of music pieces, beautiful played.
Staff very friendly.
I definitely recommend it.

The palace was incredible. The audioguide was excellent and very well explained
The only downside is the crow, definitely too many people outside and inside the palace
Attended a concert here today. An up and personal classical concert ffioedd with popular classical music. Well worth the visit.

I bought concert ticket on street at noon, 39Euro, for 6:30pm show, pay cash! Then I went back to hotel till 5 pm to the location, the door was not opened, I was kind of sad, maybe it’s  fake, so I went for dinner and come back at six, it opened! At the end, I did enjoyed a nice violent, piano, cello music concert, very nice one! But what if it was cancelled, I then don’t know what to do!

Beautiful palace with wonderful Easter markets selling gifts, food and trinkets. Easy to reach via metro.  There is a paid toilet in the ticket office area and an indoor cafe.  The gardens are beautiful and a bit hilly!
Beautiful concert hall, amazing performance 👏 ❤️

placeMetadata.name: Palais Daun-Kinsky

sources.snippet: Situated on Vienna’s historic Freyung Square, Palais Daun-Kinsky is an exquisite example of Rococo architecture. Built in the early 18th century for Count Wirich Philipp von Daun, this beautifully preserved palace is now an exclusive event venue. Although not open to the general public, visitors can admire the stunning façade and intricate detailing on the exterior of the palace.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

placeMetadata.description: Early 18th-century stucco palace adorned with paintings & sculpture, available for private events.

reviews.reviewText: This is a free entrance place in Vienna! For not paying anything, one can go inside and take the stairs to the upper floor. That’s it, no more no less!  However, all the details are amazing and that ceiling is simply perfect! Giving 5 stars, because it’s very beautiful and one cannot be pretentious when it’s for free.

Palais Daun-Kinsky is one of the hidden gems of Vienna. While it's centrally located, I think it's not on the itinerary of many people. It's free to visit and it's a jewel and a masterpiece of an architectural pleasure.

It's greatly ornated, painted and built, remembering of times that have passed. This is where history still lives.

It's perfect for taking pictures that you'll look back to and remember of this beautiful place.

This building is free to enter, but it is very small. There is nothing to see, just the paintings on the walls, decorations, and ceilings. So there is not much to see, but if you have time, come here.

My current favorite palace near the center of Vienna.
It is available for booking events but also has a hall that you can visit for free
Magnificent, extraordinary and classical interior filled with carved stone and painted ceilings.

Impressive place which you can visit for free. One of the most beautiful and, most important, well maintained palaces I’ve seen. Great place for photoshoots. It’s not big but very neat and cozy. Don’t pass by if you’re in Vienna.

I came here on the recommendation of a friend who lives in Vienna. He told me that if you want to see the most beautiful painted ceiling, you must visit this palace. Do I need to mention that the entrance is free!!! Trust me, it's worth coming and seeing something like this.
Magnificent architecture. Entry free of charge and it seems this place is quite hidden from the public as it was empty when we were there. Managed to take some amazing photos

The opening hours were confusing, since Google Maps doesn’t show them correctly. iPhone Maps said it’s open on Fridays from 10 am to 3 pm. I went on a Friday at 9 am and first entered the wrong side. Then I found the correct entrance (you have to go inside the building and to the left). It was open and completely empty. Truly impressive, very beautiful and free!!

placeMetadata.name: Palais Esterházy

sources.snippet: The Esterházy family is one of the most distinguished families of Vienna, and there have been as many as 14 palaces bearing their name across the city. This particular one isn’t open to the public, but it’s still worth a look. Walk through to the courtyards to marvel at the neo-Classical and Baroque facade.
sources.shortName: Discover The Best Palaces in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Esterházy, one of the 14 palaces bearing the distinguished Esterhazy name in Vienna, is a sight to behold. While not usually open to the public, it still offers a glimpse of its neo-Classical and Baroque facade in the courtyards. Once a year, during monument open days in September, visitors can explore its interior with highlights including the reception/music room, dining room adorned with Japanese decor, and a showroom featuring numerous portraits.

reviews.reviewText: always great to stroll old town. this palais hosts one of the finest pizza places from vienna. best of all they even made us zabaione to please

Part of our free tour so I don't really know anything about the place except for when a German speaking person pronounces the name it sounds kind of like something else. This was pointed out by a woman in the free tour group. She almost felt frightened by the pronunciation.
More than cool!

(Translated by Google) Beautiful palace that houses a few banks. Is accessible to the general public once a year, on the open days of monuments. (September).
You see the reception/music room, then the dining room (halved by the sofa desk that is there) with beautiful Japanese decor. Then a show room with a number of portraits.

(Original)
Mooi paleis waar paar banken in gehuisvest zijn . Is 1x per jaar toegankelijk voor gewone publiek en wel op de open dagen van monumenten. ( september) .
Je ziet de ontvangst/ muziekzaal , daarna de eetzaal ( gehalveerd door het bank bureau wat er zit ) met prachtige Japans decor . Daarna een pronkzaal met aantal portretten.

(Translated by Google) Incredibly bad guides. At the 2019 Open House event, a family was kicked out after waiting 40 minutes on the tour just because the kids were a bit loud. Incredible 'understanding' guide and prejudiced old people who laughed... NOTHING about you discussed architecture at all.  Toxic.

(Original)
Unglaubliche schlechte Guides. Beim Open House event 2019, ist eine Familie rausgeschmiessen worden nachdem sie 40 min auf dem tour gewartet haben, nur weil die Kinder ein bisschen laut waren. Unglaubliche 'verständninsvoller' Guide und vorurteilsvoller alte Menschen die noch dazu gelacht haben.. überhaupt NICHTS über dir Architektur besprochen.  Toxisch.

(Translated by Google) In the 2nd courtyard of the palace is the small, fine Contemplor Gallery where great artists always exhibit their works.
There is a good pizzeria in the first courtyard

(Original)
Im 2. Hof des Palais befindet sich die kleine feine Contemplor Galerie in der immer wieder tolle Künstler ihre Werke ausstellen.
Im 1. Hof gibt es eine gute Pizzeria

(Translated by Google) Mileda for you!! Todo cerrado, impossible to see the palace! The organ room looks very abandoned! shame!!!

(Original)
Mileda pa ti!! Todo cerrado , impossible veure el palau! La sala de l’orgue es veu molt abandonada! Vergonya!!!

(Translated by Google) Very fine👌

(Original)
Sehr fein👌

placeMetadata.name: Palais Niederösterreich

sources.snippet: Come enjoy an magical 1.5-hour concert the beautiful Viennese palace, Palais Niederösterreich. You'll be carried away by romantic arias, fun polkas, and traditional waltzes played by the Vienna Supreme Orchestra, a pillar of music excellence in Vienna.
sources.shortName: Best Castle & palace tours in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the heart of Vienna, Palais Niederösterreich is a stunning venue that exudes charm and history. This beautifully maintained palace serves as an enchanting backdrop for various events, including captivating concerts featuring the renowned Vienna Supreme Orchestra. Guests are treated to a delightful mix of romantic arias, lively polkas, and traditional waltzes that create an unforgettable atmosphere. The elegant interior boasts magnificent ceiling frescoes that enhance the overall experience, making each performance feel magical.

reviews.reviewText: Went there for a classical music recital and I had the best time of my life. I highly recommend "Strauss & Mozart Concerts in the Kursalon". The room was beautiful. Perhaps a little less light during the performance would have make it even better. Nevertheless, the musics, singers, dancers, everything was so amazing!
A touch of royalty with Austrian hospitality. Nice venue for events such as weddings etc.

Originally the seat of the Lower Austrian Estates, this Renaissance palace hosted key political events. Its grand halls, including the Assembly Hall, showcase neoclassical details, highlighting the building’s role in regional governance and Austrian legislative history.
Lovely building with magnificent ceiling fresco complimented by the classical, fun musical performance.

Incredible wood carvings! Very modern backrooms - this location has it all! Perfect for balls, bat and bar-mitzvahs, weddings and all! Very nice staff, two Perfect equipped kitchens, elevators where you need them!
Great location , houses the representation of Lower-Austria in Vienna.
The best wedding hall in Austria.
Very nice

placeMetadata.name: Palais Schwarzenberg

sources.shortName: Discover The Best Palaces in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: 1907 summertime palace housing a casino & restaurant & showcasing expansive baroque-style grounds.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Schwarzenberg, a 1907 summertime palace, is a Baroque landmark in Vienna still owned by the Schwarzenberg family. It houses a casino, restaurant, and expansive baroque-style grounds. Parts of the palace have been transformed into a five-star hotel while other areas host concerts and events. Visitors may be lucky enough to see the richly decorated marble gallery during their visit.

reviews.reviewText: Vienna is one of the best spots in Europe for a summer vacation, offering a perfect blend of rich culture and historic grandeur. The city’s vibrant arts scene, majestic architecture, and lush gardens make it an unforgettable destination. Whether you’re exploring the imperial palaces, enjoying classical music performances, or savoring the local cuisine, Vienna promises a truly regal experience.

palais schwarzenberg itself is a bit of a mystery for tourists. it's this huge, baroque palace, but it's not really open to the public for tours like schönbrunn or belvedere. it was a hotel for a while. you can still admire it from the outside, of course, and it looks impressive, with its grand facade and all.
​but the real action is on schwarzenbergplatz, the big square right in front of it. here, you’ll find two really striking things that are super easy to visit: a monument and a fountain.
​first, the soviet war memorial (or monument of soldiers). it's a huge, dramatic monument dedicated to the red army soldiers who died liberating vienna from the nazis. it has this big marble colonnade and a bronze statue of a soldier holding a soviet flag and a shield. it's really grand and a little imposing, and it's interesting to see this specific piece of history right there in the middle of a beautiful european city. it's definitely a powerful sight.
​then, right in front of the memorial, is the hochstrahlbrunnen fountain. this fountain is amazing, especially at night. it was built to celebrate vienna's first alpine spring water pipeline, which is a pretty cool reason for a fountain. it shoots these huge jets of water way up into the air, and it's lit up with different colors after dark. the square itself is busy with trams and traffic, but these two landmarks are definitely worth a stop and a photo
Nice place to visit. Only visited from outside due to no time left.

This historic Baroque palace, built in the 17th century, is known for its elegant architecture and landscaped gardens. It has served various purposes, including hosting diplomatic events, and remains a significant aristocratic residence in Vienna.
Peaceful vibe to chill in front of the fountain
Beautiful building if you look close enough you can see masterpiece inscriptions on walls.
Nice place and square
A must see if ur doing the Vienna sights. Beautiful architecture

placeMetadata.name: Palais Ferstel

sources.snippet: Palais Ferstel is an impressive 19th-century palace located in the heart of Vienna. Originally built as the Austro-Hungarian National Bank, it now houses a variety of businesses, including a famous café, a ballroom, and several event spaces. With its stunning Venetian-style architecture, the Palais Ferstel is an excellent example of Vienna’s historic charm and elegance.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

placeMetadata.description: Grand 1850s mansion used for events and a landmark cafe, once a hangout of Sigmund Freud & Trotsky.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Ferstel is a grand 1850s mansion in Vienna, known for its landmark cafe and as a popular meeting place for influential figures like Sigmund Freud and Trotsky. The traditional cafe, which opened in 1876, is celebrated for its beautiful interior and was once frequented by leading lights in art, literature, politics, and science. The Italianate palace hosts the famous Cafe Central on its ground floor with a tiny outdoor terrace.

reviews.reviewText: Located within historic Vienna, on the edge of Freyung square is this ornate structure, it has a lovely passageway, with a fountain topped with a bronze danube nymph,  a must visit when exploring the city.

One of the local favorite palaces inside the city.
Unique exterior with an even greater interior.
Authentic Viennese shops cover the ground floor as the Palace above shines through different even lights and concerts.
Home to a famous Cafe with years of authentic history
I think this palace is a hidden gem. You can walk through in a couple of minutes for free. Also there is a passage with a fountain.

This is one of the most beautiful passages in Vienna. It has lovely cafés and small shops. The place has a special charm, with its old-style design and quiet atmosphere. The view down the passage is simply magical - a peaceful blend of history, elegance and Viennese café culture.
Amazing event venue with impressive decoration in the main hall. Looks like it was connected with church, on a ceiling you can see Jesus Christ statues. In the lighting it looks fantastic.
Beautifull place. Very 9ld!
Stunning prestigious venue in central Vienna, perfect for exclusive galas, weddings and events. Highly recommended for memorable celebrations.

Palais Ferstel, a historic gem in Vienna, showcases a blend of Renaissance and Baroque architecture. From hosting prestigious events to housing upscale shops and cafes, it remains a vibrant destination where history and modernity converge, offering visitors a glimpse into Vienna's rich cultural heritage. Originally constructed in the 19th century, has been a hub for commerce, culture, and social gatherings throughout its storied history. With its grand halls and opulent ballrooms, it has welcomed dignitaries and luminaries, continuing to enchant guests with its timeless beauty and cultural significance.

placeMetadata.name: Sisi Museum

sources.snippet: If you are interested to learn about the lifestyle of the Habsburg Empress, then you shouldn’t miss an opportunity to visit Sisi Museum located in Hofburg Palace in Vienna. The museum is dedicated to the life of Empress Elisabeth, known as Sisi. In the museum, you can find a collection of clothes, jewelry, and portraits of Empress Elisabeth, and you can get a sneak peek at her lifestyle, interests, and her struggles.
sources.shortName: Vienna's Top 6 Palaces to Visit and Explore: Step into the World of Royalty

placeMetadata.description: Extravagant silver, porcelain & crystal-glass tableware, once used for dining in the Imperial court.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Sisi Museum, located within the Imperial Palace (Hofburg) in Vienna, offers a captivating glimpse into the life of Duchess Elisabeth of Bavaria, also known as Sisi. Despite its name, the museum not only features personal items and memorabilia of Sisi but also provides an insight into the private chambers of Emperor Franz Joseph and his wife. Visitors can marvel at extravagant silver, porcelain, and crystal-glass tableware once used for dining in the Imperial court.

reviews.reviewText:
I didn’t know who Empress Sisi was before I came to Vienna. She was quite the fashionista. Such a tiny waist!!!
Beautiful rooms. Can see why they would need the admission prices to maintain the rooms and clothes

We didn’t go inside after reading mixed reviews, but the building from the outside is absolutely stunning. It’s part of the Hofburg Palace complex, with grand architecture, domes, and arches. The museum sits on a lovely square, surrounded by impressive buildings, shops, and cafés, so it’s a great place to stroll around and soak up the atmosphere.

Too many people were inside. Had to book a ticket for a slot over 1.5 hours later, hence I expected a smaller pile up of people. I don't know how but I missed that the audio tours were free, meaning that I did not grasp the entire story. It was, however, beautiful to see various dresses and objects touched or owned by Sisi. Apparently a royal bed for one was just a regular sized bed and not king sized bed for Sisi.

I was excited to visit this museum in Vienna, but overall, I found it a bit overrated. The dining area was under construction, which was disappointing, especially after a long visit.

Many of the famous furniture pieces I had seen online were missing or not on display, which made the experience feel incomplete. I also ended up having to walk through the entire museum twice because large sections were blocked by tour groups, making it hard to access certain areas the first time around.

The architecture is beautiful, and there are some interesting exhibits, but the overall experience didn’t meet my expectations.

We bought tickets in advance and entered without any queue. The appartments are impressive but the museum itself is not well suited for crowds. We know the building can’t be changed but maybe some slotted opening/max allowance of people at each time could change this. We were unable to enjoy it since we got pushed constantly by people in the narrow walkways.

We visited other museums that had much more original pieces and impressed us much more.

Good not great.

Really enjoyed walking through the museum with the audio guide, very informative and interesting information. Some parts of it were a bit crowded due to small rooms. Took around an hour to get through it all, would recommend. Book your tickets in advance as on the day tickets were sold out.

The Sisi Museum totally exceeded my expectation, such a fascinating and beautifully done space. It’s inside the Hofburg Palace, which already feels super regal, and the way they tell Empress Elisabeth’s story is honestly captivating. You get to see her dresses, personal items, and even read about her intense fitness routines and poetry. It dives into both the glam and the pressure of royal life, and you leave feeling like you actually got to know her.

The museum is really capturing the essence of Empress Elizabeth and offered an intimate look at her life.
I purchased tickets for the last timed entrance of the day and had a really pleasant experience without too many people. While I was familiar with Sisi’s story, I found the Audioguide packed with great information about her life. Through her personal items, clothing, portraits and living space, you could feel somewhat closer to her and her poetry really showcased her feeling of being an outsider in the rigid court life.
I had also visited her palace in Corfu and it was interesting to compare this ornate but somewhat cold palace to the sunny and open villa on Corfu where she trying to find solace from her pain and mental anguish.
If you are fascinated by Sisi’s story like I am, this is a “Do not miss”.

sources.snippet: This palace is the most ill-fated of all Vienna’s palaces, at least according to some. Archduke Franz Josef, the last Austrian emperor, resided here and during the Second World War the building was heavily bombed. It has risen from the ashes later on, and the gradual restoration of historical rooms has returned it to its days of glory.

Love to sit there outside right by the Prater Hauptallee.  It's nice and quiet, which I prefer over the crowds that you usually have when eating inside the Prater. The food is good, although a little pricey, but not outrageous.

Amazing food with good service. Due to the quality of the restaurant and service, the prices are high, and it’s not affordable for everyone.
The tasting starting plate was amazing. The fishes were great, the meatball was very tasty.
The salmon was great as well.
The meat soup was the greatest soup I’ve ever had. The schnitzel was very tasty, but the potatoes that came with it were absolutely fantastic.
One of our favorite place in Vienna. We go here anytime we visit Prater. The staff is very kind and the food is top-notch.

Lovely and friendly staff
Very delicious veal schnitzel

Meierei is a great traditional Austrian restaurant located in the middle of one of the biggest parks in Vienna. The food is simple but amazing quality we had Chicken Schnitzel and Goulash and both were perfect. Also the desserts were Austrian traditional refined dough baked in the oven with sheer grains of pleasure. Most of all, the service was just the best!

ALL AVOID. no sign for cash only, didnt say the bill amount at the end and tried to pressure my wife into giving 10 euros for one coke, they own the only atm nearby which had a £5 fee, clear tax avoidance.

A great spot! We sat outside on the beautiful deck, enjoyed drinks and food. Both were good,  service was great,  and I think the prices are very reasonable.
Definitely recommended 👌

the navigation is very confusing + at night this area is hidden in the shadows, which adds to the difficulty of finding your bus :(

reviews.reviewText: I cannot put into words how bad our experience was. We had booked a double room in one of the properties. Upon our arrival we noticed that the room had not been cleaned (think dirty towels on the floor and stains on the sheets), so we called the number and they put us in a different property, which was across town, making us miss a reservation. The new accomodations had communal bathrooms and kitchens  (when we had paid for our own), a broken window (it's February) and a fire alarm that was out of battery so it kept beeping every thirty seconds all night long. We called again in the morning asking to be put back in the room we had paid for, with the assurance that it would be clean at three o'clock. It was not. Nobody had been there, at which point (after another phone call assuring us it would be fine in the evening) we cancelled our reservation (fool me twice). The one star is for the friendly support staff on the phone. Unbelievable.

placeMetadata.name: Statue of Archduke Albrecht

sources.snippet: Connected to the Augustinan Monestry stands the Palais Archduke Albrecht. In the early 19th century some members of the imperial family lived in this Palace.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles and Palaces near Vienna

placeMetadata.address: The Albertina Museum, Statue von Erzherzog Albrecht, Albertinapl. 1, 1010 Wien, Austria

reviews.reviewText: Great memorial and stunning bronze figure.
Escalator to go up. Great night view. Not sure about day light view

This monument is on the upper level of the Albertina where the entrance is located. Great views of the Vienna State Opera from the upper level. Fans of the movie Before Sunrise will recognise that this is a prominent landmark in the film.

This monument stands in tribute to Archduke Albrecht and second son of Archduke Karl and Henriette of Nassau-Weilburg. He is noted for his military success against the then emerging Prussian state.

The monument is a bronze equestrian sculpture of Albrecht wearing his field marshals uniform. His left hand is holding the reins of his horse, while his right holds the marshal’s baton. The sculpture is larger than life and depicts Albrecht at his most impressive.

The monument is located at the Albertina, on the Augustinian Bastion just outside the entrance on the upper level, but you’ll likely spot it if walking towards the art gallery as it’s pretty high up.
There is an elevator on the east side so you don't need climb stairs from the west side garden

There are many equestrian statues which can be seen around Vienna, including that of Archduke Albert (Erzherzog Albrecht) which is located on the upper-floor outdoor area in front of the entrance to the Albertina Museum. The statue overlooks Albertina-platz and can be seen clearly from this area.

Archduke Albert (1847-1895) served notably in the Austria-Hungary army. His monument was designed by German sculptor Kaspar von Zumbusch in 1898-99 and depicts the Archduke in military attire, riding his horse confidently. He seems to be peering into the distance. The statue is situated upon a oval shaped pedestal with decorative bronze reliefs on each side.

Take a few minutes to view an enjoy this monument before entering Albertina Museum, if you enjoy this time of sightseeing during your travels.

Big and magnificent monument that is located adjacent to the main entrance of Albertina museum.
I guess it's time to clean the statue.
24/7 open
It is a nice vantage point overlooking the opera. There is an escalator going up. Nice viewpoint. Good people watching.
