sources.shortName: Best Castle & palace tours in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Discover the beauty of Vienna's Schönbrunn Palace Gardens with the Free Walking Tour Schönbrunn Palace Garden by Prime Tours Vienna. While touring the palace itself may require a ticket, the gardens are open to the public for free. Joining this walking tour provides an exceptional experience led by knowledgeable guides like Michael, who offer insightful commentary and a wealth of historical knowledge.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently had the pleasure of joining the Free Walking Tour Schönbrunn Palace Garden with Prime Tours Vienna, and I must say it was an absolutely fantastic experience. Our guide, Michael, provided an exceptional tour filled with insightful commentary and a wealth of knowledge.

Michael's passion for history and the palace garden was evident from the moment the tour began. His deep understanding of the site's historical significance and attention to detail truly brought the place to life. He expertly navigated us through the expansive garden, sharing captivating stories and anecdotes that made the tour both educational and entertaining.

What impressed me the most was Michael's ability to cater to the diverse interests and questions of the group. He effortlessly engaged with everyone, ensuring that each person felt included and their curiosity was satisfied. His friendly and approachable demeanor made the experience even more enjoyable.

The tour itself was well-structured and paced perfectly. We had ample time to appreciate the stunning beauty of the garden, explore hidden corners, and take in the breathtaking views. Michael's ability to provide historical context and explain the intricate details of the garden's design added an extra layer of appreciation to the experience.

I highly recommend Prime Tours Vienna and their Free Walking Tour Schönbrunn Palace Garden to anyone visiting Vienna. The combination of a knowledgeable guide like Michael and the magnificent setting of the palace garden creates a truly memorable experience. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply someone looking to soak in the beauty of this iconic location, this tour is an absolute must.

Thanks for providing such a memorable and insightful tour experience. I look forward to exploring more of Vienna with you
in the future.

Cheers
F

I couldn't reach the meeting point in time and reached late by 15 minutes. There was no facility to call the guide and join the tour there after. We lost tour booking amount and had to buy fresh tickets which costed 68 Euro. We advise the tourist to buy tickets at the palace only as this agency does not provide any facilities to communicate or cancel the tour in case of any eventuality.
A wonderful walking tour. Stroll the gardens, take some great pictures and have a fun time.

It's really worth visiting, but I didn't like the "pride" flags and all this advertisement of the guy community.  Also for the wc you are asking for 50cents, you could at least have a machine for change...

sources.snippet: Located in the picturesque town of Bad Ischl, about 70 kilometers from Vienna, the Kaiservilla was the summer residence of Emperor Franz Joseph I and Empress Elisabeth (Sisi). This charming villa, set amidst lush gardens and surrounded by the stunning scenery of the Salzkammergut region, offers a glimpse into the private lives of the imperial couple. Guided tours of the Kaiservilla provide visitors with insights into the history of the Habsburgs and an opportunity to admire the lavish interiors and personal belongings of the royal family.
sources.shortName: Famous Castles in Vienna: Discover the Grandeur of Austria's Capital

sources.snippet: Residenz (Salzburg): The seat of the Salzburg prince-bishops, this opulent palace dates from 1120. Over the years, newer palaces were added to form an ecclesiastical complex. On the palace's second floor is a 15-room art gallery filled with the works of 16th- to 18th-century European masters.
sources.shortName: The Best Castles, Palaces & Historic Homes in Austria

(Translated by Google) When it came time for us to find a suitable retirement home for my grandmother, we of course had a lot of worries and concerns. But from the moment we walked into the Downtown Residence, we knew we had made the right decision.

(Translated by Google) Before I decided to move to the Josefstadt Residence, I 'test lived' there twice for a week each. No horse foot found. I've been living here for over a year now - still no smell of the devil. As I got older, I became quite afraid of them

None of this in the Josefstadt Residence. The unfurnished apartments are simply well planned and high-class: 3.40 meters high, white walls in all apartments, light parquet on underfloor heating (individually controlled), box windows - not even the tram makes any noise; Because of the solid construction in 1905, you can't hear the neighbors, upper and lower bars either. placeMetadata.description:
Inzersdorf was before 1938 an independent municipality, and is now a part of the 23rd Viennese district Liesing.
Today, the cadastral commune Inzersdorf has got an area of 854.06 hectares and is so on the biggest part of the district. Wikipedia.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Inzersdorf, once an independent municipality until 1938, is now a part of the 23rd Viennese district Liesing. This area spans over 854.06 hectares, making it the largest part of the district. Inzersdorf offers a blend of history and modernity within Vienna, making it an intriguing destination to explore.

placeMetadata.name: Neue Burg - Teil der Wiener Hofburg
placeMetadata.description: Incomplete 19th century palace wing hosting Kunsthistorisches Museum collections, including armory.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Neue Burg, a 19th-century palace wing within the Wiener Hofburg complex, houses the Kunsthistorisches Museum collections, including an impressive armory. It is also home to three museums: the Collection of Ancient Musical Instruments, featuring a diverse array of instruments; the Ephesos Museum, showcasing artifacts from Austrian archaeologists' excavations in Turkey; and the Arms and Armour museum, displaying armor mainly from the 15th and 16th centuries.

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful neo-classic palace surrounded by beautiful and spacious squares and gardens. A very monumental building. Pay close attention to the statues on top of the rooftops. They are absolutely gorgeous.

A place where you can spend hours and hours without getting tired.   A place that is a witness of magnificent history, art and architecture, but also a place that shows how priceless heritage is preserved, with great respect.  Beautiful gardens for enjoying the sun.  A PLACE NOT TO BE MISSED!

🏰 The Imperial Palace at night. Absolutely breathtaking.
Even more majestic than during the day. You can feel the 600 years of Habsburg power. It’s not just beautiful — it’s monumental.

You’re standing in the very heart of imperial Vienna, where history and architecture speak volumes about Austria’s powerful past.

Places like this — where the past feels grand, glorious, and alive — are exactly the kind of places I fall in love with.
As someone fascinated by the stories of Emperor Franz Joseph and obsessed with beautifully crafted historical dramas, this was nothing short of magical.
While many associate Vienna with the romance of Before Sunrise, I’m far more drawn to the city’s imperial, historical soul.

I’m officially in love with Vienna. 💙

I bought an annual ticket for 40 euros, covering 7 museums. The museum contained a carefully prepared collection. It's really the first time I've seen so many preserved and different knightly historical artifacts. The rest of the museum was full of different and interesting war pieces.
Historical building with different museums, we visited the history of Austria and it was interesting to look around and understand more about Austria.

Entrance is included in the Vienna pass. They have a big collection from all around the world. And unique pieces are very well preserved. The cafe is nice to have a break and the staff is really nice.

The architecture is just stunning on this building. Take a moment to wander around and take it all in.

It's very much a part of Vienna's historic past.

Late Aug24-walk from Burggarten or from the ring or Maria Theresanplatz. Nearby has lots of majestic buildings and Wein museum.
This place is awesome and has vast buildings and more statues to the Emperor
The archway is big and impressive. Fun to be had in the sentry columns!

placeMetadata.name: Neugebäude Palace
placeMetadata.description: 16th-century Renaissance palace & former imperial residence, with guided tours, festivals & events.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Neugebäude Palace is a 16th-century Renaissance palace and former imperial residence in Vienna. It hosts a variety of events throughout the year, including the spring festival, medieval festival, Halloween celebrations, Christmas market, and open-air summer movie theatre. The palace also offers guided tours. While it was once home to an Austrian king, today it serves as a venue for diverse cultural happenings.

reviews.reviewText: A huge Mannerist castle and new park near the Central Cemetery.

Was there for a dragon exception
Half of the status wasn't there because of a wedding and regulatory limitation.
Still paid full price, also wasn't wheelchair / buggy friendly!
Very fun place for kids and adult
This is not the Schloss Neugebäude. No idea what is in the Singerstraße, but the Schloss is Otmar-Brix-Gasse 1, 1110 Wien

nice place with different style events all year around. spring festival, medieval festival, Halloween, Christmas market and much more. not to forget the open air summer movie theatre. only negative thing about that is that all movies are only in german!

An old renaissance building where a former Austrian king lived a while. Used as a location for different events. In the front area there are some streetkitchen and a bar and you can sit outside there in summer.
Really nice location in the summer. Were there for the "Kino im Schloss". Nice athmosphere, nice "food court" with couple of restaurants. Highly recommended for a summer afternoon/night.
Nice place, the Mittelalter Fest took place here. It was awesome experience. Very near to the Central cemetery of Vienna, beside the pet cemetery.

ops.insert: Baroque, 18th-century palaces housing art from Middle Ages to today, with notable Klimt collection.
18th-century summer palace with tours of lavish rococo ceremonial rooms, plus gardens with a maze.
Habsburg palace complex with ornate, baroque interiors, imperial apartments & a silver museum.
19th-century Habsburg palace with staterooms & collections of old master prints & 20th-century art.
Museum housing secular & religious treasure collected by Austrian emperors over last 1,000 years.
Extravagant silver, porcelain & crystal-glass tableware, once used for dining in the Imperial court.
Early 18th-century stucco palace adorned with paintings & sculpture, available for private events.
1907 summertime palace housing a casino & restaurant & showcasing expansive baroque-style grounds.
Museum with exhibits on city's history from Roman times to the present, plus art by Klimt & Schiele.
Riding school dating back to 1735 & training white Lipizzaner stallions, with regular tours & shows.
Grand 1850s mansion used for events and a landmark cafe, once a hangout of Sigmund Freud & Trotsky.

Today, the cadastral commune Inzersdorf has got an area of 854.06 hectares and is so on the biggest part of the district. Wikipedia.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Vienna, the city of music and dreams, is not just known for its vibrant culture and rich history but also for its stunning castles that transport you back in time. From the opulent Schönbrunn Palace, with its striking yellow facade and beautifully manicured gardens, to the majestic Hofburg, which once served as the imperial residence, each castle tells a unique story of Austria's royal past. As you wander through these architectural marvels, you'll find yourself captivated by their intricate designs and the tales of the emperors and empresses who once called them home.

The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the hidden gems and iconic landmarks that make Vienna a must-visit destination. Whether you're exploring the lavish interiors of the Belvedere Palace, home to Klimt's masterpieces, or enjoying a serene afternoon at the picturesque Hermesvilla nestled in the Vienna Woods, there's something for everyone. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the enchanting castles that define this beautiful city, each offering a glimpse into the grandeur of Austria's history.

data.title: The 36 best beaches in and around Vienna

placeMetadata.name: Alte Donau

sources.snippet: The Alte Donau (“Old Danube”) is a natural remnant of what the Danube used to be before humans have rectified the river into it’s current shape. Today it’s Vienna’s first address for water sports of all kinds: You can surf, sail, row a boat, swim and at some winters – when it gets cold enough – even go ice skating. Surrounded by lawns and trees, this is a giant natural playground and probably the city’s most popular spot on a hot summer day.
sources.shortName: The best places to swim in Vienna in summer
A Local’s Guide to “Beaches” in Vienna, Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: The former branch of the danube river is a beloved bathing spot for viennese people as it's technically not a river anymore. The Alte Donau which translates to Old Danube resembles a lake-like bathing spot with a beautiful view on our city's skyscrapers. Electric boats, stand-up paddle boards as well as little floating islands can be rented.
sources.shortName: Where to go swimming

sources.snippet: Another popular bathing spot is the waters of the Alte Donau, offering 1.6 kilometres of beaches. The artificially built canal is home to rich fresh-water flora, the so-called macrophytes. The area offers 11 larger jetties, equipped with loungers and chairs, as well as a pebble beach, sunbathing areas, green spaces and trees.
sources.shortName: Vienna - great beaches, 500 km away from the sea

sources.snippet: For those seeking a more tranquil beach experience, Alte Donau is the perfect destination. This hidden gem offers calm waters and beautiful scenery, making it a favorite among locals looking for a relaxing day by the water.
sources.shortName: Discover The Best Vienna Beaches: A Comprehensive Guide

sources.snippet: Alte Donau (Old Danube): This former arm of the Danube River is now a popular recreational area with several lidos and beaches along its shores, offering opportunities for swimming, boating, and sunbathing.
sources.shortName: 5 Best Beaches Near Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Waterfront city park overlooked by bars & restaurants with lidos & jetties for swimmers & boat hire.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Alte Donau, also known as Old Danube, is a picturesque waterfront city park in Vienna. It offers a variety of water sports and recreational activities such as swimming, boating, stand-up paddleboarding, and even ice skating during winter. The area is surrounded by lush lawns and trees, making it a popular spot for locals seeking relief from the summer heat. With its tranquil waters and beautiful scenery, Alte Donau provides the perfect setting for a relaxing day by the water.

reviews.reviewText: What a wonder this Alte Donau. Timeless beauty in all seasons, soothing my soul. A picturesque haven where tranquility embraces every ripple, echoing the heart of Vienna. Whether to stroll on its banks or swim (when the temperature permits) it is always a fabulous experience !

5 stars, superb quality. So much fun. I saw a fish that was bordering on 70cm long so we might need to work on that in future x
James

It’s quiet big lake with clear water perfect for swimming (I would suggest only in summer). They have plenty of wooden platforms where you can have take rest or get tanned. Public toilets are also available free of charge in every few meters. So, be sure to check it out if you are Vienna for Summer:)
Really quiet and naturall place in vienna. It is a wonderful place to take a sun both and relax in sun, taking a walk or just relax on a green place near the water.
Alte Donau is the best place to live in Vienna. neighbouring river,a very big and beautiful park with multiple sports facilities, boating, swimming and last but not least donautrum.
Most beautiful part of Vienna for me. You really feel like you're out of the city even it's in reality right there.
In my opinion, it is a very beautiful and clean place, you can easily relax and enjoy nature…
Amazing place to relax and chill out but I didn't see any public beach and place where I can swim.

placeMetadata.name: Donauinsel

sources.snippet: When summer swings into action, locals head for the Donauinsel (Danube Island). Extending more than 21km (13 miles), the artificial island created as part of the city's flood protection system forms a separate arm of the river, the Neue Donau (New Danube). Swimming areas with fine-gravel beaches, a climbing park, skate park and the world's biggest floating trampoline center are among its energetic pursuits.
sources.shortName: Best parks in Vienna

sources.snippet: This island in the New Danube has plenty of swimming spots and is particularly beloved by nudists. There are a few clearly marked ‘FKK’ (clothing-free) zones on Donauinsel (or 'Danube Island'), meaning that free spirits can strip off for a line-free tan – in fact, it's actually home to one of the largest nudist beaches in Austria. Look out for signs that say 'FKK' or 'freikörperkultur' to make sure you're shedding your kit in the right area.
sources.shortName: 5 outdoor spots for a dip in Vienna | EasyJet

sources.snippet: The artificial Neue Donau (“New Danube”) runs parallel to the mighty river and serves as a protection for floods. Most of the time the water is clean and calm – and due to its depth – usually stays a little cooler than the Alte Donau. Especially later in summer, when the water warms up and the mowing boats can’t catch up with the growth of algae and water plants, the Neue Donau is a refreshing alternative!
sources.shortName: The best places to swim in Vienna in summer

sources.snippet: One of the most famous but also controversial swimming spots is the FKK area on the Donauinsel. Located here this part of the island is fully dedicated to being naked - yes, that's a real and legal thing in Austria. FKK is standing for "Freikörperkultur" which refers to the lifestyle of naturism (= practising non-sexual social nudity in private and in public).
sources.shortName: Where to go swimming

sources.snippet: Donauinsel (Danube Island): This long, narrow island in the middle of the Danube River has several swimming spots along its shores, as well as picnic areas, sports facilities, and restaurants.
sources.shortName: 5 Best Beaches Near Vienna
Discover The Best Vienna Beaches: A Comprehensive Guide

placeMetadata.description: Long, narrow island along the Danube featuring wooded recreation areas, restaurants & bars.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Donauinsel, also known as Danube Island, is a long and narrow island located along the Danube River. It offers wooded recreation areas, making it a perfect spot for picnics and outdoor relaxation. The island is a popular destination for couples seeking to escape the city's hustle and bustle. Visitors can enjoy beautiful parks, gardens, recreational areas, as well as various restaurants and cafes.

reviews.reviewText: Such a beautiful place! Perfect for relaxing and enjoying the nature

Beautiful and very peaceful bridge
You can walk across it on next to the train station or at the waterfront.
The views are stunning
A great place for festivals. Easily available by public transport - leave your car at your hotel/home

I was here with my friend on a walk. The island itself is cool but it’s quite crowded and I was quite surprised to see people swim in this river. Anyway I recommend to everyone who just want to go on a walk, chill or have fun with their friends
A long but narrow island in the middle of the Danube. It offers amazing views of the city as well as plenty of activities
Best view ever from U-Station
Love this place. So much to see and do, you can relax inmidst of nature
Beautiful place to swim

placeMetadata.name: Strandbad Gänsehäufel

sources.snippet: There’s a free shuttle service called ‘Bäderbus’ from the U-Bahn station U1 Kaisermühlen (the 1st bus leaves at 8:50am on weekdays and 7:50am on the weekend, while the last bus leaves Gänsehäufel at 8:15pm) – keep in mind: since Corona turned up, the Bäderbus is not running as reliably and regularly as it used to. We tried to research for concrete details on this, however, there’s only conflicting info to be found online and from those we spoke to at the city’s transport crowd. This is the only so-called Strandbad (beach swimming pool) requiring an entry fee that we’ve included in this list, and there’s a damn good reason for this – because this ol’ favourite is as much a Viennese experience as is waltzing while wearing a Mozart wig, eating a Manner schnitte, and drinking a Spritzer – at the same time.
sources.shortName: 5 of the best swimming spots you should dive into along the Danube river in Vienna

sources.snippet: Nestled upon a scenic little lake, the sandy shores and calm waters appeal to swimmers both youthful and seasoned, providing rejuvenating recreation. Expansive grassy banks invite relaxation upon comfortable beach chairs beneath warm sunbeams drifting lazily across rippled reflections. Additionally, a refreshing dip provides the perfect preamble to indulging in neighboring ice cream parlors before leisurely lounging commences.
sources.shortName: Explore 6 of the Best Beaches near Vienna 2024 With

sources.snippet: One of the famous beaches near Vienna that accounts for being a typical Austrian bathing beach created by water from the Donau. This is a little lake in the middle of the city which offers serene beaches, wave pools, tennis courts, and projected nude sunbathing zones for people seeking beach vacations in Vienna. This destination manages space for every adventurous traveler to enjoy good weather in the city.

sources.snippet: Escape the city's hustle and bustle at Strandbad Gänsehäufel, an idyllic and expansive beach set on an island in the Old Danube. This beach offers a unique wilderness experience within the Vienna city limits, surrounded by lush greenery and tranquil waters. It’s the ideal spot for nature enthusiasts and those looking to unwind in a peaceful environment.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best Beaches in Vienna, Austria – A Unique Urban Oasis

sources.snippet: A typical Austrian bathing beach created by water from the Donau, and formed a little lake in the middle of the city. There are Vaste Beaches, wave pools, tennis courts and projected nude sunbathings in case someone wants to tan their whole body. There is enough space for everyone to enjoy good weather

placeMetadata.description: Public swimming complex open May to September with lap, kids' & wave pools, a beach, slides & sauna.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Strandbad Gänsehäufel is a popular public swimming complex that welcomes visitors from May to September. It features a variety of pools including lap, kids', and wave pools, as well as a beach area, water slides, and even a sauna for those seeking relaxation. While the Baderbus shuttle service from U-Bahn station U1 Kaisermuhlen provides convenient access, it's important to note that its schedule may be affected by current circumstances.

reviews.reviewText: Even though I don't come often, I really like this Gänsehäufel. It is big, there is plenty of space, lots of trees for giving a nice shadow. Inside, you can find bakeries, fresh fruits, ice cream, and more. There are swimming pools, beach volleyball spots, stand-up paddling, and more. The only thing I don't like is that you can not leave and return, even though you have paid for a day ticket.

An iconic institution in Vienna, this incredibly well kept territory is an absolute must on a hot day.

We had a wonderful relaxed fun day at the beach. It was a Friday and a day off, but even so, it did not feel crowded or packed. Beautiful area and great swimming spot.

Highly recommended

Nice, lot of space under natural shadow to put your blanket or sweater. However on weekends or public holidays it's too crowded. Not enough pool space. So all around the pools is ok, but there's lack of pool space on non-working days.
Great atmosphere and staff. The sauna was extra 4,7€ but it was totally worth it.
Nice place and clean. It is hard to find a parking.

This place is amazing overall. It gives a lot of space for many people and offers a swimming pool and the old Danube to swim. You find calming chilling places and also lively places.
Food and beverage offers a good variety with homemade lemonade and nicely cooked meals. Walks through the entire grounds are great with green nature.

Enough space even on sundays, friendly lady at the ticket desk, everything very tidy and clean, not a single cigarette on the ground/grass), good maintained. Beaches clean and well equiped with showers and changing rooms. Parking available too.

Best experience! Great to spend time with family especially with kids coz they'll surely enjoy! Big pool with slide and kids pool area. Wave pool is super fun as well. Snack bar available. Possibilty to swim in danube as too!

sources.snippet: The trendiest spot on the Danube is by far Copa Beach – a strip of green banks, sandy beaches, tropical plants and hip restaurants. The Copa Beach has the added benefit of being super close to the city centre, with just a 15-minute U-Bahn ride.
sources.shortName: Vienna - great beaches, 500 km away from the sea

placeMetadata.description: Riverside recreation area with a sandy beach, bars & restaurants, a skate park & summer swimming.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The CopaBeach swimming pool in Vienna is a great place to relax and enjoy the sun during summer. The pool occupies an entire beachfront, and there are plenty of places to buy food and drinks. The atmosphere is very relaxed, making it the perfect spot to spend some time after work or on a weekend break.

reviews.reviewText:
Amazing place in the peak of summer. Way more life than I thought, without it being crowded.

Clean swimming water, great food, decent toilets, awesome atmosphere!
Great place to relax, chill out with friends, or take a walk.

Didn't actually visit the bar or use their facilities, but the riverside area just the other side of the bridge from CopaBeach was lovely. Small decked area for sunbathing, ladders/steps for easily getting in and out of the river, and also a nice seating/lounging area with little tables overlooking it a tiny bit higher up the bank. Beautiful, gently-bustling location on a warm summer evening for families, youths, couples, locals, tourists and friendly swans alike.

Don't understand why this place is advertised as an amusement park and so many good reviews. There's literally nothing here, only construction site with offices and office workers. Some abandoned restaurants and that's all. The sand they show in reviews is a half a metre fake sand on the small bar they are trying to reopen. Another over hyped place for no reason just Instagram seekers here.

Lovely embankment, with breathtaking sunset views. Would definitely recommend a nice stroll along the Danube embankment at sunset time especially! And if you're there during the daytime there's plenty of water based activities you could do. Or simply enjoy a drink or ice-cream at one of the nice cafes/bars around

Nice atmosphere to have some drinks and watch the sun go down. There are some beach chairs, some places selling food and drinks, but you can also bring your own. Very relaxed and vacation-like feeling right in the city.
Ok place but NOT a beach. it's a tiny square of shallow sand. It's nice to swim, but it's just a concrete promenade with a couple of very expensive food and drink stalls.
A beautiful beach to chill, I loved the video in early evenings and with fewer people.

placeMetadata.name: Prater

sources.snippet: Beloved by generations of Viennese, the woodlands and meadows of the Prater sprawl between the Donaukanal (Danube Canal) and the Donau (Danube). This former river basin was once Habsburg monarchy hunting grounds, and it's now central Vienna's most popular park for walking, cycling and summertime picnicking. Stately chestnut trees stand sentinel along the Hauptallee avenue, which leads to the Lusthaus, a 16th century hunting lodge that was transformed for imperial festivities in the late 18th century and these days contains a cafe and restaurant serving Austrian classics in chandelier-lit splendour.
sources.shortName: Best parks in Vienna

sources.snippet: Vienna’s Prater Park is particularly delightful in autumn when the trees lining its vast green spaces are ablaze with colour. This large public park is best known for its iconic Ferris wheel, which offers panoramic views of the city. A ride on the Ferris wheel is especially recommended at sunset when the autumn skies add a dramatic backdrop.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Beaches to Visit in Mallorca This Summer
Travel Vienna (and 4,000+ other cities) like a local

placeMetadata.description: Large park with old-time amusements, including a landmark giant wheel dating from 1897.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Prater is a historic public park in Vienna that has been open to the public since 1766. It features a long promenade, traditional amusement park rides, a planetarium, and a museum showcasing its rich history. The park also houses children's rides from the '20s and '30s that survived a fire in 1945. One of its most iconic attractions is the Prater Ferris Wheel, offering an unforgettable view of Vienna from above.

reviews.reviewText:
A Perfect Blend of Nature and Fun – A Park for Everyone!
This park truly offers the best of both worlds. On one side, you’ll find a peaceful and charming green area with a pond full of ducks, perfect for a relaxing walk, biking, or even a picnic under the trees. It's an ideal spot to unwind, enjoy nature, or just let the kids run free while you sit back and take in the serene atmosphere.

On the other side of the park is a huge amusement area that’s packed with games and attractions for all ages. From thrilling rides to fun games for kids, there's something here for everyone. We tried the giant Ferris wheel, which gave us amazing views — definitely a highlight! The ride cost €6 per person, and it was well worth it. Keep in mind that while entry to the general park is free, each amusement game or ride has its own separate fee.

There’s also a fantastic section within the park filled with restaurants! you can visit day or night. It’s a great area to relax after a walk or a fun ride, and it's equally enjoyable for both adults and kids.

All in all, this park is a must-visit. Whether you're looking for a calm afternoon in nature or an exciting day of fun, it has it all in one place!

Prater at night is a whole vibe—the lights are dazzling, the energy is high, and the place is filled with young people enjoying themselves. The atmosphere alone makes it worth a visit. There are tons of rides and amusement games, from family-friendly options to seriously thrilling ones.

I only managed to try the Ferris wheel. The ride goes for three rounds, and the view at the top is beautiful, but honestly, I’d recommend going for the newer Ferris wheel instead—it feels like the better option. I didn’t get to play the games, but walking around, you can tell it’d be a really fun spot if you had the time.

One thing to note: most rides and games are individually priced. This works if you know exactly what you want to try, but if you’re hoping to experience everything, it might add up quickly. I didn’t come across a proper “all-access” pass, though maybe one exists. Still, it’s an exciting place to wander, soak in the vibes, and jump on a few rides that catch your eyes.

I went there with my friends during our trip in Vienna and frankly there are a lot pf options of rides you can take. If you are adventurous and you like different types of rides this is the place. They even had go kart and pony rides for children and restaurants with food.
Heaps of rides and attractions! We easily spent over 5 hours here and had a great time. There's roller-coasters, the sling shot, dodgem cars, ghost trains, fun house labyrinth and loads more to do.

Prater is one of the must-visit spots in Vienna. It’s a huge park with both green spaces and an amusement park area, so you can enjoy nature and fun rides at the same time. The highlight is definitely the Giant Ferris Wheel, which gives you a beautiful view over the city.

It’s a great place for a walk, cycling, or just relaxing on the grass. Families, couples, and solo travelers will all find something to enjoy here. There are also plenty of food stalls and restaurants around, so you can easily spend a whole afternoon or evening.

A perfect mix of relaxation and entertainment in the heart of Vienna!

Spectacular!!! Nothing else like it in the world (that I have ever seen). Absolutely fun. Gives a feeling of going back to an era of amusement parks and fairs - with all the thrills of modern rides. Lots of games and delicious food too.
A must see attraction in Vienna, an amusement park with all sorts of attractions, rollercoaster, there are also children friendly ones as well. Recommend it for families and all ages.
This park is absolutely wonderful! My daughter and I thoroughly enjoy our time here, and the best part is that it's budget-friendly. There are plenty of fun activities to indulge in.

placeMetadata.name: Vienna State Opera

sources.snippet: One of the world's largest and most splendid theaters, the Vienna State Opera House (Wiener Staatsoper) has hosted many of the world's most prominent composers, conductors, soloists, and dancers. Operatic and ballet performances are staged at least 300 times a year, fuelled by an obsession with music that goes as far back as 1625 when the first Viennese Court Opera was performed. The current massive Opera House was built in 1869 and is notable for its French Early Renaissance style, while interior highlights include a grand staircase leading to the first floor, the Schwind Foyer (named after its paintings of famous opera scenes), and the exquisite Tea Room with its valuable tapestries.
sources.shortName: 27 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Vienna

sources.snippet: Autumn is the start of the opera season in Vienna, and the Vienna State Opera is the place to experience world-class performances. From classical operas to modern productions, there’s something for every taste. The building itself is a masterpiece of architecture and offers guided tours during the day for those who want to learn more about its history.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Beaches to Visit in Mallorca This Summer
Travel Vienna (and 4,000+ other cities) like a local

placeMetadata.description: World-famous opera house offering major productions, original decor & multilingual guided tours.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Vienna State Opera House, also known as Wiener Staatsoper, is a world-renowned opera house that has been hosting major productions and guided tours. It is one of the largest and most magnificent theaters globally, with a rich history dating back to 1625. The current grand Opera House was constructed in 1869 and features a French Early Renaissance style.

reviews.reviewText:
if you're a fan of music, or even just beautiful buildings, the tour of the vienna state opera is a must-do. i wasn't sure what to expect, but it was really fascinating.
​it's a guided tour, so you go with a group and a guide tells you all the stories. they take you through the grand staircases and these incredibly ornate rooms like the tea salon and the marble hall. everything is so elegant and detailed, and it's wild to think that parts of the building had to be rebuilt after being bombed in world war ii. you see the original parts and the restored parts side by side, and it's a cool mix of history.
​the highlight for me was seeing the auditorium and the stage from different angles. you get to stand in the royal box and look out, and it makes you feel like you're royalty for a second.
​the tour is about 40 minutes long, and you get so many interesting facts and stories. they tell you about the famous composers and conductors who worked there. it's a really great way to appreciate the opera house even if you don't have time to see a full performance. it's a good idea to check the schedule online and book your tour in advance because they're really popular

The building is super impressive. I cannot say anything about opera itself unfortunately, as I was there for the first time and I'm surely not an opera fan. I cannot compare to another performance,  I have no knowledge about opera singers etc. However, even taking all above into account all listed above, the experience was very cool and recommended even for people who knows nothing about the opera, like me :D live orchestra was amazing though.

If you’re in Vienna, you definitely have to visit the  State Opera House! I’ve been to opera houses in the U.S., but most of them are relatively new compared to this one. The level of detail here is incredible – every corner feels like a work of art, from the ornate ceilings to the grand staircases.

The performance was equally stunning. The orchestra and opera singers were on another level – so powerful and moving that even though I’m not usually into classical music, I loved every minute of it. This was truly an unforgettable experience and one of those bucket-list items you absolutely have to check off when visiting Vienna.

Phenomenal. Did I say that yet? Did I say phenomenal? I sat in the balcony and I could see everything. I recommend if you can to get front row seats spend the extra €50 it was just phenomenal. The music was excellent and they did some fun things at the end. Did I say phenomenal?

The English Guided Tour of Vienna was well organized, with many other language tours choreographed outside of the stage.

However, I felt they (Crowd control) became too rigid and lost their purpose when dealing with tourists. They separated families, unlike in the USA, Canada and almost anywhere, where people will switch out individuals if they have fixed people to tour, here, they don't understand and sounded rude.

The Opera is a historical early modern place of networking and pompous and continues today, and also, it is maybe the most inefficient way of doing stages and keep the jobs.

That said, enjoyed the seeing The Opera, our tour guide was excellent,most importantly 30 second seating at the biggest and the best, king's box.

Beautiful building and an amazing experience. The atmosphere is elegant and the staff is very professional. Even if you’re not into opera, it’s worth visiting for the history and stunning interior. A highlight of Vienna!

The Opera house is magnificent. Just be prepared that everybody is taking pictures everywhere.
I was pleasantly surprised about the acting skills singers had. We listened to the comedy, so that aspect was crucial. Im general I enjoyed that experience a lot. Still opera in Riga I love more. 😁

Beautiful beyond words..pl book ticket for guided tours online, they fill up fast.. though they sell offline tickets 30 mins before the tour from the opera house( but these are unsold tickets so not sure if you would one, but you may try your luck). Arrive at the venue 15 mins before the time..it is a must visit place in Vienna.. highly recommend this one

placeMetadata.name: Strandbad Alte Donau

sources.snippet: If you consider Vienna might provide artificial pools instead of beaches then you must visit this oldest outdoor bathing beach in Vienna which celebrates wide expanses of manicured lawns along the shore of a side channel of the Danube lake in the city. Under luscious shaded trees, stretched lawns of fresh green grass, and wading sand regions, you can enjoy the sun and the clean, fresh water of the river to gain a rejuvenating beach vacation in the city. So don’t miss out on a refreshing beach ride in Vienna.
sources.siteName: Explore the World with Adequate Travel - Your One-Stop Destination for Travel Planning-adequatetravel.com
sources.shortName: Top 10 Beaches in Vienna

sources.snippet: Woven seamlessly amid nature’s harmony, such oases reflect the season’s balance of bustling sport and seclusion. Beyond the sandy shoreline and refreshing artificial pools, inviting swimming awaits additional provisions carefully integrated into the landscape. Tennis courts invite active diversions while manicured lawns provide sprawling spaces to relax and enjoy the natural surroundings.
sources.shortName: Explore 6 of the Best Beaches near Vienna 2024 With

sources.snippet: These are not an artificial pools but wide expanses of manicured lawns along the shore of a side channel of the Danube, left by the dredging and strainghtening of the river a century ago. Under massive shade trees, stretched out on the grass and wading on the sand, you can enjoy the sun and the clean,fresh water of the river. 22nd District, Arbeiterstrandbadstr.
sources.shortName: Vienna's Baths & Beaches

placeMetadata.description: Vibrant park featuring a beach & lake for swimming & other recreation, plus a pier & green space.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Strandbad Alte Donau is a vibrant park in Vienna, offering a beach and lake for swimming and recreation. It is the oldest outdoor bathing beach in the city, featuring manicured lawns along the shore of a side channel of the Danube. Visitors can relax under shaded trees, on green grass lawns, and wading sand regions while enjoying the clean water. The park also includes tennis courts for active diversions and sprawling spaces to relax amid natural surroundings.

reviews.reviewText:
The best place to spend a summer day, the tickets were 7,60 with all included, we really thought it was nothing like described but it's even better, u have 3 pools, each one of different sizes. 2 volleyball camps, 2 football camps, a playground for the kids, tables for tennis, all in 1 side. The other side is the river, where u can also stay and have a swim, all of the places are watched by lifeguards. There's a shop where u can buy all the swimming things and rent some rackets to play tennis (3€ for 1h). The sun loungers are free and u can put them wherever you need, something AMAZING.
The restaurant/bar it's really comfortable and the prices are not that high, the food is good and the vibe is amazing, all the waiters were really nice.
Everything was really perfect, the only thing I would say that wasn't nice was the lifeguard of the pool in the morning, he's rude, no patience for the kids, and speaks (jokes even) with people in the worst way possible,I guess if he's tired he should just quit, it's a kids place.

Fab. After a hot day at Prater Park on the amusements, this is a brilliant way to cool off. Two pools, the Danube, and a nice restaurant/cafe, and just a really relaxed atmosphere (just don't jump or dive in the pool!). Cost about €28 for four of us - bargain.
Lovely place for a swim, especially in the warm weather! The river is beautiful with views all around and the pools are a good temperature.

Overall, I had a pleasant experience. The river is kept clean, and is not that deep, highly recommended for families with toddlers. There’s a lifeguard on duty always.

There’s a wide variety of things to do, if swimming is not on the agenda. The location is very big, it has a football field, volleyball and a restaurant/ cafe.
I recommend packing your own food, as it’s quite expensive inside. If you forgot to bring a swimsuit or want an inflatable floatie, you can always buy one there.
The price of a day ticket is a bit steep, especially if you want to go daily during the summer. If that’s your plan, I recommend getting a month ticket.
A pleasant place to spend time by the water. The shower and cabin areas are clean and nice for children to enjoy. I recommend it for spending time with family and friends.
Amazing! Big spaces, swimming pool and kids pool, and clear water. There is also a very good restaurant inside.
A lovely place for swimming and relaxing.  Highly recommend.
A place to relax and enjoy. Over the years, there are plenty of people who come for bathing and enjoying nature. There are stands with food and drinks :)

placeMetadata.name: Schafbergbad

sources.snippet: This is one of the most popular beaches in Vienna that is well-known among the top bathing destinations of the city. Besides providing high-spirited entertainment for children, they offer nice pools and manage a lot of people at once in their region. Since there’s always enough space for strolling and enjoying the beach it accounts for the best family beach in Vienna.

sources.snippet: Besides providing entertainment for children, the pool is nice and big and although it holds a lot of people, there is always enough space. And in between, there are little stands selling beverages and shakes, and a restaurant where you can get a very presentable meal. 18th District, Josef-Redl-Gasse 3 Tel: 01-4791593 To get there: Tram 43 to Hernals, then Bus 42B
sources.shortName: Vienna's Baths & Beaches

sources.snippet: The Schafbergbad is an expansive emerald oasis featuring four pools with different depth. It caters to both thrill-seekers and those seeking more leisurely activities. Adrenaline enthusiasts, young and old, can delight in the towering 10-meter diving platform and exhilarating water slide.
sources.shortName: Where to go swimming

placeMetadata.description: Outdoor pools with a thrill slide, soccer field & volleyball courts, plus a snack bar & city views.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Schafbergbad is a popular outdoor pool located in a picturesque neighborhood on the Schafberg hill, offering stunning city views without being overcrowded. It attracts a younger crowd and families, providing an extensive range of sports activities such as aqua aerobics, beach volleyball, mini golf, and table tennis. The facility features four pools of varying depths to cater to both thrill-seekers and those seeking more relaxed experiences.

reviews.reviewText:
Amazing place. Very cheap, lots of parking room, and very high quality food and service.

The pool is very nice and cool, especially in the hot sun, there is a nice slide to go down, plenty of room to sunbathe and swim, and an option to go swim in the river and/or use a boat to go around in. The tickets are very cheap and there is bars and restaurants around the place.

Try to go early for parking spots and on working days so its not as busy.

Wheelchair accessible, easy to get around and great on a hot day.

I visited on a hot day so parking was limited and the pool was packed, but it was a good experience nonetheless. The ticket I got was a paid ticket, but an additional free ticket was given for a carer. It is inside a large property with lots of green space and lovely spots to sit for a picnic.

The pool was very busy, but the water temperature was nice and refreshing. Lifeguards are on duty and there is a large 3m diving board over a very deep section of the pool. I was able to transfer from my chair onto the raised section (the pool is higher than ground level) and then throw myself into the pool. Getting out I went up the stairs and then slowly made my way back to a spot with my chair. They might have proper equipment for wheelchair access, but I didn’t try to find it. I think the lifeguards would offer to help either way (not sure about any potential language barrier). I’m not sure why, but I didn’t seem to take any photos of the actual pool. ***insert Homer Simpson “Doh!” here***

Overall, it was a great way to spend a hot afternoon

I really enjoyed visiting this pool complex. It is very large and offers activities for all age groups. Everything was super clean and well-maintained. The place is very well organized, and there are pools and spaces for everyone to enjoy. A great place to relax and have fun with family or friends!

Here’s a Google review you could use:

---

**Rating: ★★★★☆**

it was quite busy, it turned out to be a great experience overall. The water temperature was just perfect – refreshing but not too cold, making it enjoyable for both kids and adults alike. Despite the crowd, the pool area was well-maintained, and there was plenty of space around for families to set up picnic spots. The grassy areas and shaded spots made it a lovely place to relax and spend the day. A bit more space in the pool would have been nice, but overall, a fantastic spot for a family day out!
My favourite outdoor pool in Vienna! Set in so much greenery it’s just bliss! Bring a picnic and your suntan cream and enjoy a relaxing day soaking in the rays

This year there is an awful approach at food kiosk.
They don't write it anywhere and don't warn you in advance, so after you queue up for 1 hour to one cashier (the left line), you order drinks and pay for the food you would like to have, and then you get informed, that you need to queue up for another hour to the next window to pick up the food you ordered.
It's nonsense and looks like they simply cannot organize the process properly.
Lost time.
Advice: if you are more than 1 person - you may queue up to two windows at the same time.
Went there for the first time and loved it! Amazing view, cool area, many different pools and a huge water slide 💦 Will definitely be back here next summer!
nice outdoor pool, affordable prices but no normal wardrobe or shower

placeMetadata.name: Gänsehäufel

sources.snippet: When searching for must-visit Vienna beaches, Gänsehäufel is a top contender. This popular beach and recreational area is located on an island in the Alte Donau, offering a wide range of activities and facilities for visitors of all ages.
sources.shortName: Discover The Best Vienna Beaches: A Comprehensive Guide

sources.snippet: Gänsehäufel: A popular summer destination located on an island in the Old Danube River. It offers sandy and grassy beaches, several pools, water slides, playgrounds, and sports facilities. There's a small entry fee to access the island.
sources.shortName: 5 Best Beaches Near Vienna

sources.snippet: If you prefer a more monitored and family-friendly environment with lockers, playgrounds and cafeterias – the public “beaches” Angelibad and Gansehaufel (day-ticket for about 6 EUR) are great choices.
sources.shortName: A Local’s Guide to “Beaches” in Vienna, Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Gansehaufel is a public bathing beach in Vienna that offers stunning views of the UN and skyline of Vienna. It is perfect for flower children seeking tranquility, or families with free-range kids. The island has been a swimming tradition in Vienna for over 100 years and it is still one of the most popular spots on the city's beaches.

reviews.reviewText: This place is magical. We had such a delightful time visiting here in late June with some friends and we can't wait to go back! Our son really enjoyed swimming in the Alte Donau, the little beach area facing the UN is absolutely fantastic!! We also went to the children's play area near the two pools, one with a water slide, and had a picnic. It was a beautiful, hot day, perfect for swimming! Highly recommend this place!

Nice experience with great access to the Danube. You can have a nice swim there and even jump from a deck. The pools there also provide you with artificial waves. There is even a water-slide for the kids! A lot of green space where you can lay down to relax. About 5$ entry for one person.

Where else can you swim with a view to the UN and the Viennese skyline? The Gänsehäufel is a beautiful, clean bath and there is always plenty of space, even on the hottest days. It's actually more like a lake, really. Highly recommended!

I have found this place designed for different leisure activities, but not suitable for swimming and not a cheap place. You can not use your mobile pass to enter there! You have to pay 10 € to rent a (PRIVATE) deck chair!! There is a spacious space with the lower functions and any limitation about the number of guests, especially with regard to swimming!!!
Lots of space...  Well kept lawns...  Great FKK area...  Pleasant swim in the Danube!
Small island in the city with many public space for family.Love a good quality of life in Vienna!

Great place to come and swim, but half of Vienna comes here on a sunny day
Easy to get to via underground and bus.
Nice! Although we preferred old Donau a bit  further away: calmer, more space, better restaurant.

placeMetadata.name: Schönbrunn Palace

sources.snippet: The spectacular 18th-century Schönbrunn Palace (Schloss Schönbrunn) is worth visiting not only for its magnificent architecture, but also for its beautiful park-like setting. One of Vienna's top tourist attractions, this beautiful Baroque palace contains more than 1,441 rooms and apartments, including those once used by Empress Maria Theresa. Tour highlights include a chance to see the Imperial Apartments, including Emperor Franz Joseph's Walnut Room and his Bedroom, which still has the small soldier's bed in which he died.
sources.shortName: 27 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Vienna

sources.snippet: Schönbrunn Palace, one of Vienna’s most iconic sites, becomes even more enchanting during the autumn months. The sprawling gardens, which are free to enter, are adorned with vibrant autumn colours, providing the perfect setting for a leisurely stroll. You can also visit the palace’s opulent interiors to get a glimpse of life during the Habsburg dynasty.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Beaches to Visit in Mallorca This Summer

placeMetadata.description: 18th-century summer palace with tours of lavish rococo ceremonial rooms, plus gardens with a maze.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Schönbrunn Palace is an 18th-century summer residence that offers tours of its opulent rococo ceremonial rooms and lavish gardens with a maze. The palace boasts beautiful Baroque and Neo-Classical architecture, reflecting Vienna's rich history as the town of Habsburgs and Maria Theresa. It is Vienna's most visited attraction, featuring 45 luxurious state rooms, ceremonial halls, and private apartments once inhabited by Empress Elisabeth and Emperor Franz Joseph.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing palace, we took the full access. The garden was breathtaking, and the palace was pretty.  The art collection in the palace was stunning. Definitely enjoyed it. I would recommend buying tickets online, as they are strict in entrance timing .

The palace is really gorgeous. The museums inside palace and certain portion of the garden can be visited only with tickets. But we did not buy any ticket and directly visited the garden behind the palace. The garden is really humongous and beautiful.  The center has beautiful flowers followed by fountain. Also beautiful place to click a photo or two.

As the garden is so huge I saw some people there for their morning stroll. Hey Perplexity, rewrite it and adjust the tone and grammatical errors.

The palace is truly stunning. Access to the museums inside and certain sections of the garden requires a ticket, but without purchasing one, it’s still possible to visit the garden area behind the palace. The gardens are vast and beautifully maintained, with vibrant flowers at the center leading toward a lovely fountain. The scenery makes it an excellent spot for photos. Given the sheer size of the gardens, it’s common to see people enjoying a morning stroll there.

Wow.

Hard to believe this was a residence a few hundred years back.

Stunning Architecture and Grounds.

Breathtaking Hilly Scenery.

We didn’t go in because of the Price and the Wait!

Packed on a Wednesday morning. Lots of Tour Bus Groups here.

A must see and bring your walking shoes because this place is massive.

You could walk the Grounds for hours it’s so expansive.

This should be a must see in Vienna!

Very nice experience visiting this Palace. It was educational, although we did the audio tour and there were many basic facts which seemed to be missing and I might therefore recommend a guided tour. Plan on spending at least an hour on the grounds, as they are beautiful and enormous.

Wow! What a beautiful place! I would say this is a must see for any tourists. The grounds are so incredible and have so much to do. If you have several days in Vienna I recommend at least half a day to see everything here including the gardens, zoo, labyrinth, Gloriette, and palace interior. The gardens and land alone are worth devoting at least an hour or two of your time to. As for the inside I would say get the palace pass unless you are wanting to see more of the palace. The palace pass gets you access to many rooms and a gift shop at the end and there is an audio tour available in several languages. The palace is decorated with authentic furniture to replicate what it would have been like at its prime. The palace was moderately busy but manageable and in the gardens you hardly notice most of the crowds. on the inside it can be hard to squeeze past people or move along when there’s a crowd, so I would recommend trying to go in the earlier morning when it opens. Buy tickets in advance if you want a planned time slot, but if you’re fine waiting for about an hour and a half, or more, buying tickets there is perfectly fine. Also… don’t stand on the grass or places that you’re not supposed to!

We didn’t go inside the Schönbrunn Palace, but just strolling around the beautiful grounds was more than enough. My boyfriend and I enjoyed walking through the gardens, hiking up to the Gloriette for amazing views, and even wandering into the nearby forest trails. Peaceful, scenic, and a lovely way to spend time together — we loved every moment!

A very interesting site to explore. What I really liked is that the audio guide provided by the museum focuses on the most important information and is very easy to follow. The gardens are also beautiful.

If you want to get a glimpse of how royalty lived, Schönbrunn Palace and its gardens are a must-see! This is one of favorite visits in Vienna. The Baroque architecture is absolutely magnificent, and the grounds are just as impressive. The massive garden stretches behind the palace with the Gloriette perched on the hill, offering one of the best views in Vienna. My tip – start your visit at the Gloriette first and snap some photos of the entire palace and gardens from the balcony. Then, take a leisurely stroll down the hill, through the fountains and perfectly manicured paths, and make your way to the palace entrance.

The inside tour requires a ticket, but it’s worth every euro. The lavish interiors and rich history give you a true appreciation of the opulent lifestyle of the royal family. We were in awe of the intricate details and grandeur of each room – it really transports you back in time. For even more context, check out the Netflix series The Empress before or after your visit – it adds another layer of appreciation. A must-do when in Vienna!

placeMetadata.name: Stadtpark

sources.snippet: On sunny days, city workers make a beeline for the peaceful Stadtpark (City Park). Straddling the Wien River, its paths wind past duck ponds shaded by willow trees. Statues stud the park, including a shimmering gold monument of Johann Strauss the Younger (composer of the waltzes The Blue Danube and Tales from the Vienna Woods, among others) playing the violin.
sources.shortName: Best parks in Vienna

sources.snippet: Autumn brings a unique atmosphere to Stadtpark, one of Vienna’s most beloved parks. Located in the heart of the city, this park is home to the famous statue of Johann Strauss, making it a popular spot for both locals and tourists. The golden autumn leaves create a picturesque setting for a leisurely walk or a quiet afternoon by the park’s pond.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Beaches to Visit in Mallorca This Summer

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Stadtpark in Vienna is a picturesque spot, featuring the iconic golden Johann Strauss memorial and several other monuments and sculptures. It's known for being the richest park in Vienna for its collection of statues, including those of Franz Schubert, Franz Lehar, Robert Stolz, Hans Makart, Anton Bruckner, and Andreas Zelinka. Visitors can spend a leisurely day here feeding ducks by the pond or enjoying coffee from Espresso Mobil.

reviews.reviewText:
I really love this station, it's location is not the most useful, being relatively close to other better connected u-bahn stations. But it's setting is perfect, sitting just inside Stadtpark it feels urban and clean and open.

Otto Wagner's pavilion as an entry gate works perfectly in the setting.
Stumbled upon this park on my way to the theatre, it is beautiful, so calm yet lots of people just vibing

A beautiful park in Vienna, among many others!
Don't miss the golden statue of Johan Strauss, especially at sunset.

Cozy park for a nice stroll on a beautiful day. In summer the park comes to life with special events . Nice little ponds and beer gartens. Don't skip the opportunity for an apfelstrudel with icecream or a slice of sacher torte.
The only U-Bahn station that retains its original appearance.
Nice old school metro stop, and city park

While driving through in the subway - if you have the time - get out here and walk around the station. The combination of Wienfluss, Stadtpark and the stations historic architecture make for a great photo scenery ;)
Its a great experience to ride the metro here. It was in front of Inter Continental Wien.

placeMetadata.name: Kahlenberg

sources.snippet: For those who love hiking and panoramic views, Kahlenberg is the perfect autumn destination. Located in the Vienna Woods, this hill offers breathtaking views of the city, especially when the autumn colours are at their peak. The area is famous for its vineyards, and you can often find wine taverns offering local wines for tasting.
sources.shortName: 12 Best Beaches to Visit in Mallorca This Summer

sources.snippet: Whether you are looking for a hike that gives you a workout or an easy trek that's short and sweet, this list has it.
sources.shortName: Travel Vienna (and 4,000+ other cities) like a local

placeMetadata.description: A popular escape from the city, this 1588 ft. hill offers a variety of walking trails & city views.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Kahlenberg, a 1588 ft. hill located just outside Vienna in the Vienna Woods, offers stunning city views and a peaceful retreat into nature. Visitors can explore walking trails through the surrounding forests and enjoy panoramic vistas of the city skyline and the Danube River. The hill is home to cozy cafes, restaurants, and the historic Kahlenberg Church, adding cultural appeal to its natural beauty.

reviews.reviewText: I went here on my last day. I almost didn’t go as it was the last thing on my agenda but I’m so glad I did! You take the 38A bus up - best bus journey of my life. It is the last stop and you are very much there. Great views from the top overlooking Vienna. Definitely bring a jacket / wrap up. I ordered a coffee at the local shop there and stayed to watch the sunset.
Very nice view, however the peak itself hasn't got any - maybe through the tower, but it is closed during the week. For the view you  have to go to the Kahlenberg restaurant nearby - can't miss it.
Beautiful view points ,rest diff trails are all for hiking .Nothing special ,busses were full.

Pretty hill just 30min from the center of Vienna by streetcar or bus. Perfect for escaping the city and enjoying nature. So popular that it's unfortunately hard to find a quiet spot! Especially as large infrastructures have been installed at the top to bring as many people as possible by bus, which interferes with walkers who have climbed the hill on foot.
A must see in Vienna. Even though we had bad weather the view was very good. Lots of tourists. The history of Poland tells about this place. You have to be there!
All in all, nice place to enjoy city panorama & have a drink. A bit crowded on weekends though.

Amazing hike to the top with lots of vineyards around, the view is breathtaking and the wine is excellent! Def recommend to go there for the sunset but take a jacket because it gets quite cold during the night!

Great place to see all vienna from top of the mountain hill.  When we went, it was very hazy and dark, but we could still take some pictures from there. We could see the entire city and beyond.  Highly recommend.

placeMetadata.name: Donaustadt

sources.snippet: By far you might have understood how the Danube channels the best beaches in Vienna that can provide endless ways for travelers to embrace the top beachy fantasies here. Therefore, to spend time at the water’s edges or fulfilling your strolling wishes with your beloved partner along a queue or on a green hillside, this is the perfect beach to visit in Vienna. You can promenade along a sandy shoreline or dabble your toes in the water, and in most places dive right in for a swim and explore the underwater world at Donaustadt.
sources.siteName: Explore the World with Adequate Travel - Your One-Stop Destination for Travel Planning-adequatetravel.com
sources.shortName: Top 10 Beaches in Vienna

sources.snippet: All along the Danube you can find endless ways to spend time at the water’s edge – stroll along a quaie or sit on a green hillside, walk along a sandy shoreline or dabble your toes in the water, and in most places dive right in for a swim. There are long shaded walks, and boat yards where you can rent sail boats, motor boats or canoes, go water skiing or slide your own boat into the water. 22nd District, Portnergasse 38 Tel: 01-2034321 To get there: U1 to “Alte Donau” Or Strandbaeder, 2 min. walk
sources.shortName: Vienna's Baths & Beaches

placeMetadata.description: Donaustadt, the 22nd District, is a residential area and a popular hub for outdoor recreation. Picnicking families and cyclists converge on the long, narrow Danube Island, and the calm waters of the Old Danube draw swimmers and sailors. The Lobau, a wetland reserve, is laced with hiking trails. Two towers – the ultramodern DC Tower, near UN headquarters in Donau City, and the Danube Tower – offer panoramic views.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Donaustadt, also known as the 22nd District of Vienna, is a residential area that attracts outdoor enthusiasts and nature lovers. The district features the long Danube Island, a popular spot for picnics and cycling, while the serene waters of the Old Danube are perfect for swimming and sailing. Nature enthusiasts can explore the hiking trails in Lobau, a wetland reserve.

placeMetadata.name: Döblinger Bad

sources.snippet: In an analogy with Krapfenwaldbad, this place is a bit smaller but chilled out where you can spend a great time with your buddies. There is one pool and people lay on the grass to catch some sun rays and tan their speckless bodies in the shades of classic brown and beige. Döblingerbad is the perfect beach to visit in Vienna if you are looking for a chill-out spot for a bachelor’s trip.
sources.siteName: Explore the World with Adequate Travel - Your One-Stop Destination for Travel Planning-adequatetravel.com
sources.shortName: Top 10 Beaches in Vienna

sources.snippet: Similar to the Krapfenwaldbad, this is a place a bit smaller but chilled out. There is one pool and people lay on grass to catch some sun rays. 19th District, Geweygasse 6 Tel: 01-3180140 To get there: Tram 37 to Döblingerbad, 2 min walk
sources.shortName: Vienna's Baths & Beaches

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Döblinger Bad is a relaxed and slightly smaller alternative to Krapfenwaldbad, offering a great spot to hang out with friends. The facility features one pool and ample grassy areas for sunbathing. Located in the 19th district of Vienna, it's easily accessible by public transport.

reviews.reviewText:
When we went there its a cloudy and weekdat so not too much kids and people.
Theres a playground for kids. A volleyball to play.
You can bring your food and have also stires to buy.
Recommended for families. Friends also

This is one of the best family friendly pools I've been to. They have a toddler pool with a slide, a lap lane pool, a large, fun play pool with a slide and water features and lastly a heated pool with jets. They have a nice grassy area with plenty of shade that also has a small playground for kids which is perfect for families. The facility is very clean and they have lots of lockers to stash your stuff. There's also a cafe that sells an assortment of food. All the staff is friendly and helpful. Furthermore, they have an indoor pool with lap lanes and offer swim lessons.

A wonderful pool and aquatic complex in the 19th district of Vienna, 5 minute walk from the final stop on the Metro line 4. The complex has an outdoor fun area with aqua playgrounds, a small slide, and pool for kids in the summer. The rest of the year there is a small indoor complex with a 25 meter lap pool, childrens pool, jacuzzi and sauna. It is for swim instruction and coached workouts however there are certain days anyone can enter, right now Tuesday, Friday at certain times, and the weekends. Coached workout has an annual pass from Sept to June, 1st is full price, 2nd and 3rd are half price and 4th in the family is free. These include adults and children in the package.
The facilities are clean and well maintained. There is also a full cafe with good and drinks including beer and a view of the indoor pools so you can watch your kid while sipping a cold beer. The cafe is open until "about 8pm".

Getting old and looking for a quick renovation. Guards do not care and do their job slooowly. Otherwise - nice location in the center of Döbling - and extremely crowded during the hot June days. If you live in a walking distance, you should of course give it a try. After all, what can be better than a cooling swim after a heated summer day?

Very nice complex, with 4 pools, all are clean and look nice. There is also a bar where you can have snacks, drinks and ice cream. There are a lot of deck chairs. The ticket is very cheap, only 3 € per person. I recommend! 😊

Very reasonable price, they charge from the age of 3. There is one sport pool a teenager/older kids pool and a slide, a little kids pool, + slideand a larger jacuzzi.
This whole place looks like it's stuck in the 70s 80s and is in serious need of an update.
The little play park is nice but white a bit of a walk down hill.
The water in the pools is freezing btw, if it isn't a burning hot day, it isn't worth visiting.
Also, you are being charged for parking, first 30minutes are free and you have to add the hours on manually, which if you don't speak German is quite a difficult task, and they make sure you get a ticket of €40 even on a Sunday!
Clean, cheap, quiet and surrounded by nature. Multiple pools, friendly staff. One of the best pools I have visited.
Nice, not crowded, reasonable price

placeMetadata.name: Simmeringer Bad

sources.snippet: If you are really seeking the well-furnished top beaches in Vienna then this is the biggest beach complex in Vienna as it has surreal slopes and three little segregated zones for children which makes it a great destination for family vacations. In all of the five outdoor pools and magical waves provided by the complex the feeling of being at the ocean is exuberant and euphoric. Address: 11th District, Florian-Hedorfer Str.
sources.siteName: Explore the World with Adequate Travel - Your One-Stop Destination for Travel Planning-adequatetravel.com
sources.shortName: Top 10 Beaches in Vienna

sources.snippet: This is one of the biggest pool complexes in Vienna; it has two big ones with slopes and three little ones for children. In all of the five outdoor pools, magical waves give you the feeling of being at the ocean. 11th District , Florian-Hedorfer Str.
sources.shortName: Vienna's Baths & Beaches

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Simmeringer Bad is the largest beach complex in Vienna, featuring five outdoor pools with magical waves that create an ocean-like experience. The facility includes two large pools with slopes and three smaller ones for children, making it a perfect destination for family vacations. Visitors can also enjoy an Olympic-sized swimming pool as well as sauna and steam rooms with varying temperatures. The staff are known for their courteous service, and the overall atmosphere is relaxing.

reviews.reviewText: The best place to have a summer vacation feeling ☀️ Easy to reach by car or with the Straßenbahn 🚊 The trees and flowers are really nice🌳Try to go early for outside swimming in the summer as later it might be crowded. The water is clean 🌊

Great place actually, nice stuff, a little bit popular because of the district 11 and crowded sometimes, but the high wives are so nice 👍.
Usually a cabine cost 2 euros additional but because I came after 5 I asked for it and they were easy to include it in the ticket 🙃

We went for a swim competition. Organisation was great, but inside there is no Tribune for the public and only one emergency door in one angle to go out and breathe... basically a sauna inside during the whole day.
On one side, the pool is 1.30m deep and has no trampoline. Hence, the start is slower, and Rollwende is less smooth.
Wardrobes are clean.
I would say not ideal for competitions, but nice to go swimming there.
Great even if it is under renovation for improvement when we went there fee weeks ago.

Great pool that turns the waves off and on. There is a children's section  so the small kids can play without  the older ones. It also has a restaurant so you can buy food there. They also offer discounts after 1 p.m. and again another discount after 4 p.m. I went at about 5 p.m. and there were still several chairs available to layout on. They are also equipped with plenty of showers and bathrooms.

i been here twice in a month and i found it very relaxing. Though frequented by seniors, there where also a lot of young children having their swimming exercises. the staff were very courteous and been trying to accommodate me with a very limited understanding on German language. i will surely be back to this place again on my return to Vienna next week. Their Olympic size swimming pool is great, but their Sauna and Steam room is amazing choice of 80 to 90 degrees C and 90 to 110 degrees C.

Amazing for family outgoing you can take some snacks and enjoy
I recommend

The pool isn't deep and very orderly. The personnel is friendly and even borrows you swimming aids if you need them to work on your swimming techniques. (When asked nicely and if they have some left.)

placeMetadata.name: Ottakringer Bad

sources.snippet: For an isolating beach experience in the city in the midst of an industrial district with traffic streaming, Ottakringerbad is the best choice to follow upon. This basically an oasis of green, implicitly insulated from all the noise and bustle with the specific classic decor that makes the outside world seem far away and offers a relaxing vacation. With nice clean pools enabling all its visitors a refreshed and enthusiastic destination it becomes one of the must-visit beaches in Vienna to explore.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the heart of an industrial district with bustling traffic, Ottakringer Bad offers a serene and secluded beach experience. This urban oasis is adorned with classic decor that creates a tranquil atmosphere, allowing visitors to escape the outside world. The clean pools provide a refreshing retreat for guests, making it a popular destination in Vienna. Families can enjoy quality time together at this venue, which caters to people of all ages.

reviews.reviewText: Good indoor swimming here. No annoying criscross swimmers but organized lanes. Sauna very good.

A nice place to spend good quality time with family. You can find there people of any age from a few months old babies to veeeery old people.

There are two swimmingpools, a big one for adults and a small one with a small water tunnel included.

There is a special shadowed place for families with small children, you can sit near the pool or on the green grass in the big garden.

There are also a playground for children, beach volleyball filds, changing rooms and a bar.

The sauna is not available on summer.

The only thing that bothered us was the fact that smoking is allowed there as it is an open space. Having smokers around can ruin your wellbeing.

The swimming pool is rusty and old, the changing rooms are nice however you need 2 euro coins to use the locker, the staff speaks a little bit English and they look like they are ready to throw people out if they break any unknown rules (as mentioned by other comments), however it is a nice place to relax and it looks more suitable for families rather than individuals. There is a slide but it is more for little kids rather than adults as well. The water was mostly clean even though there were little natural waste coming from the wind. The pool is 10m deep and it's widths weren't clearly shown so I can't say. Overall nice relaxing experience. It could have been better but that's for other pools to decide.

This public swimming pool has an interior with one regular sports pool and one deep pool for diving, and an exterior area with a sports pool, a fun pool and a children's pool. There a huge outdoor grass area with quite a few trees and therefore shade. There is also a playground and even trampolines that one can use when paying a fee. One can buy food in the cafeteria or the kiosks. The downside: The water doesn't appear to be too clean and the place in general is a bit gunky. Additionally, on hot summer's days, the place is packed full with people. Concluding, I would say that Ottakringer Bad is fine, but there is certainly room for improvement.
It doesn't have a cabinet to change between swimming clothes and normal clothes and you get thrown out for being too loud, although, you still have your fun when going to swim there with friends
Very good, very quiet, and so much space for swimming
Staff is really unfriendly, the indoor pool is pretty small and the people visiting,... Well,... See for yourself. It's good for a 30 minute workout, but nothing more.

A public outdoor pool which is clean and reasonably priced.
There is a big outdoor area to sit and relax.  Gets busy,  but not too crowed.

You can enjoy the surreal feeling of summer and holiday pleasures at this famous destination without any interruption. Address: 12th District, Hufeland Gasse 3
