I had the great pleasure, along with my fiancee, of attending your performance on Easter night, Sunday the 20th, in Vienna's Karlskirche.

It impressed us so much that we can say that it was the best performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It was very moving and still reverberates in our hearts. It was very, very special.

Wonderful evening in Vienna. The venue is a beautiful church. The violinists are awesome and I enjoyed Vivaldi’s Four Seasons

Highly recommend spending your evening in this concert.

The acoustics is a very little disappointing.

We hoped for an amazing evening of Vivaldi at a stunning setting. The setting was indeed stunning. But the music was waaay to quite for the huge church :(
Maybe if you take the first few raws it will be better. But we were at the second half and the sound was messy and indistinctive.

If not for the venue, it would have been 2 stars.
One of the highlights of my trip! The Vivaldi concert in the church was absolutely amazing. I highly recommend it to any music lover 🎵🎼🎻🎺🎷🪉🪈🎹🎶

We prebooked tickets direct, so we got to choose our seat rather than just which area.  The booking system says 'benches' but it is actually church pews.  We had chairs, but the pews would offer slightly higher views.  Blankets were on each seat, and it did get colder towards the end of the performance.  We aren't great
connoisseurs of classical music, but thoroughly enjoyed this performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons in a beautiful environment.  Thoroughly recommend.

We attended Vivaldi's Four Seasons concert. It was a wonderful concert, held in the evocative location of the Church of San Carlo Borromeo.
We'd like to extend a special thanks to the staff, who allowed us to attend the show even though we'd booked the wrong day.
Everything was perfect, from the artists to the organizers.
Thank you so much!
We’ve had a fabulous evening at the Karlskirche Vienna! Great orchestra 1756. Very good performance of Vivaldi four seasons. Highly recommanded👍🏻

placeMetadata.name: Burggarten

sources.snippet: Burggarten is a sweeping formal garden that backs onto The Hofburg and you can choose to visit it in conjunction with the palace or as an individual entity. As you meander your way around the space, you’ll encounter statues of the likes of Mozart and Franz Josef and eventually reach the Art Nouveau conservatory, Schmetterlinghaus, which houses hundreds of butterflies and makes this one of the best Instagram spots in Vienna for fans of the colorful creatures!. There’s plenty of space to experiment with your captures in Burggarten.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: The Burggarten, located right in the heart of Vienna, is a serene haven that once served as the imperial court’s private garden. Today, it is a public park where locals and visitors alike can unwind and soak up the beauty of nature. Whether you’re a nature enthusiast, a history lover, or simply seeking a serene spot for relaxation, this park has something for everyone.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones

sources.snippet: Adding to the best locations near the Hofburg Palace, the building of the Weltmuseum has architecturally beautiful steps with old-fashioned street lamps that look amazing in the afternoon light. You can find this place on the side of Burggarten heading toward the Butterfly House. It’s definitely worth a stop and makes for a fantastic instagrammable spot in Vienna.
sources.shortName: The Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: Ultimate Photo Guide
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: The Burggarten is a park, famous for its Mozart statue, which borders the Hofburg and Albertina palaces. It was built after Napoleon’s army demolished the defensive structures which occupied the area. It used to be a private royal garden for the Habsburg family until the end of the empire in 1918.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Well, you’ve done a thorough tour of the Instagrammable spots in Vienna!. Let’s head back to a lovely, peaceful spot, put your feet up, and reflect on what an amazing city this is!. Remember that nice park, situated just outside the Palm House and the Schmetterlinghaus?
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

sources.snippet: The Burggarten is of course more suitable for summer weather, but it also thrilled us in winter. We had the entire space to ourselves and were able to marvel at the incredibly beautiful architecture. In the photo I’m sitting in front of the butterflyhouse.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: Burggarten is a sweeping formal garden that backs onto The Hofburg. As you wander around, you’ll find statues like the one of Mozart and Franz Josef and eventually reach the Art Nouveau conservatory, Schmetterlinghaus.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

placeMetadata.description: A striking art nouveau conservatory with butterfly house stands in this statue-filled palace garden.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Burggarten is a picturesque formal garden located near The Hofburg in Vienna. It features statues of prominent figures such as Mozart and Franz Josef, adding to its charm. The highlight of the garden is the stunning Art Nouveau conservatory, Schmetterlinghaus, which houses a variety of colorful butterflies and serves as a popular spot for photography enthusiasts. Additionally, visitors can enjoy the serene atmosphere and explore the park's impressive monuments and statues, including Vienna's oldest equestrian statue.

reviews.reviewText:
This place is amazing! We were just passing by when we saw many people just siting on the grass and hanging out. This gave us the good idea to come here the next morning to stay on a blanket and eat our breakfast. The park is very beautiful and perfect for picnics, dogs and board games.

I definitely recommend this wonderful green chill zone!

Visited Burggarten in the morning and it was a calm, peaceful place with fresh air and beautiful surroundings.
I was hoping to see the famous horses nearby but, unfortunately, didn’t spot any. Still, a lovely spot to relax and enjoy the quiet.

One of Vienna's many beautiful parks.
But this park is particularly special thanks to the presence of so many young people.
It was quite refreshing, and the atmosphere was positive, even fun, like being at a university during the holidays. The weather was superb, and the location even more so.

Just look at the photos :-)

Beautiful public park with lots of shade and even a pond in the middle for some cool breeze. In close proximity to supermarkets and some cafes and bars. Also very close to the Butterfly house, which is also beautiful. Very accessible with public transportation. Beautiful place to be on a hot summer day. Definitely safe to come here on your own as a woman and to just relax with a book or snacks for a few hours!
The garden is very comfortable and relaxing. There are benches, and you can also lie down on the grass, which makes it a great place to rest. The only downside is that the toilet is paid.

Spectacular gardens surrounded by walkways and criss crossed by paths befitting the Palace - plenty of trees and places to wander and sit. The Treble Clef flower bed was in need of replanting but to have this garden close to the centre of town is a bonus.
I wasn't expecting to see so many young people here! This place definitely has a vibe. You'd see plenty of groups just chilling in the grass, doing small parties, or just hanging out.

Butterfly garden is amazing! A piece of jungle with waterfalls and tons of butterflies right in the middle of the city.

And the cafe on the grounds though definitely pricey had amazing food and desserts (I took a bowl of beef soup, a latte and a carrot cake with lemon sorbet - every little part of everything was so well thought of and so tasty)

placeMetadata.name: Michaelerplatz

sources.snippet: This city centre square is home to many different historical buildings and archeological sites. Stood in this square you will be surrounded by gateways from the 1200’s through to the 1900’s, why not go on a horse drawn carriage to feel fully immersed in this setting?. On one side of the square you can find the entrance to the Hofburg palace complex, in the middle open Roman excavations and to the other sides the Michaelerkirche church, the Loos House and the Palais Herberstein.
sources.shortName: 17 Most Instagrammable spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: In keeping with European cities, Vienna is home to a range of beautiful public squares but Michaelerplatz is one of my recommendations for photographers. Centrally located within the Innere Stadt, Michaelerplatz forms the main entrance to The Hofburg, the former imperial palace of the Habsburgs. Within the square, you will also find the historic Michaelskirche which dates back to the 13th century as well as the excavated site of the Roman settlement, Vindobona.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Perhaps one of the most impressive buildings in all of Vienna is the mighty Hofburg Palace. With its immense baroque architecture, it is one of the most heavily photographed buildings in the city. While I’ll go into greater detail about the Palace itself later on in this post, this first Vienna photography location is about Michaelerplatz, also known as St. Michael’s Square, one of the most famous squares in Vienna.
sources.shortName: The BEST photo spots in Vienna (with pictures)

sources.snippet: This square holds the beautiful Neo-Baroque entrance gate to the Hofburg complex. Later in the morning to evening, there are several horse and buggies parked outside the entrance gate for a ride through the central district of Vienna. There are several coffee houses and cafes nearby, which makes it a perfect spot to have a coffee or hot chocolate while admiring the beautiful architecture through the window.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: Vienna has a range of beautiful public squares, but Michaelerplatz is one of my favorites for photos. Centrally located within the Innere Stadt, Michaelerplatz forms the main entrance to The Hofburg, the former imperial palace of the Habsburgs. Within the square, you will also find the historic Michaelskirche, which dates back to the 13th century, and the excavated site of the Roman settlement, Vindobona.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

sources.snippet: There may be nowhere else in the city that quite sums up the grandeur of Vienna as well as Michaelerplatz. This open circular plaza sits before one wing of the majestic Hofburg Palace and its gleaming white baroque façade. Two magnificent fountains flank the main gate, and traditional horse carriages parked out front help to complete the scene.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Photography Spots in Vienna
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Instagrammable Spots in Vienna | Europe Famous Hostels

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Michaelerplatz, or St. Michael's Square, is a captivating hub in the heart of Vienna that showcases an array of historical architecture and archaeological treasures. As you stroll through this vibrant square, you'll be enveloped by structures dating from the 1200s to the 1900s. A delightful way to experience its charm is by taking a horse-drawn carriage ride, which adds a touch of nostalgia to your visit.

reviews.reviewText: A beautiful place with ancient roman structures and the impressive Hofburg.
This is an architecturally impressive square containing St. Michael's church and the stunning entrance to the Hofburg Palace.
Scenic and historic part of Vienna near luxury stores and historic buildings. You can hire a traditional Fiaker (horse-drawn carriage) and explore the area like classical time.
Beautiful square leading out of the Hofburg complex into the St. Michael's church. Pay attention to the ruins in the middle of the square.
Amazing place for visitors

Michaelerplatz is pretty much the main junction in old Vienna. One way to the shopping area, the other to the Opera, and through the archway to the Spanish riding school,  Sisi museum, the Hofburg palace and the museum quarter. If you don't visit here, you may have missed some of the best of Vienna.
So amazing and huge building. Very impressive and really massive. I love sculptures outside the building
The heart of Vienna! A must see

placeMetadata.name: Café Central

sources.snippet: Not so far from Rathaus and St. Peter’s Church, there is the Café Central one of the most beautiful and picturesque coffeehouses in Vienna. The beautiful architecture, full of details in gold and marble, with pillars reaching the ceiling from the floor, will be something taking your breath. Cafe’ central is an institution in Vienna since 1876, this beautiful coffee house has welcomed historical personalities such as Trotsky, Freud and many others.
sources.shortName: 20 Unbelievable Vienna Instagram Spots Worth A Visit

sources.snippet: Located in the first district of Vienna, the Café Central is a traditional Viennese coffee place that used to be a meeting spot of the Viennese intellectual scene in the late 19th century.It is one of those classic experiences you need to have in Vienna!. Photo tip: get the famous Sachertorte, a chocolate cake with apricot filling as a prop for your photos, and eat this wonderful treat as a reward!
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Remember that rather nice-looking, but seemingly un-extraordinary cafe which stood on the corner of the building?. It’s the Cafe Central – and it’s our next stop on our tour of Vienna Instagram spots!. This is probably the most famous cafe in Vienna, and it’s not just for the cakes – though those are delicious too!
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

sources.snippet: Ferstel Passage is a hidden treasure trove of architectural splendor and boutique shops. Tucked away near Vienna’s historic center, near the square Freyung, it is a passage through time that is perfect for exploration. The passage dates back to 1860 and was designed by Austrian architect Heinrich von Ferstel.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones

sources.snippet: With historic links to Freud & Trotsky, Café Central has been a Viennese staple since 1847. There may be queues outside, but it’s worth it. Indulge with classic Viennese dishes, traditional coffee specialities and sweet treats from the in-house patisserie.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Vienna

sources.snippet: What’s a trip to Vienna without some Viennese coffee and a treat?. A photoshoot in this iconic cafe is a must. Regardless of where you sit in  Cafe Central, you will get some instaworthy backdrops with their high mirrored walls and sparking chandeliers.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

sources.snippet: One of Vienna’s most picturesque coffeehouses is Café Central. As you go in you’ll instantly be greeted by stunning pillars reaching from floor to ceiling. This cafe is also perfect for a break to get some tasty Viennese coffee and cake.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)
Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Long-standing venue for Viennese cuisine, with famous historic links including to Freud & Trotsky.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Café Central, located in the Palais Ferstel complex, is a renowned Viennese venue with a rich historical legacy. Frequented by influential figures such as Freud and Trotsky, this café was a hub for literary and political discussions. Since its establishment in 1876, it has retained its late Romantic Historicism style despite post-WW2 renovations.

reviews.reviewText:
Beautiful architectural interior with a beautiful selection of cakes all fitting for the location.
We booked online so when we arrived we were able to walk past the very long queue outside and go straight inside and we were seated immediately.
The place is every bit as beautiful as all the photos and there was someone playing the piano which added to the elegant ambience.
Tea was beautifully served and the cakes were some of the best we’d had during our week in Austria. There’s a vast selection on offer so it’s tough to choose something! And the ones we tried tasted as good as they looked.
The cakes and the beverages were all very reasonably priced too. They also have a full food menu too which is also very reasonably priced.
Although this is known as a touristy place, I would definitely come back and try a meal here. Maybe in the evening so we can enjoy the evening ambience. All in all a lovely experience.

Now I Know What the Fuss Is All About – I had read so much about Café Central before my trip to Vienna - rave reviews everywhere, calling it a must-visit. And after finally experiencing it, I completely understand the hype. The café is a beautiful slice of tradition. The interior is stunning - elegant and classic. There is an impressive selection of cakes and pastries, and choosing just a couple was no easy task! We went with the warm chocolate cake (served with vanilla ice cream and fresh cream) and a vanilla puff pastry. The chocolate cake was absolutely the highlight - rich, indulgent, and melt-in-your-mouth good. We also ordered coffee- cappuccino was great, though the latte was just okay. Not bad, but nothing special.
The service was pleasant and efficient despite the crowd. And yes, be prepared to wait in a queue, especially during peak times.

We had to try out this iconic restaurant. The apple strudel was a little bit of a let down, but everything else we tried was good. What you are getting most by coming here is the atmosphere. You can feast with your eyes because the decor and architecture is stunning. It does feel like stepping back in time. The service is exceptional for those in wheelchairs. Just go to the front and they will guide you through a back entrance that has a ramp. We were able to skip the incredibly long line because of this. And the see areas others don’t get to see was a treat.

After waiting at the door for 15-20 minutes, we were let in. The waiter who attended to us was very humorous and friendly. We were very pleased with his service. The atmosphere is great for visiting with friends or your loved one. We ordered an apple dessert, but it wasn't to our taste. The latte and hot chocolate were satisfying in quantity and passable in taste. However, the cafe's ambiance was very nice for a tourist destination.

A Classic Cafe

When in Vienna, they say, you must pay a visit to this cafe. And that’s what I did.

I went in around 8pm, so was fortunate there was no queue. The ambience is beautiful with people enjoying themselves with friends or family and having a coffee. The place is lit up beautifully and the decor lives up to its reputation. Furnishings are classy as well. Table was a bit small for the number of things we ordered though.

We tried the famous pancake. It was not so sweet and nice. The apple pie was surprisingly good though. Together with a nice drink, it was wonderful to soak in the ambience of this classic cafe.

Service was prompt and attentive. They did their best to make sure we got whatever we needed like an extra plate, fork etc. They wanted our experience to be a good one. And I gotta say we appreciated it.

Definitely a place to visit when in Vienna.

We waited around 30 mins to get a table. The host with gray hair is incredibly rude but didn’t let him spoiled my experience, I got to try the best Kaiserschmarrn I’ve ever had here 🥰 and the grilled sandwich was delicious too. Their signature coffees “Amadeus” and “Maria Theresa” are an interesting combination, they were both so good! The interior is absolutely stunning and our waiter was nice and friendly too. Definitely a must-visit while in Vienna!

Absolutely wonderful experience!
The food was delicious and beautifully presented, and the service was attentive, friendly, and professional. Cafe Central truly lives up to its reputation – a must-visit in Vienna!

An iconic cafe in Vienna that beats out the rest in my opinion.  You walk in to a massive, beautiful painted ballroom with the piano playing.

We ordered a few desserts and all were really good. The strudel was the best we had our entire trip and the cake we picked out was good too.

Come for the ambiance.

placeMetadata.name: St. Peter's Church

sources.snippet: The St. Peter’s Church (Peterskirche) is a Baroque Roman Catholic church and the first domed structure built in Vienna!. There used to be an old church dating back to the Early Middle Ages in its place. Even though nothing remains of it today, it is said to have been the oldest church building in Vienna which was replaced with the Romanesque church that you can see today.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: This oldest church is really beautiful, located in the center of the city you can find it easily and the interior is amazing with its incredible dome. The turreted dome was mainly designed by Matthias Steinl, who was also responsible for the interior decoration and the pews with their fabulous cherubic heads. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: 10 most Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: The Peterskirche is an incredibly beautiful church right in the center of Vienna. Surrounded by two buildings, it looks as if she wants to squeeze between them. Unfortunately, at the time we were there, there was a construction site on the left, which is why it does not appear as it does in reality in the photo.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: Situated on the narrow Groban Street, the church’s Baroque exterior topped with a light green dome is picture perfect. Especially if you manage to snap a horse and carriage that’s passing by. Inspired by its namesake counterpart in Vatican City, the exquisitely ornate interior is well worth a glimpse, too.
sources.shortName: 11 of the most Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: Another beautiful photo location in Vienna is right outside of St. Peter’s Church (Peterskirche). The Baroque/roman church is not just remarkable to look at but also impresses on the inside. If you happen to get here around noon, you can enjoy the sunlight hitting the roof and parts of the front.
sources.shortName: The Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: Ultimate Photo Guide

sources.snippet: Stationed right in the heart of Vienna, this baroque building is inspired by St Peter’s Basilica in Rome. Not only is it a church but it is also a venue for operas, concerts and recitals. We recommend you try and view the church when the sun is shining.
sources.shortName: 17 Most Instagrammable spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: St. Peter’s Church (Peterskirche) is located right next to Graben, which is one of the most representative places in the old town. This building can be seen on many Instagram photos from Vienna.
sources.shortName: Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: 18th-century church featuring ornate baroque art & architecture & daily organ recitals.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Peter's Catholic Church (Peterskirche) is an 18th-century baroque church modeled after St. Peter's in Rome, with a rich history dating back to a Roman church and one founded by Charlemagne in 792 AD. The church features ornate baroque art and architecture, including a massive dome with a superb fresco and many artistic treasures.

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful church with amazing interior. We went there for an organ concert but they had changed the program last minute so we couldn't hear it. I recommend checking the music program on their website daily to avoid missing some performances. I am sure that the concerts there are worth a visit especially when they don't require expensive tickets or prebooking.

St. Peter’s Church is absolutely stunning with beautiful architecture and incredible artwork that make it worth a visit on its own. We attended a concert here and, while the seats weren’t the most comfortable, the musicians were outstanding. Their performance truly transported us through time and space, perfectly matched to the historic and atmospheric setting. A memorable experience in a breathtaking venue.

St. Peter’s Church is one of those places that leaves you speechless the moment you step inside. Tucked away just off the bustling Graben, it might be easy to miss if you’re not looking for it—but it’s absolutely worth seeking out.

The baroque architecture is stunning. Every inch of the interior is intricately detailed—gilded sculptures, vivid frescoes, and an altar that practically glows in the natural light filtering through the dome. It’s not a large church, but the sheer amount of craftsmanship packed into the space is astonishing.

Even during busy hours, the atmosphere remains peaceful and reverent. If you’re lucky, you might catch an organ recital or a classical concert in the evening—an experience that feels nothing short of transcendent in such a beautiful setting.

Unlike some other major churches, St. Peter’s is free to enter, though donations are welcome and deserved. It’s an ideal spot to take a quiet break from sightseeing, light a candle, or simply soak in the incredible artistry and serenity.

Whether you’re religious or not, this church is a must-see in Vienna. It’s a masterpiece of design and a perfect reminder of the city’s rich cultural and spiritual history.

Very imposing and nice church to visit. Entry is fee though you are encouraged to make a donation. They do have people playing the church organ from time to time. During those times, the sanctuary area might be closed until after the performance.
The interior of the church looks very beautiful. Worth a visit.

Small but surprisingly beautiful church. First I thought it would be just another little church. Still decided to visit purely for spiritual purposes but after stepping in, I was speechless. There was the prayer going on and the whole experience with the prayer, organ music, singing, and interior was simply amazing.

St. Peter’s Church ⛪🎨✨
A hidden Baroque beauty in the heart of Vienna! 🌟 Gold ceilings, angel statues, and dreamy organ music fill the air 🎶👼💫. Small but totally breathtaking! 😍⏳📿

The church is located in the historical center of Vienna, near Graben Street, and is one of the oldest Christian shrines in the city.
What

St. Peter’s Church is a Roman Catholic gem tucked away in Vienna’s heart, and wow, it’s a Baroque stunner! The architecture hits you right away—those elegant curves and that gorgeous green dome scream grandeur. Inside, it’s like stepping into a golden wonderland. The frescoes on the ceiling are mind-blowing, especially the one with the Coronation of Our Lady, and the gilded altars and statues are just dripping with detail. It’s smaller than St. Stephen’s but feels so rich and intimate. Can get busy, so early mornings are best to really take it all in. 5 stars for this beauty.

placeMetadata.name: Ferstel Passage

sources.snippet: Running beneath Palais Ferstel, the Ferstel Passage is one of the best Instagram spots in Vienna if you want to tap on a spot of shopping alongside your shoot!. This covered 19th-century arcade was modeled on the shopping passages found in Paris and is buzzing with high-end shops, fresh produce, and chic eateries. You can choose to capture the arches, fountains, and moldings or take a seat in one of the cafes for some lifestyle shots.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Running beneath Palais Ferstel, the Ferstel Passage is one of the best Instagram spots in Vienna if you want to tap on a spot of shopping alongside your shoot!. This covered 19th-century arcade was modeled on the shopping passages in Paris and is buzzing with high-end shops, fresh produce, and chic eateries. You can capture the arches, fountains, and moldings or sit in one of the cafes for some lifestyle shots.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

sources.snippet: Many visitors don’t know that there are a handful of semi-hidden passages that run through parts of Vienna’s historical center. Without question, the most photogenic is the Ferstel Passage, an elegant arcade that passes through a cluster of historic noble palaces. Ornate skylights and arches make for a grand spectacle here, as does the classic indoor water fountain in the passage’s light-filled courtyard.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Photography Spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: Ferstel Passage is a covered shopping arcade connecting Herrengasse and Freyung streets. The passage is built into the Palais Ferstel, which is named after the architect who designed it. Even though the palace was originally built for a bank, it is now most famous for its ground cafe, named Cafe Central, which offers the visitor a glimpse of the magnificent interior of the building.
sources.shortName: Vienna Instagram Spots: 15 Amazing Photo Locations

sources.snippet: The Ferstel Passage is most definitely one of the best Vienna Instagram spots – it may only take a few minutes to walk through it, but you’re bound to fall in love with it. And so will your followers!. The passage is a covered shopping arcade (which were super-fashionable in Vienna at one point), built into the Palais Ferstel.
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

sources.snippet: This is the first of a few secret Instagram spots in Vienna. The Ferstel Passage is often outside of the tourists’ maps, which is good to shoot empty places in the city centre. This shopping arcade is going from Freyungass e to Herrengasse, perpendicular to Strauchgasse.
sources.shortName: 20 Unbelievable Vienna Instagram Spots Worth A Visit
Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Built in 1860, this regal arcade with a fountain & courtyard offers upscale boutiques, bars & cafes.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Ferstel Passage is a covered, 19th-century arcade in Vienna that's packed with upscale boutiques and cafes. It's a great spot to snap some lifestyle shots alongside the fountain and courtyard, or to take a seat in one of the cafes for some sweet shots. If you're looking for an underground party scene, head to Passage Nightclub located in a rundown underpass that used to connect the Imperial Palace and Kunsthistorisches Museum.

reviews.reviewText: Interesting shopping covered shopping parade with a variety of shops and cafes. Ornate ceilings and architectural elements throughout the parade. Some interesting shops and cafes located throughout. Busy when we visited but not overwhelming. Worth a look.
Ferstel Passage is a hidden gem in Vienna. It’s a lovely place to stop by one of the charming shops or cafes. If you love discovering unique and less crowded spots, this is definitely worth a visit.

The Ferstel Passage in Vienna is magical at night during Christmas. Visiting after hours, it was peaceful and quiet, with soft live music echoing through the elegant, beautifully lit arcade. A serene and enchanting holiday experience.
So beautiful! There are lots of cute spots for a quick break but just walking down the passage is pretty worth it! Nice little gem.

The Ferstel Passage in Vienna is a hidden treasure, offering a charming blend of elegance and history. Nestled between opulent buildings, it invites you to stroll through its stunning arcades, where exquisite shops, cafés, and architecture transport you to a bygone era. A perfect spot to experience Vienna's timeless allure.
It is a very beautiful passage! The shops are soo nice and the cafes as well! Thee is a nice statue at one end of it and another passage in it that leads to a nice restaurant!

This is a passage thru time, you can see and feel the elegance and style of an era long gone by.
It is amazing and you are left with a sense of wonder,  at the beauty and magnificence. Take time to see and view.
Such a beautiful and cosy viennese place! Now, at lockdown time you can buy a Glühwein here for take away, to walk around. Just look at this Christmas tree! :)

placeMetadata.name: Austrian National Library

sources.snippet: The Austrian National Library (Nationalbibliothek) impresses with detailed ceiling art aka frescoes, darker wood tones, and gold accents. On top of that, the library is home to over 12 million books filling the shelves. Taking a photo right at the entrance of the State Hall or by the marble statue of Emperor Charles VI will grant you stunning Instagram pics.
sources.shortName: The Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: Ultimate Photo Guide

sources.snippet: Situated in the heart of Vienna, The Austrian National Library, one of my favourite places in Vienna, is a treasure trove of knowledge and beauty. This grand institution is not just a library; it is a breathtaking journey through time. As you step into the library, you will be greeted by the jaw-dropping Prunksaal, or State Hall.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones

sources.snippet: You don’t need to be a book worm to enjoy the spectacular views at the National Library. If you only visit one thing in the library it MUST be the baroque state hall. The scenery is breathtaking with marble columns and an ornately painted ceiling.
sources.shortName: 17 Most Instagrammable spots in Vienna
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: This library definitely isn’t the easiest for Instagram as it’s so wide. At night it gets lit up and also looks nice.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Baroque State Hall with ceiling frescoes housing National Library including papyrus & globe museums.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Austrian National Library, also known as the Prunksaal, is a magnificent Baroque State Hall adorned with intricate ceiling frescoes. It is located in Vienna and houses the Habsburg Court Library, which was commissioned by Emperor Charles VI in 1716. The library's stunning architecture features marble, gold, and hardwood elements that create a grand atmosphere. Visitors can explore the extensive collection of over 12 million books while admiring the opulent interior.

reviews.reviewText: I mean - so stunning!!!! Huge Beauty and the Beast vibes!! What I would give to climb a few of the ladders and crack open the books! A highlight of our trip for sure and would highly recommend! We used our Vienna City Passes to get in and I’m so glad we did!!

One of the most beautiful and magical bookstores I’ve ever visited! The whole time I was there, I felt like I was dreaming. I highly recommend visiting it, especially for book lovers. My only note is that it gets very crowded it would be much better if they introduced time slots and allowed groups in at intervals. That would improve both the experience and the flow of the visit. Still, it’s absolutely worth it!

Worth any money to see… I have visited many libraries around the world and this is one of the most fabulous. And as a geographer, the globe is absolutely amazing. The paintings even the stairwell are all beautiful. I highly recommend visiting. Danke !

This baroque library is among the most beautiful libraries in the world. It's been the Austrian emperor's library and contains over 200'000 books. Besides the books, the architecture is stunning, especially the ceiling paintings. Audio guide (on your own smartphone) available. Photo and video taking is permitted.

One wonderful room stacked full of books. Really surreal and has some nice detail about Austrian history through the media as well.

Worth a visit simply to stand in awe of this beautiful and historic interior.

Like a dream. It was one of the most beautiful places I've ever been to. As a tourist, I was here to take in all the beautiful aesthetics. I'm so glad I came by. Was a last min decision. The tour guide recommended it and I came right by and bought an entrance ticket.

The Austrian National Library in Vienna is a stunning place full of old books. Its grand State Hall with golden shelves and colorful ceilings is breathtaking. The rooms feel like stepping into history. It’s a quiet spot perfect for book lovers. A must-visit for anyone in Vienna!

I absolutely loved the place. While I do agree that the price is a bit much (though I had a student discount), I enjoyed it enough to say it's worth it. The place is beautiful, I was in awe. It also has an exhibition with significant points in Austrian history. That includes old papers and media from each time, which I found very interesting. There was no line for tickets, and while it was a bit crowded, it was alright. I recommend a visit!

placeMetadata.name: Catholic Church Maria am Gestade

sources.snippet: The final of my Vienna photo spots is one of the oldest churches in the city. Maria am Gestade Church (Mary at the Shore) is Gothic in its design and architecture and was built in the late 14th century. It’s far more humble in comparison with the other churches featured in my guide but is nonetheless one of the most beautiful monuments in the city which will appeal to devotees of ancient buildings.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: One of the oldest churches in the city—along with St. Peter’s Church and St. Rupert’s Church—it is one of the few surviving examples of Gothic architecture in Vienna. Climb up the *very* photogenic steps for the best Insta. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Vienna

sources.snippet: Probably one of the most photogenic stairs in Vienna are located just below the church of Maria am Gestade (Mary at the Shore). This place is often overlooked by tourists, usually local people make photo sessions here.
sources.shortName: Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria
The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Landmark Catholic church, one of the oldest & last examples of Gothic architecture in the city.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the heart of Vienna, the Catholic Church Maria am Gestade stands as a remarkable testament to Gothic architecture and is one of the city's oldest churches. This stunning structure offers visitors a glimpse into the medieval past, surrounded by other historical landmarks like St. Stephen's Cathedral and various monastic complexes that date back to the 13th century. The church overlooks the serene Donaukanal, adding to its charm and beauty.

reviews.reviewText: Located in the Innere Stadt, the Catholic Church Maria am Gestade, a hidden gem in Vienna, is a striking Gothic structure that draws visitors with its majestic architecture and rich history. Beautiful architecture, free entry to see inside.

Although it is a famous Catholic cathedral, it was easy to visit and there were few tourists, so it had a good atmosphere. The interior was cozy. It is located a little high up, so the view down is also pretty.

We were on our way from the beautiful Votive Church to Stephen's Square and its magnificent cathedral when we discovered this church.
It's smaller, but just as beautiful.
And as always, I recommend you go inside and admire its beauty.
It's definitely worth the detour.
In short, beautiful and out of the paths, try to make some time for it.
Take a look at the photos.

MG has a 5pm English mass so we found ourselves there on a Sunday evening during our stay in Vienna.   We arrived early so we could explore the church.  We were pleased to discover a reliquary of St Clement, the patron saint of Vienna.  The community was welcoming and we were pleased to be able to enjoy the baptism of the newest member of the parish!  The music was enjoyable as well.  The hymnals are in English for the English mass :).   The notes are the same though!

Its considrred the first church in Vienna dedicated to Mary. It is called Mary by the river (the river now had been diverted elsewhere so its no longer by the river :) ) The Redemptorist Missionary priests are caretakers of the Church which is also home to the remains of a great Redemptorist Saint: Saint Clement Maria Hoffbauer CSsR. He is the second patron of the city of Vienna. He played a great role in the city's Catholic revival during an era of heavy enlightenment and anti-religious era. St. Clement together with the city's inteligensia inspired the romantic philosophical movement so that the Catholic heritage, faith and devotion was greatly preserved. I went up to its bell tower and it was magnificent. But you got to ask permission and with a guide from Father Rector Dominic a kind Irish Redemptotist who speaks good German. Please pray there for an increase of vocations in Europe. If you are Filipino, Dr. Jose Rizals place is just few blocks away. Most probably he visited this church as mentioned in his memoires.

A hidden gem for the Gothic enthusiasts.
Located quietly in between buildings but grand when looked at from the front; this church holds it's grace as you climb it's stairs.
The interior of this church felt like no other, rather small and captivating but still unique and detailed.
It hold the title as being one of my favorite churches in the city.

Maria am Gestade (Mary at the Shore) is located at Salvatorgasse street and is one of Vienna's oldest churches and few remaining examples of Gothic style buildings from the Middle Ages. The churches history dates back to at least the 12th century while the present building was constructed between 1394-1414.

During a recent visit, I unfortunately found the church closed to the public so was unable to enter and explore the inside. However, I did very much enjoy walking around the outside, taking in the original Gothic architecture of the building.

Most notably for me were the porticos which are fenced but easy to view. These are decorated nicely with statue reliefs and fresco ornamentation. You can spot a few gargoyles as well on the side of the church building. If you step back across the street in front of the church, you can better view the church tower which rises 56 metre high and dates back to 1428.

In the end, hopefully others will find the church open for visitation. If not, the exterior is worth a few minutes to enjoy if you are a fan of Gothic architecture.

Note: There is a decent stone fountain called Hannakenbrunnen at the bottom of the staircase leading up to Maria Am Gestade. This is worth checking out as well if you enjoy viewing monuments during your travels.
Beautiful gothic church, with paintings, sculptures and fine architectural details

placeMetadata.name: Naschmarkt

sources.snippet: The bustling Naschmarkt is Vienna’s largest and most famous food market, offering a colorful array of fresh produce, exotic spices, and local delicacies. The market’s lively atmosphere and vivid hues make it an ideal photography spot, allowing you to capture the essence of Vienna’s culinary scene. Don’t be afraid to strike up a conversation with the friendly vendors – they might just share a humorous anecdote or two about their experiences at the market.
sources.shortName: Vienna Photography Spots: Unraveling the Elegance of the Imperial City

sources.snippet: When in Vienna, it would be a crime not to visit the most famous market in the city. Not only can you find some funky fruit, vegetables and other fresh food from all over the world, you can also take some incredible photos with all the vibrant colours that just scream out at you. You can also buy some incredible food here too, both from the market and from the small independent shops that line the outside.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: The shapes and colors of food stalls always add some extra oomph to anyone’s Instagram feed, and Vienna’ Naschmarkt is no obsession. This nearly mile-long market over the Wien River has been a local favorite since the 1600s, and you’ll find plenty of appetizing displays to make your photos a feast for the eyes. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: 11 of the most Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: Many travel guides strongly recommend a visit to the Well-known Naschmarktbeyond the borders of Vienna. We also wanted to follow this recommendation, but we have to admit that we were very disappointed with the market. We find that there are now too many restaurants, restaurants, cafés, bars, etc.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions, Things to do & Photo spots (Austria)

sources.snippet: For capturing the vibrant essence of Vienna, the Naschmarkt is the place to visit. This lively market, with its colourful stalls and diverse crowd, is perfect for street photography. It showcases the lively, eclectic side of Vienna.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Not So Known Photography Locations In Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Naschmarkt is a bustling open-air market with two distinct lanes. One side is filled with casual dining spots, while the other offers high-quality produce and gourmet products favored by renowned chefs for their culinary creations.

placeMetadata.name: Albertina

sources.snippet: The Albertina Museum is known for its impressive architecture and art collections, but its terrace provides a stunning view of Vienna’s old town. The terrace overlooks the Opera House, and the combination of historical buildings with the bustling city below makes for a unique photo. The statue of Duke Albert and the grand entrance stairway lined with statues are also photogenic spots within the museum complex.
sources.shortName: Where to Find Vienna's Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Since you are already at the Albertina Museum’s terrace to take photos of the Vienna State Opera, make sure to also take a look around!. Elevated above street level, the terrace has at its center the equestrian statue of Archduke Albrecht. With its amazing views over the Vienna State Opera and the Hofburg Palace, it is one of the most beautiful spots in Vienna’s historic center.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Inside the Albertina Museum is a must-stop for history buffs!. Albertina is home to over 50,000 paintings featuring exhibits from artists such as Henry Matisse and Pablo Picasso, making it one of Austria’s most popular museums. It is also home to one of the largest print collections with over a million items.
sources.shortName: Photo Guide: The Top 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: In fact, the pictures of the Vienna State Opera taken on the terrace of the Albertina Museum most frequently appear on Instagram.
sources.shortName: Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: 19th-century Habsburg palace with staterooms & collections of old master prints & 20th-century art.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Albertina is a 19th-century Habsburg palace located in the largest of the Habsburg dynasty's residential palaces. It houses an extensive collection of old master prints, 20th-century art, over 65,000 watercolors and drawings, and about 70,000 photographs. The museum features works by renowned artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Rembrandt and others.

reviews.reviewText:
Magnificent museum worth spending a whole day in. Once a residential palace , later transfomed into an art museum by Maria Christine ( daughter of Queen Maria Theresa)and her husban Albert, hence the name - Alberina.
Great collection of modern and contemporary art.  Albrecht Dürer famous Hare , Modigliani Female Semi Nude, some Picasso, Klimt are just a few highlights of the collection.
I was lucky to see Matthew Wong exhibition here. What a wonderful discovery! I enjoyed every painting of it.
Don't miss the terrace featured in the movie  The Tabacconist.
Loved my visit and would come back to enjoy more next time I'm in Vienna.

Visited Albertina museum this afternoon. What a treat to anyone who loves art. Top floor of Albertina museum hosts an amazing collection entitled From Monet To Picasso that is a home to many pieces by Monet, Renoir, Kandinsky, Kokoshka, and Picasso. Admission is reasonable: as of July 2025, children under 19 get in free, and my adult ticket was 19 euros. Audioguides are free for children and 5 euros for adults, those are available in all major languages. The museum building itself is absolutely georgeous.
Great museum with stunning Impressionist works and elegant historic staterooms. Not too crowded, easy to enjoy. A must-visit in Vienna!

This is a great museum with famous colections, including some modern art. Small rooms, but spacious, seating benches, some parts include stairs, not crowded, but busy. We spent 2-3 hrs inside and It was worth it.

Good contemporary museum with regular changing expositions. Have visited the exhibition "From Monet to Picasso" exhibition this weekend, enjoyed contemplating quite a few fabulous pieces of art by impressionist and post-impressionists

My favourite museum, feels like you have visited 3 or more. You can get lost inside for hours... Magnificent interior, tons of famous pictures, beautifully arranged and curated. Definitely must visit while in Vienna! There's a great online "combo" ticket so you can explore this one and Albertina Modern. Not that the price is relevant for this experience...

In my opinion the best museum in Vienna.

It is a great example of a combination of classic and modern architecture both outside and inside. The cloakroom, lockers and the toilet are located before ticketing. Cloakroom costs some euro (can’t remember if it’s 1€ or 2€, only cash) but if you don’t have any money for it, the staff will give you token for the lockers - that’s really useful, thank you so much!

I recommend buying ticket online but it’s not a big deal cause queue was minimal (at least on Monday 12PM). After the ticket office area, you enter the exhibition, cafe and shop place. The staff is giving u some sort of sticker and if you want to came back to lockers or something they would know that you already bought a ticket.

The most impressive collection is the one located on level 2 - MONET TO PICASSO. The Batliner Collection. It’s a a comprehensive exhibition of the most important art of the XIX and XX centuries (names such as: Monet, Degas, Signac, Klimt, Matisse, die Brücke artists i.e. Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Karl Schmidt Rottluff, Munch, Kandinsky, Klee, Kupka, Magritte, Miró, Picasso). Don’t know why there wasn’t Francis Bacon and Marc Chagall on display.

On the first floor there are also quite charming rooms - Prunkräume, which could be interesting to people fond of this period - however everyone should see in the last of rooms works by Albrecht Dürer.

Prices in shop btw:
Magnet - 4,90€,
Postcards - 1,5-2€,
Monet to Picasso exhibition book - 19,90€.

World class museum that is a must see when in Vienna. See large amounts of art by Michelangelo, Rubens, Durer, Renoir, Picasso, Klimt, Matisse, Chagall, Monet, Cezanne and more. Expect to spend 3-4 hours in this incredible museum. Be sure to see the state rooms for some historic art.

placeMetadata.name: Viennese Giant Ferris Wheel

sources.snippet: Vienna’s Giant Ferris Wheel has been offering some of the best views over the city since 1900. The ferris wheel is an iconic part of the city, located near the entrance of the Wurstelprater amusement park in Leopoldstadt. Standing at more than 200 feet tall, the huge ferris wheel is one of the city's most iconic landmark and draws tons of tourists each year.
sources.shortName: Photo Guide: The Top 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: One of the more unusual photo spots in Vienna I found was the enormous – and some what out of place – Giant Ferris Wheel. The Giant Ferris Wheel was erected in 1897 to mark the 50th year of Emperor Franz Joseph’s accession to the throne. From it’s peak, you can bare witness to almost 2000 years of Vienna’s history.
sources.shortName: The BEST photo spots in Vienna (with pictures)

sources.snippet: Visible from far away, Giant Ferris Wheel offers a lot of great photo spots. Whether taken from far away, from below the wheel, or from the top of it, it provides numerous enviable photographs. It has a special charm when the night falls, and the carts are lit up.
sources.shortName: Top 11 photo spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: The Wiener Riesenrad is one of the oldest and largest Ferris wheels. It was built in 1845 and still comes with wooden cabins. I prefer photographing this at night but it also looks good in the day.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Fairground attraction rebuilt in 1945, with wooden cabins offering dining & an exhibition.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Viennese Giant Ferris Wheel, also known as Riesenrad, is a famous attraction located in the Wiener Prater. Originally opened to the public in 1766 by Habsburg Joseph II, this former royal hunting ground quickly became a popular entertainment hub for locals. The Ferris wheel was built in 1897 and rises to 65m, offering visitors stunning views of the city during its 20-minute rotation.

reviews.reviewText:
The Great Wheel From Vienna, a wonderful symbol of this city. It's definitely a must for those coming here. The views are stunning and the tickets are worth it. This is the best thing from Prater! 🙌
I definitely recommend it! ✅️🌟👍🏻

Very cool kind of pricey Nice to be able to see the city from such a vantage point. Was disappointed the way they rush you in and out of the car and so many people on each, also that they do not stop you at the Apex and was only taken around for one circle. Overall was a good experience recommend doing it once.

I haven't been on many Ferris Wheels so I don't have a lot to compare this one to but I really enjoyed it. The cabins are big and spacious and they don't stuff them full of people so there's plenty of room to move around and get a good view as it goes around. You'll be able to take some great pictures of Vienna and the panoramic view is spectacular. It was a windy day so there were some points where the cabin swung back and forth which may be scary for some people. If you're afraid of heights it's probably not the best choice but for everyone else it'll probably be worth it. The price is €14.50 for a single ticket.

Super slow. Not much of a view. Just worth going as it’s the oldest. They really don’t invest to make it a fun memorable experience. Many cable cars are blocked for dinner service , but no one knows how to book this dinner service and the price. But in advance no line tickets.

In order to see the view from above I would recommend to ride a Ferris wheel. There’s enough space inside . I bought a Vienna pass and it was included in this pass . We even have a nice picture from the whole family before the ride . Some pictures are taking from above .

Gorgeous sunset views from atop this beautiful Ferris wheel.  You ride within large cars that are all enclosed where you can sit or walk around sharing the different views with other riders.  It’s quiet, smooth, solid and feels very safe.  Highly recommend this experience.  Easily purchased my ticket at the ticket desk inside the building below behind the restaurant (a cool dry Saturday evening in May.)  During the summer it might be better to buy online to avoid a long wait. Before going up you get to see a beautiful one-room display of very artfully made models of the park and its history. You can walk through as fast or as slow as you desire.

Excellent Austrian service. The gentleman at the ticket station with Turkish sold tickets and open the doors tot he wheel with ok customer service. Then there were the beauty of the Vieanna wheel above beautiful Vienna. Beautiful pics, nice atmosphere, safe place, clean surroundings, good English skills in the service staff.

Wonderful views across Vienna from large, sturdy wagons.
Yes, it's a tourist trap, but not without merit.
We timed it well, but do plan ahead - it looks like the queue often gets frustratingly long at peak times (sunset).

placeMetadata.name: Votive Church

sources.snippet: When you’re searching for the best photography locations in Vienna, don’t miss the Votive Church off your list. This is a warm and welcoming place, and a photo of the interior is well worth the walk!. You can find this place just off the Ring Road, and a stone’s throw from the Sigmund Freud Museum (more on that later!), and you’ll spot it from a mile away – it’s a gorgeous, neo-Gothic building with a really interesting history.
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

sources.snippet: The Votive Church (Votivkirche) is a neo-Gothic church located on the Ringstraße. Here is the crazy story of how and why it was created. Following the failed attempted assassination of Emperor Franz Joseph by Hungarian nationalist János Libényi in 1853, the Empeor’s brother, the Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian organized a fund to build a church to thank God for saving his brother’s life and this Church became a votive offering.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: In the northwestern part of the 1st district – directly at the university ring – there are other beautiful buildings, such as the mighty Votive Church. Unfortunately, it was equipped during our visit; we were still able to take a quick look. The foundation stone for the church was laid in 1856 and the entire construction took more than 20 years to complete.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions, Things to do & Photo spots (Austria)
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Storied neo-Gothic church built in 1879, with a museum showcasing liturgical objects.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled along the iconic Ringstrasse, the Votive Church (Votivkirche) is a stunning example of neo-Gothic architecture that dates back to 1879. Its creation was inspired by a dramatic event: after an assassination attempt on Emperor Franz Joseph in 1853, his brother Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian initiated a fund to construct this church as a gesture of gratitude for the emperor's survival.

reviews.reviewText: Absolutely stunning! A night light show is a must visit! It is not only great light effects, but awesome sound. So breathtaking that you don't have time to take photos. Buy tickets for show in advance, tickets sell quickly. We bought tickets in the middle of the haul, had a great view.

My favorite cathedral in the city of Vienna.
With its perfect location between a  spacious park, this magnificent church lavishes your gaze when you take a look and doesn't disappoint.
A walk around the building is highly recommended before you get to the front since then you'll get to enjoy it's full beauty.
Decorated and detailed stone capture your attention since it cannot be missed when every corner of this church says that is was crafted to do so.
A heavily structured interior hold you gently as you study its corners.
Built for gratitude, honor and respect whilst holding beauty and histroy ;
this church remains a charm of the city of Vienna and a staple of family love.

The Votive Church stands out as both a historical monument and spiritual retreat. With its awe-inspiring neo-Gothic architecture, artful stained-glass illumination, and serene interior, it offers a unique and reflective experience. Whether you’re an architecture lover, history enthusiast, or just seeking a peaceful sanctuary, this gem—often overshadowed by its famous neighbor—deserves a spot on your Vienna itinerary.

Such a stunning spot! Votive Church is an absolute gem—its neo-Gothic architecture is breathtaking, and the stained glass windows are mesmerizing. Whether you’re religious or just love beautiful buildings, this place is worth a visit. It’s quiet, cozy, and has a peaceful vibe, perfect for taking a break from the city’s buzz. Bonus points for the little garden and play area for kids! Highly recommend checking it out.

This has to be one of the best church buildings in Vienna. Very different from other architecture-wise but very similar to churches that you would in  central France (for instance in Beauvais).
It has stunning stained glass windows coupled with beautiful masonry/stone work.
They have light shows there.

We watched the light show and it was amazing. The duration is just enough for you to enjoy the show. It was spectacular experience and whoever came up to this idea is genius.

You have to buy the ticket earlier because even though it was already happening for a long time now, they are mostly sold out

This impressive church, just a short walk from the Rathaus and the Volksgarten, should not be missed.
The interior is just as splendid as the exterior.
Especially the large stained glass which are truly amazing
Just take a look at the photos.
On Saturdays, a small flea market is also held nearby, offering plenty of opportunities to buy souvenirs and much more.
Enjoy!

Great white church near Rathaus.  It has double towers and the inside is really beautiful. Big park around it. Most of the churches in Vienna are spectacular with lots of ornament and history.  Not many tourists here. Recommend it and then after you can go and check ot the Rathaus.

placeMetadata.name: St. Francis of Assisi Church

sources.snippet: A real life fairytale, this church is spectacularly similar to a mediaeval castle and in one of the most magical locations!. One of the most beautiful churches in Vienna, this Basilica style monument is set right next to the Danube River where you can get amazing views and pictures of the church from the Reichsbrücke, in other words the Empire bridge. Very well connected by metro links into the city centre, this church is the PERFECT spot for breathtaking photos!
sources.shortName: 17 Most Instagrammable spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: The St. Francis of Assisi Church is further afield compared to the other Vienna Instagram spots on my list but it’s worth riding the metro out to pay it a visit. It follows the architectural style of a Catholic Basilica and was built at the turn of the 20th century and consecrated in 1913. With its russet-colored turrets and towers and Rhenish-Romanesque elements, it resembles the fairytale castles of Europe.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: The St. Francis of Assisi Church in Vienna looks like a fairytale castle and is located right near the Danube in the second district at the Mexicoplatz. It's one of the newer churches in Vienna. It was built to honor the 50th anniversary of the reign of Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria - the husband of Empress Elisabeth of Austria ("Sissi").
sources.siteName: No Camera Bag: iPhone Photography for Travelers and Explorers
sources.shortName: Top 7 Must-Visit Photo Spots in Vienna for Night Photography
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Landmark basilica consecrated in 1913, with golden mosaics in the art nouveau Elizabeth Chapel.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Francis of Assisi Church, also known as the Kaiserjubilaumskirche or Mexico Church, is a landmark basilica in Vienna. Built between 1898 and 1910 to celebrate Emperor Franz Josef's 50th anniversary, it resembles a medieval castle and features golden mosaics in the art nouveau Elizabeth Chapel.

reviews.reviewText:
This beautiful church was one of the highlights of my latest itinerary while in Vienna. It lies next to the Danube and beholds your eyes with it's beauty. If you've ever dreamt of seeing a real life princess castle, this is the closest thing to reality.

I love the architecture and design, reminiscent of ancient times, whilst being anchored in our contemporary time. The bright red roof and towers are visible from miles away and are just simply stunning.

I've took lots of photos here and I still think it wasn't enough. The pictures don't make it justice, as I highly recommend that you visit this church to see for yourself. We didn't go inside as it was closed during our outside visit, but I do think you can visit the premises when opened.
The impressive church is a little bit too far from the center. In the evening time when we were there the church was under lighted, however it’s an important touristic objective worth to visit.

During our river cruise with Avalon Waterways, our ship had docked in this area. On a very first night when we saw the church from our top deck, it looked very beautiful in colorful lights. St. Francis of Assisi Church also known as Kaiser Jubilee Church, is a Basilica style Catholic church in district 2 of Vienna on the banks of Danube. The interior of the church is worth seeing for the lovers of art and architecture. From outside it looks more like a castle. A large striking tower and two bell towers adds to the beauty of church. Beside art nouveau angels with palm leaves in gold mosaic on the ceiling and a large art nouveau chandelier, there are modern paintings by living artists. Worth seeing !!

It is one of the most beautiful churches in Vienna.  The look from outside is just amazing.  I was unfortunately not inside as it was closed by the time I was there. You can also have a great view when you travel with a car. The colour of the church,  the art , the design,  the look , and the location of the church are just amazing ❤️.  A must visit place in Vienna . I always enjoy the view.

The Saint Francis of Assisi Church, also known as the Kaiser Jubilee Church or “Mexico Church”, is a stunning riverside landmark in Vienna. Built between 1898 and 1913 to honor Emperor Franz Joseph’s 50th reign anniversary, its unique mix of Romanesque, Byzantine, and Gothic styles makes it look like a charming little castle. The red-tiled pointed and round roofs, along with multiple towers, really stand out on the banks of the Danube Canal near the Reichsbrücke (Empire Bridge). Nice place to visit for architecture lovers and anyone enjoying a scenic walk by the river.

This church was beside where our cruise ship was moored for a couple days.  At first I was surprised that such a grand building would be named for such a humble saint; but when I visited, it made more sense.  Unlike the cathedral at the center of Vienna, this place has simple rough doorways.  The inside is beautiful but not opulent.  Instead of sitting in the commercial center of the city, it sits by the river where more of the city’s working class seem to traffic. If you’re looking for a sanctuary of peace in the middle of a hectic vacation; take some time in the morning here to pray and contemplate God’s kindness and beauty.
This church is incredibly beautiful, and a large park in front enhances its charm.
A magnificent church that looks like a castle. It’s definitely worth going inside to take a look.

placeMetadata.name: Maria-Theresien-Platz

sources.snippet: Maria-Theresien-Platz is a large public square surrounded by two almost identical buildings, Kunsthistorisches Museum (Museum of Fine Arts) and the Naturhistorisches Museum (Natural History Museum). A large statue of Empress Maria Theresa is located at its center, given its name to the square. Photo tip: even if the plaza becomes pretty full during the day if you take your photos from an angle in front of the bushes, it is easy to avoid people.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: Another public square that I can recommend to photographers and content creators is the beautiful Maria-Theresien-Platz. This piazza is adjacent to The Hofburg and is the setting of prominent museums such as Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien and the Museum of Natural History Vienna. At the heart of the square, you will spot a huge statue of Empress Maria Theresa with four fountains marking each corner.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Another public square Insta worthy is the beautiful Maria-Theresien-Platz. This piazza is adjacent to The Hofburg and is the setting of prominent museums such as Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien and the Museum of Natural History Vienna. At the heart of the square, you will spot a colossal statue of Empress Maria Theresa, with four fountains marking each corner.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

placeMetadata.description: Prominent square by museums featuring a monument to empress Maria Theresa, fountains & green space.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Maria-Theresien-Platz is a significant square in Vienna, named after Empress Maria Theresa. It is flanked by impressive architecture and sits between the Hofburg Palace and the MuseumsQuartier. The square features a large statue of Empress Maria Theresa at its center, surrounded by fountains marking each corner. This public space is home to two prominent museums, the Kunsthistorisches Museum and the Naturhistorisches Museum.

reviews.reviewText: Wauw, I absolutely love this place! It is so amazing! The buildings around are beautiful and the park is nice to relax. You can lay down in the grass and look around. It’s family friendly and there are sitting places too.

Maria-Theresien-Platz is one of Vienna’s most beautiful and historically significant squares. Nestled between the stunning Kunsthistorisches Museum and Naturhistorisches Museum, the square offers visitors a perfect blend of art, culture, and history. The centerpiece is the impressive monument of Empress Maria Theresa, surrounded by beautiful gardens and fountains. It’s an ideal spot to relax, take photos, and soak in Vienna’s rich heritage. The atmosphere is lively, especially during special events and seasonal markets, making it a must-visit location for anyone exploring the city.

Absolutely loved visiting Maria-Theresien-Platz! 😍 The architecture is stunning, with two beautiful museums facing each other and the grand statue of Maria Theresa right in the middle 👑. It’s such a peaceful spot to relax, take photos 📸, or just enjoy the vibe of Vienna. The gardens are super well-kept and everything feels so elegant and historic 🌿🏛️. Great place to stop by, especially in the evening when everything lights up ✨. A must-visit if you’re in the city!
The museum district of Vienna is simply amazing. You have three to four incredible buildings that are right in line with Parliament and all the other impressive monuments.

Flanked by two magnificent museums , this monument ( surrounded by parks) is huge and built in honour of Empress Maria Theresa . It is a great place for art lovers who can visit the museums and family and friends to chill in the park .
Famous square with two mirrored museum and the famous statue. For more, follow our instagram @gemislist
What a scenery!!! Look at the architecture of these two massive historical buildings right next to the plaza!

The two massive buildings facing each other, the Kunsthistorisches Museum & the Museum of Natural History, totally blew me away. I’m pretty sure they’re almost identical, and both are absolutely stunning architecturally. The symmetry is so satisfying, and the whole square feels super grand but still peaceful. The statue of Maria Theresa in the middle adds that perfect historic touch.

placeMetadata.name: Schönbrunn Palace Park

sources.snippet: Schönbrunn Palace is one of the top attractions in the city and no Vienna itinerary is ever complete without visiting this gorgeous palace. Schönbrunn served as an imperial hunting lodge in the earlier days but in the 18th century, it was transformed into a palatial imperial residence. Although it’s possible to tour the inside of the palace (you can check the ticket options here), sadly you can’t take any photos inside.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: The Schönbrunn Palace, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is one of Vienna’s most popular attractions and an ideal place for photos. Its striking Baroque architecture, grand facade, and symmetrical designs make for a dramatic backdrop. The gardens are vast and beautifully landscaped, with tree-lined walkways, fountains, and statues that add elegance to any photo.
sources.shortName: Where to Find Vienna's Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Schonbrunn Park itself is another Insta-worthy place in Vienna where you can take lots of beautiful photos. The grounds are literary huge, so even on a crowded day, you’ll still be able to find a spot to have only for yourself. On top of that, exploring the gardens of the palace won’t cost you anything, as it’s one of the free things to do in Vienna.
sources.shortName: Vienna Instagram Spots: 15 Amazing Photo Locations

sources.snippet: The Ringstrasse is a circular road around the inner city of Vienna. Along this road are numerous historical buildings, including the Parliament, Hofburg, State Opera, City Hall, University of Vienna, Votivkirche, Art History, and Natural History Museum. The street has a length of 5.3 kilometers and should definitely be on your Vienna itinerary.
sources.shortName: The best photo spots in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Former summer residence of the royal family with vast gardens & tours, now a UNESCO site.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Schönbrunn Palace Park, the former summer residence of the royal family, is a UNESCO site and an essential part of Vienna's cultural heritage. The Baroque-style gardens surrounding the magnificent palace feature well-kept lawns, intricate flower beds, and elegant fountains.

reviews.reviewText: Even if you're not planning on going inside the palace, a trip to the gardens is definitely a MUST in Vienna. You can easily spend hours and hours walking around this massive complex while savouring some of the best views you'll ever see. Vienna is a charming city and this place proves why!

Schönbrunn Palace Park is absolutely stunning and definitely worth a visit. The park is huge and offers plenty of space to walk, relax, and enjoy nature. Every corner is beautifully maintained, with impressive gardens, fountains, and lovely views. It’s a perfect place for taking photos — the surroundings are truly majestic and picturesque. Whether you’re exploring the tree-lined paths or admiring the palace from the Gloriette, you’ll feel the charm and grandeur of the place. A must-see in Vienna!

best part about it is that the main, huge part of the park is completely free to enter, so you don't even have to buy a palace ticket to get a taste of the imperial life.
​it's massive, so plan to do a lot of walking. you've got the perfectly manicured great parterre right in front of the palace, with all the statues and fountains. it's so symmetrical and fancy, you feel like you're in a period drama. then there are the less formal parts of the park, with big trees and winding paths. you'll see locals jogging, families with kids, and tourists like me just trying to take it all in.
​a big must-do is the walk up to the gloriette. it's a bit of a climb up a gentle hill, but the view is just... chef's kiss. you look down on the whole palace and the city beyond it. it's a great photo spot and there's even a cafe up there if you need a little reward for your effort.
​there are also a few smaller, special areas you can pay to enter, like the maze, which is fun for a quick break from all the history, and the privy garden, which is a more secluded, ornate part of the garden. and of course, the zoo is also on the grounds and is a whole attraction in itself.
​it's a perfect mix of formal beauty and natural space. you can easily spend an entire afternoon here, getting lost in the paths and just enjoying the scenery
The garden is huge and only some limited part are worth the time, energy and money but the zoo is an absolute gem. We spent very enjoyable 5-6 hours in the zoo which wouldn’t ever regret.

Probably the most beautiful royal residence park in the world. Unbelievably green and clean, gardens are well maintained and everything falls into astounding order! You could walk on those alleys for the whole day and still not get bored. Definitely recommend spending at least couple of hours here and see a different colors as the sun rises/sets! There is a dedicated car-train with designated stops if you don't feel like walking much.

A beautiful and peaceful park with stunning landscaping and well-maintained paths. The combination of nature and historical architecture creates a unique atmosphere. Perfect for a relaxing walk, enjoying the views, or just sitting by the fountains.👌🏻

Stunning! Well worth a visit, we didn't pay for any sights this time but still had plenty to see and do. Welcome ice cream and drinks carts dotted round the grounds and absolutely beautiful buildings and gardens!

It is a very beautiful place, an amazing park and great buildings, and the palace as well.
To visit all locations you need a minimum of one day or even two.
The park is free, but there are a lot of interesting places for tickets.

placeMetadata.name: Vienna City Hall

sources.shortName: 21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: Vienna’s City Hall (Weiner Rathaus) is one of the most monumental buildings in Vienna and the actual seat of the local government. This Neo-Gothic building features five towers including the central tower with a height of 98 meters!. Photo tip: every winter, you can enjoy a beautiful Christmas market in front of the Weiner Rathaus.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Taking pictures of it isn’t really the easiest as there is almost always an event or something going on in front of it.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Massive municipal building built using some 30 million bricks & now hosting balls, markets & events.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Vienna City Hall, also known as Rathaus, is a massive municipal building constructed with around 30 million bricks. It hosts various events such as balls and markets. The 19th-century neo-Gothic tower of the Rathaus stands at an impressive height of 103 meters, making it a prominent feature in Vienna's skyline. The building houses government offices, a city library, and over 1500 rooms.

reviews.reviewText: Vienna City Hall (Rathaus) becomes pure magic during Christmas! The grand façade, already beautiful, is transformed with lights and decorations that make it feel like a winter fairy tale. The famous Rathausplatz Christmas Market adds to the charm, with dozens of stalls offering handcrafted gifts, mulled wine, and delicious treats. The ice skating rink and carousel create a cozy, festive atmosphere perfect for families and couples. Even if you’ve seen other Christmas markets, this one feels special with the stunning backdrop of the City Hall. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Vienna during the holidays!
