We visited the City Hall during the Christmas market, and it was one of the most wonderful Christmas markets we’ve ever experienced. The atmosphere was colorful and lively, filled with festive energy.

There were plenty of food stalls offering a variety of delicious treats, along with charming craft shops showcasing unique handmade items. It truly created a magical and memorable experience, a perfect way to enjoy the holiday spirit.

We visited during New Year's Eve and it truly was like a fairy tale land. Everything was meticulously made. Prices were about the same everywhere in the city. There were many areas and options for all ages.

Vienna City Hall, or the Wiener Rathaus, is a stunning Neo-Gothic building that serves as the seat of the local government. Its tall spire and detailed façade make it one of the most iconic landmarks in Vienna.

When I visited, I only saw it from the outside, but it was during the winter season, and the square in front of the City Hall was transformed into an impressive ice skating rink. It wasn’t just any rink—it was large, beautifully set up, and full of lively energy. Definitely a great spot to visit, even if just to enjoy the festive atmosphere around this magnificent building!

This neoclassical building represents the city of Vienna in such an authentic way; it makes you realize you are in the city where classicism rules over modernism.
Hosting local events, markets, shops and much more; this city hall is like no other.
Surrounded by so many more Viennese treasures, you really shouldn't miss the opportunity to see this masterpiece.

I call it the HEART of AUSTRIAN 🇦🇹 culture. From the different Balls to wining,  dinning and dancing 💃🏽……..it’s always a great time in there. Visit Vienna & check out on the different events that happen in Vienna’s City Hall

Vienna city hall is the town hall of Vienna, Austria, located in the Innere Stadt on the Rathausplatz, off the Ringstrasse. The Gothic Revival building was designed by Friedrich von Schmidt and constructed between 1872 and 1883. It houses the offices of the Mayor of Vienna, as well as the city and state government. It one of most interesting thing in Vienna and one of most beautiful building in Europe

This Neo-Gothic City Hall must be the most beautiful city hall I have ever seen anywhere.  The building is outstandingly intricate and looms over a garden where during Christmas time they hold a Christmas Market for the joy of Viennese people and tourists alike.

placeMetadata.name: MuseumsQuartier Wien

sources.snippet: The MuseumsQuartier is a sprawling cultural complex that houses some of Vienna’s most prestigious museums and galleries. The striking architecture of the Leopold Museum and the MUMOK (Museum of Modern Art) offers numerous opportunities for visually compelling photographs. As you wander the courtyard, keep an eye out for the cheeky, oversized sculptures that add a touch of humor and playfulness to the scene.
sources.shortName: Vienna Photography Spots: Unraveling the Elegance of the Imperial City

sources.snippet: The MuseumsQuartier is a unique blend of art, culture, and architecture and an essential destination when visiting Vienna. Whether you’re an art lover, architecture enthusiast, or just looking for an entertaining day out, you can find something that interests you in the MuseumsQuartier.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Vienna

sources.snippet: Tip: Good viewpoints at this location include going up the steps at either side for some higher perspectives. I’d say MuseumsQuartier makes for better photography at night.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Restored area of historic & modern buildings containing many of the city's finest museums.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: MuseumsQuartier Wien, also known as MQ, is a captivating blend of historic and contemporary architecture housing some of the city's most impressive museums. The complex, once the Imperial Court Stables designed by Fischer von Erlach, now showcases thousands of 20th and 21st-century masterpieces.

reviews.reviewText:
Museum of Vienna. Really nice place to visit.

The staff are also nice, the toilets are clean and they have a lot of exhibitions inside, must see.
I was there briefly, just to walk around that plaza. I felt that the place has so much history and tradition that I need to visit it again and spend more time going to all the museums.

Amazing cultural spot in Vienna with world-class museums, modern art, and lots of space to relax. Great mix of history, design, and vibrant atmosphere—perfect for both art lovers and just hanging out.
Definitely a must to see in Vienna. Wonderful architecture, very rich in culture and art. Lots to do and to see there. You may need more than a full day to visit all museums and exhibitions.
Must see. Free entrance for all up to 19yrs. Others pay 18€. It is reasonable, and of course the architecture is amazing. I hope you enjoy it. Paid parking 4.50/hr in the garage below.
Such a beautiful creative space with galleries, cafes and bars all in one place! A must visit and more than once!

This is such a cool and creative space, totally different vibe from the older, classic museums nearby, but in the best way. It’s this awesome mix of art, design, and chill hangout spots. The buildings themselves are a blend of old and modern, which gives it a really unique character. You can explore contemporary museums like Leopold or MUMOK, or just relax in the courtyard with a coffee and people watch. It feels young, artsy, and full of energy, but still very Viennese.
Realky interesed to learn about the Vienna Secession movement, started in 1897, and the artists that broke away to be instrumental in the "Art Nouveau" - including Gustav Klimt! Visit - its a treat!

placeMetadata.name: Café Sacher Wien

sources.snippet: Take a break from the historic monuments and lush green spaces and visit one of the best Instagram spots in Vienna where you can sit down and nibble on a slab of the city’s famous dessert. Café Sacher is the home of the Original Sacher-Torte, a delectable chocolate sponge cake served with a dollop of whipped cream and a coffee of your choosing. Besides the cake itself, the cafe setting is highly photogenic with its red velvet booths, vintage chandeliers, and old-world charm.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Café Sacher is not just a café; it’s a Viennese institution that has been serving up decadent desserts and coffee for over a century. Located in the heart of Vienna, it’s a must-visit for anyone exploring the city’s culinary delights. The star of the show at Café Sacher is undoubtedly the Sachertorte, a legendary chocolate cake created by Franz Sacher in 1832.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones

sources.snippet: If not, you are missing the yummy cake that all the world envy Vienna. Café Sacher Wien is the original place where this cake was made at first. Despite being a common touristy place, the old café is gorgeous and worth an Instagram spot in Vienna.
sources.shortName: 20 Unbelievable Vienna Instagram Spots Worth A Visit

placeMetadata.description: Corner bar with views of shopping street, serving drinks & snacks including the house Sacher-Torte.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Café Sacher Wien is a quintessential Austrian café located in the heart of Vienna, offering a typical Viennese coffee-house atmosphere and the opportunity to indulge in an Original Sacher-Torte. The café boasts a rich history, situated near Vienna's opulent opera house and adorned with elegant décor. Its signature dessert, the Sacher Torte, is a decadent dark-chocolate cake with a layer of tangy apricot jam, served with whipped cream.

reviews.reviewText:
Went there expecting a tourist trap (one of the tourist traps you should fall into anyways if you visit Vienna). The cake was excellent though and so was the coffee. We enjoyed the atmosphere and they offered great service.

I also loved the fact that even though it was a Saturday evening and they were quite busy, they never rushes us out of the cafe once we finished our cake. This is something you don't see in North America...

No complaints really other than their rather high price but that was expected given the popularity and location of this cafe.

I visited this café twice within five hours on the same day and had two completely different experiences.

1) The first time, I went alone around 4 p.m. — I was greeted by an extremely courteous gentleman who seated me quickly. The atmosphere on the second floor was very pleasant and authentic. I had a slice of Sachertorte — it was delicious and moist. At one point, a waitress accidentally knocked over my water bottle, which fell onto the plate and broke it (there was still about a third of the cake left). The girl apologized and offered to bring me a new slice, but I declined — accidents happen. I had already eaten enough, and overall, everything was wonderful.

2) The second time was around 8:30–9 p.m. with my husband and a friend. This time, we were greeted by a very rude lady who didn’t seem interested in talking to us at all. I understand it was the end of the day, and a lot of tourists pass through, but it was still working hours — being polite is part of the job. After I had told the guys about the delicious cake I had earlier, they decided to order a slice as well. Unfortunately, their pieces were nothing alike — they were dry, oddly flavored, and seemed like they were a few days old. They were quite disappointed.

I must admit, though, that despite the mixed experience, I ended up buying a whole Sachertorte, some chocolate bars, and a fudge from their shop afterward — and all three were divine, far more delicious and moist than the cakes served in the café.

came here early in the morning when there were hardly any other customers. The environment was quiet and peaceful, and the staff were very professional. I ordered their famous cake—it was on the sweeter side, but paired perfectly with the fresh whipped cream! Sitting by the window, enjoying the street view while having cake and coffee was such a soothing way to start the day.

The cafe is in the heart of the city, so its location is excellent.
You usually have to wait outside to be seated even if there are empty tables.
We tried the original Sacher cake and the fudge one, and to be honest they were good but didn't meet my expectations, I expected something very unique, but I've had better.

The seating and decor are really nice, and the place has a great vibe. One of its advantages is the large number of tables, which makes it easier to find a spot despite the long line at the entrance. It’s well-known for its chocolate cake, but honestly, I found it pretty average — a bit overrated in my opinion. The coffee was just okay, nothing special. Service was somewhat slow, and the prices are on the higher side.

The atmosphere is top!
I’ll definitely come back. Everyone orders the Sachertorte here, but I’m not a big fan of that dessert. The cottage cheese strudel was absolutely top!

It is a beautifully decorated place with a great history. You really feel special when you enter the Cafe. The interior looks like a room of a castle and I felt like a princess from many years ago. And the staff was approachable and nice, too. It is really delightful and I can understand the hype, but there is too many people. My friends and I waited for more than one hour in the line. We tried the Sacher cake and we all agreed that it was a bit dry. We also tried multiple different coffees. Some of them were really good, but not the ice cream one. The ice cream totally melted before even coming to us. I think the Cafe is worth visiting, but a bit overpriced also (price of the cake is okay, but coffee prices are a bit much). Nevertheless, it was a nice experience with lovely views.

The staff members are racist.
We waited outside before opening, but upon entering, the two Asian groups ahead of us were seated on the 2nd floor Even though the 1st floor was empty. Taking orders was sloppy, and the servers just slammed the dishes down on the table without a care. It was obvious the cakes and drinks had been thrown together carelessly. And that female server clearly looked down on Asians.

The real shock came at checkout. The man who’d seated us asked if 10% was okay, then selected the 10% tip option on the card machine himself with his finger before handing it over. Do they think we’re pushovers because we’re clueless tourists? lol This is the first time I’ve ever had a server choose the tip percentage for me.

Why is this place still so popular when the food is tasteless and the service is the worst?
If you’re in Vienna and trying Sachertorte, absolutely skip this spot and go to the other historic one instead:)

placeMetadata.name: Graben

sources.snippet: Probably the most famous street in all of Vienna is Graben, a pedestrian boulevard right in the heart of the city. Photo opportunities here abound, from glimpses of St. Stephen’s Cathedral up one end to the fountains and elaborate Plague Column that line it. Graben is a particularly special spot come Christmastime when large chandelier-shaped lights are strung up overhead.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Photography Spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: Located in Vienna’s First District, Graben is one of the most famous streets in the city center of Vienna. It is a historic boulevard that has been at the center of Vienna’s social and commercial life for centuries. As you walk down Graben, you will be surrounded by architectural wonders that date back to the Habsburg era.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones
21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Roman-era walking street known for its bustling retail activity & ornate historic buildings.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Graben, an ancient street in the heart of a historic city, dates back to Roman times when it served as a defensive ditch for the Vindobona military camp. Over time, it transformed into a bustling marketplace and residential area. Notable figures like Mozart once called this street home. Today, Graben is known for its vibrant retail scene and ornate historic buildings. Visitors can explore nearby attractions such as Am Hof square and St.

reviews.reviewText: The Graben Vienna is an exclusive and pulsating shopping street in the heart of the inner city with a plague column. There's so many hot spots and tourist areas around here, renowned restaurants, and many stores and historic places.
Graben is super busy but has everything you need—shops, cafes, and that lively city vibe! A must-visit spot for shopping lovers.
First time in Vienna, very impressive but the place very crowded
As an id specialist, this monument was a must-see on my list. The whole street is beautiful—definitely worth visiting more than once.

Such a lovely, lively and posh street right in the heart of Vienna. The buildings are absolutely beautiful - stunning architecture everywhere you look. The street is lined with high-end shops like Burberry, Louis Vuitton, Rolex, and Prada, and the Louis Vuitton building in particular is especially gorgeous.
When we visited, there was live street music playing, which really added to the atmosphere and made the whole experience even more enjoyable.
It’s the perfect place to stroll, take in the sights, do a bit of shopping, or simply relax at a café. And it’s just a short walk from St. Stephen’s Cathedral, so it fits easily into a day of exploring central Vienna.
As busy as it can get in Vienna!
The most famous street you can visit in Vienna, close to many historical landmarks and filled with international brand shops but also authentic austrian markets too.
A very beautiful place with distinctive and international shops.

placeMetadata.name: Palm House

sources.snippet: Located just along the street from the Albertina Museum, the Palm House is perfect for those looking for Vienna Instagram spots – or just a good cup of coffee!. Not to be confused with the Palm House at Schönbrunn Palace, this gorgeous building was constructed as a – yup, you guessed it – palm house for the Imperial family, where they could get out of any dreary Austrian weather, and go for a stroll among tropical flora. It wasn’t limited to palm trees, but a multitude of hanging vines and potted greenery… and now, you can go in and eat some brunch in the middle of it all!
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

sources.snippet: If you’re a plant lover, you’ll truly feel like heaven in this place!. The Palm House is the largest greenhouse in all of Austria and it’s located inside the Schönbrunn gardens so you can easily visit it while touring the gardens. The house is divided into three pavilions and each of them houses numerous tropical, subtropical, and Mediterranean plants.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: The Palm House or Palmenhaus is a giant greenhouse located inside Schonbrunn Park. You can visit it, but it’s actually due to its exterior that it made this list along with other Vienna photo spots. How to get here: same as for Schonbrunn Palace.
sources.shortName: Vienna Instagram Spots: 15 Amazing Photo Locations

placeMetadata.description: Established in 1882, this huge, airy greenhouse with 3 pavilions showcases many exotic plants.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled within the enchanting gardens of Schönbrunn Palace, the Großes Palmenhaus Schönbrunn stands as a testament to botanical beauty and architectural grandeur. Established in 1882, this impressive greenhouse spans an astonishing 111 meters, making it not only Austria's largest but also one of the most significant greenhouses globally. With its three distinct pavilions, visitors can explore a diverse array of tropical, subtropical, and Mediterranean plants that thrive in this temperature-controlled haven.

reviews.reviewText:
Located at Schonbrunn Palace Park, 1130 Vienna, Austria 🇦🇹.
I highly recommend purchasing tickets online before going to avoid the long waiting times. Admission is fixed admission times. We paid for the Grand Tour which included an audio guide. I liked this as I could go at my own pace. We explored the entire piano nobile of the palace: in addition to the private apartments of Franz Joseph and Elisabeth, the south-facing reception rooms and the State Apartments. We also got to see the rooms occupied by Maria Theresa. It was fantastic. This cost €32.00 which I think was quite reasonable. Children are €23.00. There’s also the Imperial Tour which cost €27.00 for adults and €19.00 for children. This also includes audio guide. There’s other tours available on the website.
One hundred and thirteen metres long, the Palm House consists of a 28-metre high central pavilion and two lateral pavilions which are three metres lower. Linked by tunnel-like passages, the pavilions contain different climatic zones: a ‘cold’ house to the north, a temperate zone in the central pavilion and a tropical zone in the south pavilion. The building itself is work of art, simply beautiful and inside is magnificent, so lovely to just explore and take in the beauty of all the stunning greenery. After exploring everything including the gardens, the palace etc we were there for practically the whole day. We took our time exploring. We had lunch at one of the cafes that is there, the food was delicious. There’s a large selection of places to choose from. We did a lot of walking and I definitely recommend wearing comfortable shoes. Overall, the Palm House was amazing, I truly loved it. Would definitely recommend. Thumbs up!!! 👍👍👍

If you enjoy the company of plants in everyday life this is a must visit in Vienna.
Huge glass and steel structure itself seen from the outside invites you to explore it inside. For me, it was definitely worth it.
Exotic plants from remote parts of the world, some of them reaching the ceiling of the glass house provokes admiration.
There are a couple of spots where you can sit on white benches and just observe and listen the sounds of tropical forest.
Too bad that the stairs to the gallery were closed, therefore I give it 4/5 star review.

The Palmenhaus at Schönbrunn is stunning. A huge historic glasshouse filled with exotic plants, tropical palms, and rare flowers. The architecture alone is worth the visit, and walking inside feels like stepping into another world.

Beautiful greenhouse complex with an ongoing  exhibition about giant Victoria Amazonia water lilies—I thought the lilies would be in a bigger pond, but still enjoyed experiencing these lovely flowers. The lady at the ticketing counter is also very patient and helpful. Thank you!

The Palmenhaus is absolutely stunning and was one of our favorite parts of Schönbrunn. From the outside it looks like a grand glass cathedral, but stepping inside feels like entering a different world. Towering palms, exotic plants, and the humid air make it feel almost dreamlike, and the structure itself is a work of art with its elegant iron and glass design. It’s easy to lose track of time wandering through the different sections, spotting plants you’ve never seen before and soaking in the atmosphere. Well worth the ticket, and a perfect escape if you want something a little quieter and more magical than the busy palace grounds.

An absolute architectural masterpiece and one of the most magnificent greenhouses in the world! Stepping inside the Palmenhaus is like being instantly transported to a lush, tropical rainforest. The scale is awe-inspiring – the soaring cast-iron and glass structure houses towering palm trees, exotic plants, and a serene atmosphere that feels worlds away from Vienna.

It’s not just a collection of plants; it's a beautifully curated ecosystem with winding paths, little bridges, and even a small café to sit and soak it all in. The perfect escape for a rainy day or when you need a warm, green retreat. A true jewel of Schönbrunn.

Pro Tip: Look up! The architecture of the greenhouse itself is a work of art. And don't miss the butterfly house if it's open.

Palm house is a gigantic, yet elegant and stately  greenhouse encompassing 3 pavillions. It was established back in 1882. Was thrilled to see vanilla bean flower and experience its exotic, rich and abundant smell.  Arabica coffee plant was a very educational experience. Resident biologist (?) of the greenhouse was very friendly and happily answered my kids multiple questions. Overall, the Palm House is very family-oriented and kid-friendly facility.

This is a must-see in Vienna if, like us, you love botanical gardens and parks.
Of course, if you visit Schönbrunn Palace, one of the top three places to see in Vienna, you absolutely must visit the Palmenhaus.
One could say it's expensive, too humid and unpleasant inside, or that the selection of plants isn't up to our expectations...
I nevertheless highly recommend you go and visit it.
Of course, as always, it's best to buy your tickets online to choose the time that suits you and avoid the endless lines: it's better to enjoy the magnificent plants than to wait in the endless queues.
Have fun and take many photos!

placeMetadata.name: Volksgarten

sources.snippet: The Ringstrasse is a circular road around the inner city of Vienna. Along this road are numerous historical buildings, including the Parliament, Hofburg, State Opera, City Hall, University of Vienna, Votivkirche, Art History, and Natural History Museum. The street has a length of 5.3 kilometers and should definitely be on your Vienna itinerary.
sources.shortName: The best photo spots in Vienna

sources.snippet: Volksgarten (“Folks’ Park”) is a public park most famous for its incredible rose garden that has over 3,000 rose bushes of different varieties. My tip is to go there early to be able to take photos of the flower beds without any people in them. June, in particular, is a very good month to see the flowers in all their glory and colors.
sources.shortName: Vienna Instagram Spots: 15 Amazing Photo Locations

sources.snippet: This beautiful park is a blooming oasis in Vienna’s city center. It was built over the city fortifications that Napoleon destroyed in 1809 and is part of the Hofburg Palace. At its center you’ll find the shining white Theseus Temple which is a replica of a Greek temple.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Strauss & Lanner once played in this manicured public park with temples, fountains & rose gardens.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the heart of Vienna, the Volksgarten is a stunning public park that beautifully marries history and leisure. Originally designed as a private garden for archdukes, it has welcomed visitors since 1825 and is now part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site Historic Center of Vienna. The park features manicured landscapes adorned with temples, fountains, and vibrant rose gardens.

reviews.reviewText:
One of the most beautiful and peaceful parks in Vienna.
Whichever time of the day,  this is the perfect place to take a break and enjoy the so many roses growing here.
Just take a look at these pictures.

An impressively lovely gardens right along the inner city of Vienna. Everything is precise, orderly and beautiful.

There’s a section where rose bushes are donated by people and it makes for a colorful pop along the walking path.

We came on a rainy day but this would be a lovely spot to sit and spend more time when the weather is better. I loved how precise everything was set up here, the grounds are very well attended to and cared for.

It is one of the must visit place I stayed there for almost two hours.It was a really good place to relax.There are places to sit and enjoy beautiful greenery all around, the fountain and statues looked great, and the nearby monuments were truly mesmerizing.

Large garden with lots of roses. Water mists on to cool down tourists under the strong sun. Bathed in sunlight on the bench, my eyes linger on roses in full bloom, while heavy music roars from the club — a strange harmony of beauty and chaos
Perfect place during the spring season. Flowers are in bloom and they smell really good. It gets crowded a bit so better to visit early. Park is free, with lots of benches.

We went during the winter. I really wanted to like the garden but it just does not look as good as expected. But I’m sure it should look better in spring/summer when all the grass are green and the flowers are blooming.
Nice little park with a lot of sitting place right in the centre of Vienna. It's especially beautiful in May and June when the roses are blooming. It's usually crowded, too.

a little bit of nature is a nice change of pace. volksgarten is a public park right in the middle of everything, between the hofburg palace and the parliament building, but it feels like a little oasis. the main attraction for me was the rose garden. there are thousands of rose bushes with all different kinds of colors and scents. if you're there in late spring or early summer, when they're all in bloom, it's just magical. it's the kind of place where you just want to sit on a bench, breathe in the air, and watch the world go by.
​besides the roses, there are a few cool things to see. there's the theseus temple, which looks like a mini greek temple, and it's kind of a funny contrast to the ornate imperial buildings around it. and if you're a fan of empress sissi, there's a beautiful memorial to her in a quiet corner of the park. it's a really peaceful spot.
​the best part is that it's completely free to enter. it's the perfect place to take a break from sightseeing. it’s open from early in the morning until late at night, so you can easily pop in whenever you're in the area

placeMetadata.name: University of Vienna

sources.shortName: 21 Incredibly Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: Speaking of beautiful buildings in Vienna, I absolutely have to mention the University of Vienna. Don’t be afraid to go inside and take a look at the beautiful architecture, it’s open to the public and definitely worth stopping by – especially on a cold winter day.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: At the University of Vienna there are a few magnificent staircases and corridors which make for great photographs. To find the staircases after you’ve walked through the main entrance and past reception, take the corridors either right or left.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

placeMetadata.description: Public teaching & research institution, founded in 1365, with a campus & about 92,000 students.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The University of Vienna is a historically important university with a beautiful campus. It's perfect for taking photos inside the building and in the inner yard.

reviews.reviewText: Absolutely fantastic campus. Diverse and unbelievable legacy. It's white wing design was put together by Azerbajani architect, who definitely gave its mega scale and space.

One of the most remarkable aspects of the University of Vienna is its association with numerous Nobel laureates. Over the years, many scholars connected to the university have been awarded Nobel Prizes in fields such as Physics, Chemistry, Medicine, and Literature. This highlights the university’s long-standing commitment to groundbreaking research and academic achievement. The institution continues to attract top researchers and students from all over the world, maintaining its reputation as a leading center for higher education and scientific discovery.
Beautiful building, however if you want to visit, you can go on a guided tour only. For english it's only on Saturday 1130am and public holidays on request. Rest day it's in German.
University of Vienna has a long history.There used to be a lot of masters.Now the campus is full of vitality.I saw a lot of beautiful girls.
Lovely place to visit when you're in Vienna, free entry of course and beautiful architecture. A must-see place to stop by, if you're going to opera, state museum or hofburg - it's on the same street!

Great university in Vienna, whilst walking and feels a call of nature, just go inside the university’s toilet. I’ve seen a diverse group of students , international students. I felt relieved 🙏🏽 thank you university admin

I only visited for a couple of minutes while touring the city. Lovely building!
There’s a U-Bahn right next to the university, and right there are lot of shops that sell all sort of stuff. Will make a good break spot in between classes.
Guided tours available on select days in different languages for 5 euros. Pl check and go

placeMetadata.name: Lower Belvedere

sources.snippet: It is divided into two magnificent palaces: the Upper Belvedere and the Lower Belvedere, both of which are surrounded by stunning gardens and decorated with fascinating sculptures. The palace is conveniently located in Vienna’s city center, making it easily accessible by public transport or a leisurely walk. The Upper Belvedere houses a treasure trove of Austrian art ranging from the Middle Ages to the present day, including the world’s largest collection of Gustav Klimt’s masterpieces.
sources.shortName: Discover the Best & Most Wonderful Ones

sources.snippet: The Belvedere, one of Vienna’s most popular attractions, is a building complex consisting of two Baroque palaces; the Lower (Unteres) and the Upper (Oberes) Belvedere. This palace complex was built as a summer residence for Prince Eugene of Savoy. Located in the middle of a gorgeous Baroque park, with fountains and sculptures, the Belvedere is a very famous Instagram spot in Vienna.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Two majestic baroque palaces comprise the Belvedere Museum, a must-see for all Klimt pilgrims as it houses his iconic The Kiss. While the museum itself is a gem, the French-style gardens that connect the upper and lower palaces are particularly spectacular. Fountains, waterfalls, sculptures, colorful flora and sculpted hedges comprise the UNESCO World Heritage site.
sources.shortName: 11 of the most Instagrammable places in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Lower Belvedere is part of the stunning baroque complex that also includes Upper Belvedere, connected by a beautiful garden. It houses Gustav Klimt's renowned masterpiece, The Kiss, and features an extensive art collection spanning from the Middle Ages to contemporary pieces. Visitors can enjoy diverse exhibitions such as the impactful Dali - Freud showcase and thought-provoking modern tree exhibition.

reviews.reviewText: After the palace, we walked through the garden and found that there is another museum as we didn’t know there was another one. But we were this went in and it turned out to be a very cool museum with some rather unconventional work.

Lower Belvedere in Vienna is a charming spot that offers a lovely, more intimate experience compared to its grander counterpart, Upper Belvedere. The palace features beautifully preserved Baroque architecture, and the interiors are quite elegant. Highlights include the Marble Hall, the Golden Room, and the Hall of Grotesques, each with intricate designs and a rich history. The palace also hosts special exhibitions, adding a bit of variety to the visit. The surrounding gardens are peaceful and perfect for a stroll. While it may not have the extensive collection of its bigger sibling, it's definitely a worthwhile stop for anyone interested in Austrian art and Baroque architecture. Overall, a solid four-star experience!

Although it's smaller than the Upper Belvedere, my visit was incredibly rewarding and fulfilling. There was a special exhibition centered around the works of Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele, which exceeded all my expectations.

Seeing famous works like Klimt's "Water Serpents I" and "Judith" up close was a truly moving experience. The exhibition also offered a deep dive into Egon Schiele's artistic world through his various drawings and paintings.

What impressed me most was the feeling of these vibrant and revolutionary artworks breathing new life into a historic palace. There was a wonderful sense of the past being re-energized and revitalized, which I found truly fantastic.

The compact size of the exhibition space is actually a plus, as it allows you to appreciate each piece deeply without feeling rushed. I highly recommend it for anyone interested in Viennese Modernism!!

Nice museum, visited the interesting exhibition here on the reconstruction of lost Klimt masterpieces. The huge paintings had been commissioned for the ceiling of the main hall of the University of Vienna, but they were considered pornograhic and grotesque, and Klimt sold them to a private collector instead. In 1945 they were destroyed when retreating nazis set fire to the building they were housed in. Google helped to reconstruct the colours on the basis of old black and white photos.

The museum itself is much smaller than the Upper Belvedere. There was also a collection of medieval art
Beautiful exhibitions going on at the moment. Ranging from Medieval art to Modernism. The Klimt one is a must see.

Book this online in advance and include the Upper Belvedere for a full afternoon of art. There are special exhibits here but the exhibit on Klimt's painting techniques, which includes several of the collection's paintings, is really worth the price of entry.
2025 jun. Now the building from one side is renovating, all fountains not working, there is no flowers... beautiful, but a bit disappointed.
Beautiful spot but the museum is over priced 🤔

placeMetadata.name: Rathaus

sources.snippet: Located in the central district of Innere Stadt, the Rathaus is an impressive building that serves as Vienna’s city hall. It one of the most visited tourist attractions in Vienna — and for good reason!. Between its grandiose architecture, historical significance, and the tower’s panoramic views, the Rathaus has a lot to offer.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Vienna

sources.snippet: It is located in the very center of Vienna and is presented as a Gothic building, in which the meetings of the parliament and the municipality are held to this day.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Instagrammable Spots in Vienna | Europe Famous Hostels

sources.snippet: Whenever I post a picture of Vienna’s town hall on my Instagram, I always receive at least one comment comment like “what a beautiful castle!
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rathaus, located on Rathausplatz in Vienna, is a stunning Neo-Gothic building constructed in the 1800s to house the mayor's offices due to the city's growing population. Resembling Brussels' town hall, it boasts five towers with an iconic Rathausman statue crowning the largest one. The Christmas markets adorn it with beautiful lights and decorations. Its gothic architecture and intricate details make it a must-see in Vienna.

reviews.reviewText: The City Hall is definitely the most impressive building in Vienna! Amazing gothic architecture, attention to details at its best.
Great tram stop to utilize the city's incredible public transit system. Not on the main avenue but rather on a quieter inner street which I really appreciated.
Beautiful architecture from outside!
Beautiful Christmas decoration and hot punch :)
Always Vienna is a good destination.
The best ice scating ever
Very beautiful

(Translated by Google) Stupendous. During the Christmas markets it is full of lights and beautiful decorations. Marvelous

(Original)
Stupendo. In occasione dei mercatini di Natale è pieno di luci, addobbi bellissimi. Meraviglioso

sources.snippet: The State Hall of the Austrian National Library is one of the most unique spots in Vienna. As one of the less popular tourist attractions, only a few people discover the library’s huge bookshelves and stunning ceiling murals!. It has become a must for some of the best travel content creators.I recommend getting there right when it opens to have the highest chance of getting your shot without people walking in the background.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

sources.snippet: The State Hall of the Austrian National Library is a Baroque masterpiece brimming with statues, antique Venetian globes, frescoes, and over 200,000 books. As with the Palace of Justice, this is one of the hidden gems in the city so you can create some truly unique content here. The State Hall is one of the best Vienna Instagram spots for capturing the spirit of the Age of Enlightenment – with a modern twist of course!
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Right next to the Hofburg is the State Hall, which is part of the Austrian National Library. We had seen pictures of this on a small flyer and were very enthusiastic, so we definitely wanted to look at the hall. The Vienna State Hall is rightly one of the most beautiful historical library halls in the world.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions, Things to do & Photo spots (Austria)

reviews.reviewText: Just like in the movies! It is a fantastic library with a relatively cheaper ticket than other museums (around €10, maybe even lower with discounts). It has a great atmosphere with frescoes on the ceiling, rare books from the Middle Ages and wooden bookcases! Great!

Breathtaking library! The grandeur and the beauty of this place is unique. We took our tickets once there and we didn’t wait at all! The tickets were 11 euros per person. Definitely a well spent money! Highly recommend it for everyone who is visiting Vienna.

Stunning externally and internally. Ornate lavish  baroque architecture, marble statues and columns, elaborate frescoes adorn the ceilings and walls, bookcases that reveal glimpses of rooms behind, and intriguing staircases leading to the unknown.

It's both fascinating and breathtaking just looking at the detail and the vast collection of historical literature on display.

In a building where it appears time has stood still, I love the  juxtaposition with the very interesting exhibition looking at  Austria's history from 1925 to the current day. A century in pictures'.

The State Hall is normally closed on a Monday. However, opening hours change from June, and I was fortunate to stop by on the 1st Monday in June.

Definitely worth a visit and the €11 entry fee.

This is a quite impressive library! Not sure if taking 10€ as an entry fee is a justified price tag, but you at least get to see a very impressive building from
The insight with like 200,000 books from the past. They will of course not let you touch any. But seeing them is impressive enough.

The most beautiful library that I can walk in(Other you can only see from afar). It should take you less than an hour to get through all but a lot of people there. I don't think there are limits on the number of people but I am not sure. I got the tickets in front. It is quiet in the center of all main attractions. If you have free time I would recommend visiting and on Thursday it opens at night too.
The Library itself is an awesome example of baroque architecture. There's also a picture gallery concerning the history of Austrian politics.

Beautiful library with history of Austria between 1925 and 2025.
Gorgeous paintings on the ceilings.
Impressive library all round.
Great exhibit of Austria from 1925 to 2025. There are 4 large really cool antique globes. Quiet, calming place as there is something about a beautiful room full of books.

placeMetadata.name: Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien

sources.snippet: The Kunsthistorisches Museum has an awesome foyer as you walk in with very pretty architecture. It also a beautiful cafe towards the top. When I was here they were preparing for an evening event so I didn’t manage to get a photo.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna (25 locations)

sources.snippet: The interior of the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna looks very impressive. If you would like to take an interesting picture on Instagram, you should visit this place.
sources.shortName: Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Imposing 19th-century museum with lavish interiors housing art collections & antiquities.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Museum of Art History in Vienna is an imposing 19th century building that houses a vast art collection including pieces by some of the world's most famous painters. The museum is located on the Ringstrasse, and visitors can explore its endless galleries filled with incredible masterpieces. Some of the most renowned artists in history are represented, including Caravaggio, Tintoretto, van Dyck, Raphael, Rembrandt, and Rubens.

reviews.reviewText: The museum itself is a treat to soaring eyes. The exteriors of the palace can be your historic backdrop of your wallpaper and the royal staircase leading to the art pieces is a statement of grandeur and style in itself. It’s a huge complex so do take out a minimum of 5 hours to experience the museum thoroughly. The cafe on the 3rd floor is usually filled with visitors as well as the photographers. One of the finest museums I ever visited.

The exhibitions were great (I came for the Tower of Babel), but the building's architecture was breathtaking. I have never seen anything similar in my life before. The level of details, the grandness, and the overall arrangements were all amazing.
They had a souvenir shop with some cool (albeit pricey) gifts as well.
If you're a student under 25, remember to mention so for a discounted ticket!

A stunning museum where the building itself is no less impressive than the masterpieces inside. The architecture, ceilings, and details are breathtaking – you could easily spend time just admiring the space before even looking at the collections.

Another highlight is the café right in the center of this magnificent hall. Having lunch surrounded by such art and architecture is a truly unique experience.

Definitely worth visiting not only for the collections but also for the atmosphere of the building itself.

World top five museum.   I have spend days in here and still have not had enough.

If you grew up in America in the 70s playing Masterpiece  you will recognize no fewer than 5 paintings here.   AMAZING!

Even if you don’t like the collection (weirdo!) it’s still worth visiting the Most Ornate Cafe on Earth under the rotunda.

The waiters there are divas that somehow see themselves as victims of an awful fate, failing to appreciate the extraordinary beauty of the room nor and the wonderful people flowing in from all over the world.

The cafe always has an unnecessary line.   You can only avoid it my arriving when the museum opens at 10AM.

Google made me edit this post because one photos partially showed the buttocks of a bronze statue.    That is absurd and completely unacceptable.

ANYTHING on display in a great museum is worthy of sharing .

超过想象的好。It completely exceeded my expectations. If you love oil paintings, don't miss this place. The works of masters like Bruegel and Raphael are lifelike. It's not crowded, so you can enjoy it quietly. I recommend going to the second floor of the cafe for viewing and taking photos.

A great selection of paintings, ancient objects, and precious gems. I would recommend viewing the highlights suggested by the Museum first then go to your favorite sections. Also, look out for Klimpt as you climb the stairs as it is easy to miss.

This museum has to be one of my favorites in the city.
The building itself is uniquely built and portrays a very artistic scene towards the eye that catches it.
The perfect house for the objects that live inside it; an example on how your surroundings can affect your presence.
A grand hall, with doors and hallways of your dreams. Every step you take is a step taken on art.
Each room and area the building houses is different from the previous one and it will make you feel like you have not walked enough so you do and then get lost through it's glamorous walls and flawless corners.
Every look you take, you picture different artists making their art; each with their own complexity and diversity.
All in the same building.
The exhibitions are all divided in different sections of the building and are very easy to navigate through.
Maps and audio guides are available too ,with great prices you indulge into this dreamland with your every sense.
Art here is inclusive; it has a bit ofeverything for everyone.
Austrian (authentic) together with other European pieces of art.
Ancient Greek and Roman tales and Egyptian origins all in one place.
A place better than heaven for art enthusiasts!
p.s This place also has other branches of local museums that house different exhibitions under it's name in different locations around Vienna.
The place is amazing. I thought it’s bigger, needed maybe 10 minutes to see it all and take all the pictures needed. As a tourist with few days in Vienna, you won’t miss anything if you skip it.

placeMetadata.name: Rathausplatz

sources.snippet: Rathausplatz is another public square within the Innere Stadt and is where you will find the Rathaus, the seat of local government. This massive Neo-Gothic hall dominates the square and providing that you arrive early enough you should find a variety of angles to get creative with your images. The square connects to the Rathauspark where you will find landscaped gardens and leafy avenues further adding to one of the most Instagrammable places in Vienna.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: For a more urban feel in your photos,  Rathausplatz is the perfect spot. The famous square has some interesting architecture and monuments that are great backdrops for any photo shoot. This spot is the most magical when it has Rathausplatz’s epic Christmas market, like when I visited!
sources.shortName: 15 Best Vienna Instagram spots

placeMetadata.description: 19th-century park with statues, mature trees & fountains, plus summer cinema & winter ice rink.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rathausplatz is a 19th-century park featuring statues, mature trees, and fountains. It offers various activities such as a summer cinema and a winter ice rink. Adjacent to the Vienna City Hall, this area is surrounded by significant landmarks including the Austrian Parliament Building, the main university, and the Neo-Gothic Votiv Church.

reviews.reviewText:
Wow, what a beautiful place! The building itself is stunning, and the best part was that there was a Film Festival 2025 happening when we visited. It really lit up the whole area – it felt like a fair!
They had installed a large screen right in front of the Rathaus building, and the atmosphere was incredible. There were so many food and drink stalls offering cuisine from different places. Aperol had its own little corner – their drinks were great too!
The area was so lively. We first went during the day and loved it so much that we went back again in the evening to enjoy the atmosphere. It was even more crowded in the evening, with so many people around. A musical movie was playing on the giant screen, and the whole place was buzzing with energy.

Such a great place for people to socialise. Various events take place here throughout the year. The town hall building is huge and very beautiful.
There are lots of eateries and bars here that you can enjoy.

A nice place to visit at night in Vienna. Film festival was held here June to end Aug, free entry. Lots of food stall and drinks at the courtyard, together with the music makes it like a carnival. Great place to socialise and appreciate Vienna at night.

Visited the Rathauplatz at 9pm on a Tuesday night in July and was overjoyed to discover a live televised performance of the Elizabeth musical that started at 21:00. The musical tells the dramatic and tragic story of Empress Elizabeth of Austria (known as Sisi). The tunes were beautiful, catchy and melodic; the actors' performance and costumes were simply outstanding.  What a treat on a balmy July night!

Historic site
Offers food options in the evening
Hosts movies, concerts for public
Has mobile restrooms
Is very safe
Is connected to public trams
A must visit site in Vienna’s 1st district
Go there with your friend during key moments - summer concerts, Christmas festivals, football games etc.

I always visit town halls in big cities. The architecture of these buildings are always admirable. In many bigger cities in Austria it is the most beautiful places, but Vienna is Vienna😎🇦🇹🇦🇹🇦🇹🇦🇹🇦🇹🇦🇹🇦🇹Too many beautiful places to visit😃Still one of them!!!👍🏻👀⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
A beautiful building surrounded by a great public space. Visited the other day and the screen was set up in front for a film festival, but we enjoyed the atmosphere with the food and drink vendors

Beautiful place, especially during summer with the film festival. Lots of food stalls ranging from korean to latin american food, drinks and cocktails and free seats to enjoy some films and concerts! Perfect summer night

placeMetadata.name: Stadtpark

sources.snippet: Stadtpark is a lush, green oasis in the heart of Vienna that seamlessly blends nature and history. The park’s winding paths, charming bridges, and tranquil ponds offer an idyllic setting for your photographs. Don’t miss the chance to snap a shot with the gilded Johann Strauss monument – it’s like having a personal serenade from the Waltz King himself!
sources.shortName: Vienna Photography Spots: Unraveling the Elegance of the Imperial City

sources.snippet: The Stadtpark was opened in 1862 as Vienna’s first public park. It has more monuments and sculptures than any other park in the city. The most famous one is the golden Johann Strauss memorial.
sources.shortName: The 10 Best Instagram and Photography Spots in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Stadtpark in Vienna is a picturesque spot, featuring the iconic golden Johann Strauss memorial and several other monuments and sculptures. It's known for being the richest park in Vienna for its collection of statues, including those of Franz Schubert, Franz Lehar, Robert Stolz, Hans Makart, Anton Bruckner, and Andreas Zelinka. Visitors can spend a leisurely day here feeding ducks by the pond or enjoying coffee from Espresso Mobil.

reviews.reviewText:
I really love this station, it's location is not the most useful, being relatively close to other better connected u-bahn stations. But it's setting is perfect, sitting just inside Stadtpark it feels urban and clean and open.

Otto Wagner's pavilion as an entry gate works perfectly in the setting.
Stumbled upon this park on my way to the theatre, it is beautiful, so calm yet lots of people just vibing

A beautiful park in Vienna, among many others!
Don't miss the golden statue of Johan Strauss, especially at sunset.

Cozy park for a nice stroll on a beautiful day. In summer the park comes to life with special events . Nice little ponds and beer gartens. Don't skip the opportunity for an apfelstrudel with icecream or a slice of sacher torte.
The only U-Bahn station that retains its original appearance.
Nice old school metro stop, and city park

While driving through in the subway - if you have the time - get out here and walk around the station. The combination of Wienfluss, Stadtpark and the stations historic architecture make for a great photo scenery ;)
Its a great experience to ride the metro here. It was in front of Inter Continental Wien.

placeMetadata.name: Burgtheater

sources.snippet: Similarly to the cathedrals, you’ll find amazing architecture by the Burgtheater. Located close to the Hofburg Palace and across the street from the Rathausplatz, you’ll find yourself taking great pictures here. The clean architecture makes a very easy backdrop and is perfect for that Vienna Instagram feed.
sources.shortName: The Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: Ultimate Photo Guide

sources.snippet: The Burgtheater is the National Theater of Austria and one of the most important German-language theaters in the world. Opened in 1741, it was destroyed in a bombing raid and a fire. After the war, the theater was rebuilt between 1953 and 1955 in the same neo-Baroque style.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Vienna: 20 Incredible Photo Locations

placeMetadata.description: Magnificent, statue-rich 1888 edifice with staircases painted by Gustav Klimt, vast stage & tours.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Burgtheater, also known as the Imperial Court Theater, is a grand 1888 building in Vienna with stunning staircases adorned with artwork by Gustav Klimt. Designed by architects Karl von Hasenauer and Gottfried Semper, it is part of the Viennese Imperial style and showcases Baroque influences with its elaborate columns and statues.

reviews.reviewText:
One of the prettiest buildings in Vienna.
Located near many more gems of this city, it stands for it own beauty and shines the spirit of the artists who built it; as the god of the light himself on top of it, Apollo depicts.

Sure its a beautiful building, but it does look a lot alike many other buildings in Vienna. In other words its nice but not remarkable. Chances are you won't remember much about it the day after you have visited it.

Had an outstanding experience inside. The theater is huge and beautiful (was actually my first time inside one such theatre in Europe). I went for Akram Khan Dance company’s Thikra. Had an IMAX level experience with the sound!

The architecture is amazing. The Klimt’s and other two artists’ paintings on the ceiling are gorgeous.
More importantly we had a very informative and generous tour all around the place. We visited the back stage, stage, rehearsal rooms and got lots of info about Viennese Theatre.

I recommend buying the 4€ standing ticket and then creep lower into a seat.
If available of course. The view is special, extra terrestrial, computer like, isometric as if playing an old school adventure game. As you don’t interact it starts quickly feeling like a dream of a let’s play without commentary. Still my neighbor with the binocular started sleeping after the first 15minutes.
Also they used a Saab convertible for the stage design. I mean a Saab!!!!!❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️so highly recommend if in Vienna. It is not really important what play you see.
I’ll go back tonight.

The Burgtheater was opened in 1741.
After the WWII, the theater was rebuilt between 1953 and 1955.

Just opposite City Hall, you can find the Imperial Court Theatre (Burgtheater). The theatre opened its doors in 1741 and has since been a focal point in Austrian culture.
To this day it is the most important German-language theatre and is known to locals simply as “die Burg”. No less than three of Mozart’s operas premiered here.

Was there one month ago for Radetzky March play. Got standing room tickets for 3.50 €/person, on their website. It went on for about 2 hours and it was totally worth it, even though we didn't understand anything as our German language skills are poor. Fantastic architecture, ornate interior design, and amazing performance. The crowd seemed very posh, the crème of Vienna, when we were there! You will be charged 1.50 € per person for holding your jackets inside. If you are in Vienna, I highly recommend it!

placeMetadata.name: Justizpalast

sources.snippet: Justizpalast or Palace of Justice is one of the most stunning places in Vienna, located on Schmerlingplatz, a square near the Ringstraße boulevard in the central district of Innere Stadt. The architecture of this building is amazing and if you want to see the view of the city from a different angle you can go to the rooftop café, the perfect place to share pictures with your friends over some delicious Café Viennois. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: 10 most Instagrammable places in Vienna

sources.snippet: It’s okay if you take 1-2 pictures, but you should be quiet and respectful (I hope that this is clear anyways).
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Photo Locations in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Stately 19th-century courthouse with statues & a grand atrium, plus a stylish rooftop restaurant.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Justizpalast is a beautiful and impressive courthouse located on Schmerlingplatz in the central district of Innere Stadt. It is well worth checking out for its stunning architecture, which is perfect for posing for pictures or enjoying the view from the rooftop cafe.

reviews.reviewText: A magnificent building with extraordinary architecture and craftsmanship. They allow entry in groups of 25 people every hour. You go through a very strict security check when entering, and liquids are not allowed inside. Entry is free of charge. In addition, there is a restaurant on the building’s terrace with a stunning view, but it only accepts cash payments.

Some people come in to ask why they are waiting so long, because they are waiting outside and there is a queue. Others come in without respect so that they don't have to wait in line anymore. Be careful that someone else doesn't enter in your place. Talk to them respectfully. Because only 25 people can enter. Otherwise you have to wait another hour. Security doesn't do their job by standing at the entrance by the door and asking: how can we help you? All three Security guards are inside and they don't know who respected the queue. And security only comes when they have to let 25 people in! And they don't know how to respect the queue!

Otherwise, very nice, but especially up at the cafe where there is a superb panorama! It's worth the wait and to visit!

You can eat, drink, it's big inside and outside on the terrace! Only the smell that greets you when you enter the cafe is bad! It seems that their kitchen doesn't work!!! So that tourists can stay in a pleasant smell! When you leave, you'll smell like food.👎👎👎👎

Dress Respectively!
This was a really worthwhile visit however, when I arrived I was told shorts were not appropriate for the court house, so I went home and got changed. I sat up at the cafe for over an hour reading a book and enjoying the views.
Cash only in the cafe.

Stunning architecture! At the entrance you will go through a security check, which includes standing inside a fully closed tube, before being granted access to the inside.  There is no fee to enter, but it is an active building so you may expect to see people participating in legal proceedings.

Highly recommend.

An interesting and free place to visit. It’s true, though — you’ll need to wait about an hour to get inside, unless you arrive just before opening time, when there’s no queue yet. Only 25 people are allowed in per hour.

Before entering, there’s an airport-style security check: all electronic devices and metal objects must be placed in a plastic tray, and bags are thoroughly inspected. My partner was allowed in with a standard-size backpack, but it’s probably a good idea to ask in advance, as this might depend on the security staff on duty. We were lucky to meet a very friendly team, including a helpful, chatty security guard.

The interior is truly impressive. Visitors have access to the main entrance hall and the central part of the first floor. Afterwards, you can take an elevator up to the 5th floor, where there’s a restaurant and café offering a nice view over Vienna.

If you have some time and don’t mind a few minor inconveniences at the entrance, it’s definitely a place worth visiting.

The earlier you go, the better. They let 25 people in at the half of every hour. The place itself is actually small, but the pictures are truly worth it. Do not put bags, jackets or anything on the floor, be quiet and you won't have any problems. They check your things like in an airport.

I tried several times to see this… The inside… While in Vienna, but they only let a few people in each hour and each time I was thwarted. I’m sure it’s wonderful inside as the pictures show. I wish they would let more people in, but I understand.  Danke.

We arrived half an hour before the closing and the security man didn't let us in, we asked for at least seeing the stairs for a minute and he said no. It didn't make any sense, we hate feeling that they are lying to us in our face. What a dissapointment... (We told him the paper at the entrance didn't say that, as you can see in this photo)

placeMetadata.name: Schmetterlinghaus

sources.snippet: Located a five minute walk from the Vienna State Opera,  the Schmetterlinghaus is a tropical oasis right in the heart of the city. Also known as the Imperial Butterfly House, this beautiful building is home to 400 unique butterflies as well as exotic plants from tropical worlds away. The glass greenhouse located at the corner of the palace court garden is a place to enjoy some quiet right in the heart of the city.
sources.shortName: Photo Guide: The Top 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Vienna, Austria
25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

placeMetadata.description: Art nouveau palm house, home to hundreds of butterflies housed in a tropical rainforest setting.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled just a short stroll from the iconic Vienna State Opera, the Schmetterlinghaus, or Imperial Butterfly House, is a stunning Art Nouveau palm house that transports visitors into a vibrant tropical rainforest. This enchanting oasis is home to over 400 species of butterflies fluttering amidst lush exotic plants and serene waterfalls.
placeMetadata.address: Hofburg, Burggarten Palmenhaus, Schmetterlinghaus, 1010 Wien, Austria

reviews.reviewText:
You just have to see it for yourself. It’s such a charming little place—photos really don’t do it justice. The atmosphere is magical, especially when it’s not crowded and you can really take in the beauty of all the butterflies fluttering around and the "jungle" they live in.
It’s not a big place, but that’s part of its charm. I’d definitely recommend going when it’s quieter, so you can feel the true magic of the butterflies up close. It’s one of those spots that leaves you smiling long after you leave! 🥰🦋🌸

I recently visited the Butterfly House in Vienna and overall had a lovely experience. The place is very beautiful, with a nice variety of butterflies fluttering around. However, it did seem like one particular type of butterfly was dominating the space, which was a little underwhelming considering the expectations for more diversity.

The greenery inside is lush and well-maintained, and the small waterfalls throughout really add to the atmosphere, mimicking a real-life tropical ecosystem beautifully. It’s a very charming and peaceful setting — at least it would be if it wasn’t so crowded. The space itself feels a bit too small for the large number of visitors, which made it harder to fully enjoy the experience.

The entrance fee is €10, which is reasonable given the uniqueness of the place. It’s also situated in a lovely area surrounded by nice cafés, making it a great spot to plan a day around.

I would recommend expanding the space a bit and introducing more types of butterflies to enhance the experience even further. Overall, I’m giving it four stars — definitely worth a visit if you’re in Vienna, but be prepared for some crowds.

A small but very charming place with a fair entrance fee. Even though it’s not large, you can walk around a few times and always notice something new. Strollers are a bit inconvenient inside, but there’s a place to leave them outside. Nice gift shop as well.
Nice place to visit with kids

The place is magical.  The garden with tropical plants gives the impression that you are in a jungle, and the butterflies flying around enhance the impression. For a moment you think that you have fallen into some animation or virtual reality. It is very hot and humid inside. It's quick to get around, it's not a big area, but we repeated the circuit to enjoy it a little more :) Butterflies is very friendly, we enjoyed a lot.

Like Butterflies?

Then come here.

Very Tropical botanical environment.

Lots of Butterflies fluttering around.

Some with land on you. A sign of good luck in some Cultures.

Admission is not free.

Nor is it as big and time consuming as you may think.

It’s a rather small venue. So maybe take a few laps inside?

We enjoyed it. But there is no reason to come back.

Try it for something to do….

Great experience! We paid 8€ (student’s price).
It feels like you are entering another realm.
There were many butterflies, but sadly the big ones didn’t move too much, because they were eating.
A fun experience that I recommend if you want to do something different.
Perfect to go with your friends or on a date as well.

Visiting the Butterfly House in Vienna was a magical experience. The lush tropical setting, combined with the vibrant colors and graceful movements of countless butterflies, made me feel like I had stepped into a dream. It’s not just a museum — it’s a living, breathing paradise. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a peaceful and awe-inspiring escape in the heart of the city.

I can't explain how cute and calming this place is. Butterflies of all colours and shapes are flying and eating around you, there's a waterfall which noise relaxes you immediately. It is a small place, hot and humid (all is good for butterflies), you will spend maximum an hour when it's not crowded inside. Great location and definitely worth the visit!

placeMetadata.name: Albrechtsbrunnen

sources.snippet: Located right in front of the Albertina Museum, Albrechtsbrunnen is a fountain that comprises a series of statues that represent the relationship between the city of Vienna (Vindobona) and the River Danube (Danubius). Other rivers are depicted and aim to highlight the strength of Austria-Hungary. When the sky is blue and the fountain is gushing, this is one of the loveliest outdoor Instagrammable places in Vienna and it is a contender for the Trevi Fountain in Rome.
sources.shortName: 19 Stunning Vienna Instagram Spots You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: A river themed monumental fountain, and that’s exactly what the Albrechtsbrunnen is. Located on the lower level of the Albertina museum, this fountain is unique as water only plays a small part of its structure, its principal focus are its sculptures that represent the main rivers of the historical Austro-Hungarian empire. The perfect photo pitstop before visiting the museum or other sites in central Vienna.
sources.shortName: 17 Most Instagrammable spots in Vienna

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: In the heart of Vienna, right in front of the Albertina Museum, stands the Albrechtsbrunnen, also known as Danubiusbrunnen. This river-themed monumental fountain features a series of statues representing the relationship between Vienna and the River Danube, along with other rivers symbolizing the strength of Austria-Hungary. The fountain is a popular spot for visitors seeking picturesque photo opportunities and offers a relaxed atmosphere for those looking to enjoy some peace amidst their travels.

reviews.reviewText: The large statue on the fountain wall, a decorative Renaissance-style wall fountain and monument at the base of one of the few parts of the city walls that remained largely intact.
Iconic and lovely to visit at any time of the year. Be ware of the lines around the place! A lot of people hang around to grab a snack at the booth nearby. 🌭

Crowded area with tourists but worth to see..

The fountain bears the name Albrechtsbrunnen, named for Archduke Albrecht (owner of that palais and the guy riding the horse in the statue on the plateau above the fountain).

Locals also refer to the location as the Danubiusbrunnen, because of the figure of Danubius at the centrepiece of the installation and the overarching Danube theme.

Beautiful! You get a great view and you’ll be able to take amazing pictures. We went twice around 11AM and again at 4PM, each time it’s not been busy and you had space to snap a picture.

It’s got a relaxed atmosphere so this place is great if you want a change of scenery and want some peace.
Amazing sculptures and a fountain. You will see long lines ups at lunch for the street vendors. People will come sit in front of the statues and bask in the artistic ambience to relax.
Beautiful place to sit and contemplate the city life. Could spend hours looking for details in the buildings and fountains.

The Albrechtsbrunnen , also known as Danubiusbrunnen is located in the heart of lovely Vienna. This historical masterpiece, has been made of 9 statues (one in the middle Danubius and Vindobona and four at each side), a fountain and the background building.
A beautiful architecture which needs time to visit and admire.
5 star

placeMetadata.name: Palais Ferstel

sources.snippet: The charming Freyung Passage is in an elegant shopping arcade built in the 19th century as part of the Ferstel Palace. Surrounded by quaint cafes, this is a pretty picture stop. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Vienna

sources.snippet: The marble-clad passage of Palais Ferstel with luxury stores and cafes looks really splendid. It is also called the Freyung Passage. Do not forget to visit the famous Café Central which is located nearby.
sources.shortName: Top 15 most instagrammable spots in Vienna, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Grand 1850s mansion used for events and a landmark cafe, once a hangout of Sigmund Freud & Trotsky.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Palais Ferstel is a grand 1850s mansion in Vienna, known for its landmark cafe and as a popular meeting place for influential figures like Sigmund Freud and Trotsky. The traditional cafe, which opened in 1876, is celebrated for its beautiful interior and was once frequented by leading lights in art, literature, politics, and science. The Italianate palace hosts the famous Cafe Central on its ground floor with a tiny outdoor terrace.

reviews.reviewText: Located within historic Vienna, on the edge of Freyung square is this ornate structure, it has a lovely passageway, with a fountain topped with a bronze danube nymph,  a must visit when exploring the city.

One of the local favorite palaces inside the city.
Unique exterior with an even greater interior.
Authentic Viennese shops cover the ground floor as the Palace above shines through different even lights and concerts.
Home to a famous Cafe with years of authentic history
I think this palace is a hidden gem. You can walk through in a couple of minutes for free. Also there is a passage with a fountain.

This is one of the most beautiful passages in Vienna. It has lovely cafés and small shops. The place has a special charm, with its old-style design and quiet atmosphere. The view down the passage is simply magical - a peaceful blend of history, elegance and Viennese café culture.
Amazing event venue with impressive decoration in the main hall. Looks like it was connected with church, on a ceiling you can see Jesus Christ statues. In the lighting it looks fantastic.
Beautifull place. Very 9ld!
Stunning prestigious venue in central Vienna, perfect for exclusive galas, weddings and events. Highly recommended for memorable celebrations.

Palais Ferstel, a historic gem in Vienna, showcases a blend of Renaissance and Baroque architecture. From hosting prestigious events to housing upscale shops and cafes, it remains a vibrant destination where history and modernity converge, offering visitors a glimpse into Vienna's rich cultural heritage. Originally constructed in the 19th century, has been a hub for commerce, culture, and social gatherings throughout its storied history. With its grand halls and opulent ballrooms, it has welcomed dignitaries and luminaries, continuing to enchant guests with its timeless beauty and cultural significance.

placeMetadata.name: deli am Naschmarkt

sources.snippet: Naschmarkt is the most popular flea market in town, bringing shoppers as early as sunrise who are on the hunt for a great souvenir. Every Saturday, around 400 vendors arrive long before the sun rises, setting up their stalls at 4 AM. They sell everything from souvenirs, to jewelry, and even rare antiques.
sources.shortName: Photo Guide: The Top 16 Most Instagrammable Places in Vienna, Austria

sources.snippet: This is the most popular market in Vienna and located at the Wienzeile over the Wien River. About 1.5 kilometers long, here you can find plenty of things and there are some great restaurants and cafés. Try the local food and of course capture the moment on camera.
sources.shortName: 10 most Instagrammable places in Vienna

placeMetadata.description: Unfussy marketplace eatery with outdoor seating & DJs at night serving Turkish & Mediterranean fare.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Naschmarkt Deli is a casual eatery located in Vienna's largest outdoor market, offering Turkish and Mediterranean cuisine. The market itself boasts over 120 stalls selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and international delicacies, as well as numerous bars, vinotheks, and restaurants. Naschmarkt Deli stands out with its small selection of cocktails and weekend DJs. The market is a popular destination for locals and tourists alike due to its diverse offerings and vibrant atmosphere.
placeMetadata.address: Naschmarkt, Linke Wienzeile Stand 421/436, 1060 Wien, Austria

reviews.reviewText: I like this restaurant. The food is fresh and tasty. Everyone is friendly and atmosphere is positive.

The meals were rather average. The lamb wasn’t good at all. The chicken wrap was nice but the sides were rather average. They could also use a better wine for their spritzer. The staff were friendly but not attentive, for example, we didn’t know they had a meals of the day menu which seemed nice and could have saved us €20.
Great food, friendly staff! Highly recommended.

We went for a snack and a drink in the afternoon. Although the place was half empty the staff moved slowly and definitely without any intention to be polite or friendly. However when it was time to pay they reminded me to leave a tip. Quality of food I suppose it was acceptable (I had a salmon wrap what could be wrong?) however overpriced.

It was one of best Mediterranean cuisine!
We ordered vegan breakfast and feta cheese grilled, overall was perfect especially the homemade feta cheese, hummus and soft bread😍

The service was friendly also

Strongly recommend people looking for somewhere to eat passed by market!

We stopped here for lunch before continuing our tour through the city, and ordered grilled salmon, lamb skewers, and beef schnitzel. The lamb was quite tender, and there was no trace of the lamb odour (my mom hates the smell and was fine eating this dish). The crust of the schnitzel wasn't very crispy, but the meat was okay. The rice side dish is actually surprisingly good (high praise from an Asian family). We were overall quite happy with the experience.

Great Mediterranean and Turkish food. We ordered hummus and the Mediterranean vegetables plate. Both were great and pretty light/healthy, which is what we were craving. The aperol spritzes were well made and use Prosecco. Atmosphere and outdoor seating were phenomenal!

I have given this place multiple opportunities, but the food is definitely not its highlight. The drinks are okay, and the service tends to be quite helpful and friendly, which is always super nice in Vienna. The atmosphere is cool, and I love the DJ there; they play cool songs.

sources.snippet: Tucked away beside the Hofburg Palace is a series of impressive buildings known collectively as the ‘ museum quarter‘. Now, it may seem obvious from the name exactly what these buildings are, but nothing prepared me for their enormity and grandeur. Here you will find attractions such as the Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien (Art History Museum) or, my personal favourite, Naturhistorisches Museum Vienna (Natural History Museum).
sources.shortName: The BEST photo spots in Vienna (with pictures)

sources.snippet: The MuseumsQuartier is a cultural complex combining classic and contemporary architecture, making it a diverse photo spot. The complex includes the Leopold Museum, Kunsthalle, and Museum of Modern Art, offering unique facades and modern installations. The courtyard is also lively and filled with artistic seating structures that add character to your photos.
sources.shortName: Where to Find Vienna's Best Photo Spots

reviews.reviewText: One of my favorite spots in Vienna! Grab a vegan ice-cream, a book from my favorite bookstore nearby and chill!

The MuseumsQuartier (MQ) in Vienna is a vibrant cultural complex that seamlessly blends historic architecture with contemporary design. Among its many attractions, the MQ features a distinctive water feature that serves as both a visual centerpiece and a communal gathering spot.

Design and Features

The MQ’s water feature is characterized by its minimalist design, featuring a series of shallow pools and gentle streams that create a serene atmosphere. This design encourages visitors to relax, socialize, and engage with the space, making it a popular spot for both locals and tourists.

Cultural Significance

Beyond its aesthetic appeal, the water feature embodies the MQ’s commitment to fostering artistic expression and community interaction.
