It complements the complex’s diverse range of cultural institutions, including museums, galleries, and performance spaces, thereby enhancing the overall visitor experience. ￼

Visitor Experience

Visitors to the MQ often praise the water feature for its tranquil ambiance and the opportunity it provides to unwind amidst the city’s hustle and bustle. The surrounding area offers a variety of cafés and shops, allowing guests to enjoy refreshments while appreciating the artistic surroundings.

In summary, the MuseumsQuartier’s water feature is a testament to Vienna’s dedication to integrating art, architecture, and public space, offering a unique and enriching experience for all who visit.
Always nice to hangout, eat or drink 👌👍

A wonderful museum and high quality of modern art and technological architecture. On the territory of the museum there is a very good bookstore, there is a gallery in the yard with temporary exhibitions, a very unusual passage arch with a painted ceiling, cafes and restaurants and many different benches on which it is pleasant to relax in the fresh air. I really liked it!

(Translated by Google) A different form of motivation. It looks nice.

(Original)
Faklı bir eser motivasyon şekli. Güzel görünüyor.

(Translated by Google) Wow... definitely one of my favorite places in Vienna... you could stay there forever. There's so much to see, and the view from the café's rooftop terrace is highly recommended.

(Original)
Wow.... definitiv einer meiner Lieblingsorte in Wien.....man könnte ewig dort verweilen. Es gibt unheimlich viel zu sehen und zu empfehlen ist der Ausblick auf der Dachterrasse des Cafés👀

The MQ Water Feature is a really nice, relaxing spot in the middle of the MuseumsQuartier. It's a great place to sit down and chill for a bit, especially on a warm day. The minimalist design is cool, and it's a perfect little oasis to take a break from all the sightseeing

(Translated by Google) Really beautifully laid out and the owner puts a lot of effort into it!

(Original)
Richtig schön angelegt und der Inhaber gibt sich richtig viel Mühe!

placeMetadata.name: Third Man Museum

sources.snippet: Prater Park is certainly one of the best-known attractions in Vienna, and it’s simply impossible not to include the Wiener Riesenrad Ferris wheel on a list of Vienna Instagram spots!. You can easily reach the park by taking a subway train to Praterstern station, and following the lights and noise. In days gone by, this used to be imperial hunting grounds, but it was opened up to the public in 1766.
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

placeMetadata.description: Small museum with  memorabilia from the film "The Third Man" which takes place in postwar Vienna.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Third Man Museum is a small museum located in the underground world below Vienna, showcasing memorabilia from the iconic film 'The Third Man,' which was shot in postwar Vienna. The museum offers an adventurous experience as visitors can explore the sewers with a headlamp and recognize parts that featured in the film. It contains thousands of items related to the movie and its historical period.

reviews.reviewText: I expect if you're visiting here that you've already seen (and loved) "The Third Man". What a perfect film it is.  I was so glad to be in Vienna on a Saturday afternoon to have had this experience - the museum has so many wonderful artefacts from the film.  Even little Hansel gets his moment!

WOW! Not just a museum about The Third Man, they have a tremendous amount of historical artifacts about Vienna during Post-War reconstruction. The owners Karin and Gerhard are incredibly nice and will answer any questions and ask if you saw certain museum displays.

Pro-tip - Go here FIRST, buy their filming locations book and then explore Vienna.

I was planning on being in Vienna for a few days and when I saw there was a Third Man Museum there it made my trip so much more exciting. And the museum, not only didn't disappoint, it exceeded my expectations.
This place was awesome and is clearly the work of someone who loves Vienna and the movie - and couldn't be possible without the support of those who love him.

Great museum both for fans of the film and really for anyone interested in post war Vienna. Lots of unique memorabilia and some fun photo opportunities. Not huge and split between three buildings but the staff is lovely and helpful and makes it super easy. It was very quiet when we went at opening time on a Saturday. Highly recommend.

Gerhard, the owner and founder of the museum, gave my group a fantastic walking tour of Vienna focusing on the period of post World War II ‘Cold War’. We really enjoyed his perspective of connections to present day world relations.
The museum shows so much of world history, events and connections to the US and Allied forces. All the with Primary source documents and items. I highly recommend the museum, even if you have never seen the Third Man Movie!
Awesome museum, a little treasure in Vienna. Such a great work of dedication. And of course great tribute to a superb movie.

We had the best tour. Fantastic experience. Fascinating museum. We knew a lot about WWII and the Cold War in Germany, but this was a lot of new and nuanced information and exhibitions. Gerherd was so great. Excellent stories. Flexible. Really an outstanding Vienna experience.

Clearly a work of passion by the owners (thank you!), this museum is a go-to place for all fans of the movie. An extension now provides historical background on Vienna during and after WWII. Alas only open Saturday afternoons, so do make it a priority when planning your trip.

placeMetadata.name: Jesuit Church

sources.snippet: Whether you’re on the hunt of Instagrammable places in Vienna because you want some photo fodder, or whither you simply want to check out the most beautiful spots in the city, you have to check out the Jesuit Church. It’ll quite possibly be the most breathtaking church you’ll ever set foot in!. A short walk from the very center of the city, the Jesuit Church is also known as “University Church”, because of its proximity to the University of Vienna.
sources.shortName: 25 Amazing Places You'll Love!

placeMetadata.description: This 17th-century Jesuit church has an opulent interior with marble columns & frescoes.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Jesuit Church, also known as the University Church, is a 17th-century architectural marvel located in Vienna. Its unassuming exterior belies the opulent and breathtaking interior featuring marble columns, frescoes, and an incredible illusionistic dome painted by renowned artist Andrea Pozzo. The church's proximity to the University of Vienna makes it a notable landmark in the city.

reviews.reviewText: The Jesuit Church is a stunning architectural masterpiece! Its elegant Baroque façade and richly decorated interior, complete with ornate stucco work and grand frescoes, create an awe‑inspiring atmosphere. A true gem of design and history.

A hidden Baroque masterpiece only 8 minutes from St. Stephen’s Cathedral. The gilded details, vivid frescoes, and majestic organ are simply breathtaking. I visited at 1 PM and the sunlight streaming through made the gold and colors glow pure magic. Peaceful, stunning, and uncrowded.

Hidden gem of Vienna! One of my favourite churches so far. Really beautiful, quiet and holy atmosphere. I recommend visiting early in the morning so you can soak it the stillness and calmness of it without other visitors (the entry is free)

the jesuitenkirche (jesuit church) is one of those places that completely surprises you. from the outside, it looks pretty plain, just a simple facade with a couple of towers. you'd probably walk right by it if you didn't know better.
​but once you step inside, wow. it's like a baroque explosion. the interior is incredibly opulent and decorated with tons of gold and ornate detail. the whole space is a feast for the eyes, with rich colors and a real sense of grandeur.
​the best part, though, is the ceiling. you're looking up, and you see this magnificent dome. but then you realize... it's not a real dome! it's a trompe-l'œil painting on a flat ceiling that creates this amazing illusion of a dome with incredible perspective. it was painted by a jesuit artist named andrea pozzo in the 1700s, and it's a masterpiece of optical illusion. you can walk around and see how the perspective changes as you move.
​it’s a much more less crowded space than st. stephen's or karlskirche. you can really take your time and admire the details without feeling rushed. it's a true hidden gem and a great reminder that you can't always judge a book by its cover. and it's free to enter, so it's a perfect stop to make if you're in the area

Great quiet location for a place like this.
A truly captivating interior, corners filled with gold and delicately carved stone.
p.s Take a look inside the hidden underground chamber this beautiful church holds.
Wow it was under maintenance when we visited but wow. It’s magical!

Two of the best things I like about churches are very grand and very free. This has both.

Amazing architecture. You can spend some beautiful time here.
I found this church unexpectedly and I was left speechless. One of my favorite churches in Vienna. The art is simply incredible and stunning

ops.insert: Medieval Roman Catholic place of worship with an ornate spire, catacombs & a treasury museum.
Baroque, 18th-century palaces housing art from Middle Ages to today, with notable Klimt collection.
18th-century summer palace with tours of lavish rococo ceremonial rooms, plus gardens with a maze.
World-famous opera house offering major productions, original decor & multilingual guided tours.
Habsburg palace complex with ornate, baroque interiors, imperial apartments & a silver museum.
Large park with old-time amusements, including a landmark giant wheel dating from 1897.
Artist's creation of brightly painted, natural apartment block with a forested roof & balconies.
18th-century Habsburg domed cathedral with a 32.5-meter platform for views of the ornate frescoes.
Long-standing venue for Viennese cuisine, with famous historic links including to Freud & Trotsky.
A striking art nouveau conservatory with butterfly house stands in this statue-filled palace garden.
18th-century church featuring ornate baroque art & architecture & daily organ recitals.
Built in 1860, this regal arcade with a fountain & courtyard offers upscale boutiques, bars & cafes.
Baroque State Hall with ceiling frescoes housing National Library including papyrus & globe museums.
Landmark Catholic church, one of the oldest & last examples of Gothic architecture in the city.
19th-century Habsburg palace with staterooms & collections of old master prints & 20th-century art.
Fairground attraction rebuilt in 1945, with wooden cabins offering dining & an exhibition.
Prominent square by museums featuring a monument to empress Maria Theresa, fountains & green space.
Storied neo-Gothic church built in 1879, with a museum showcasing liturgical objects.
Landmark basilica consecrated in 1913, with golden mosaics in the art nouveau Elizabeth Chapel.
Former summer residence of the royal family with vast gardens & tours, now a UNESCO site.
Corner bar with views of shopping street, serving drinks & snacks including the house Sacher-Torte.
Massive municipal building built using some 30 million bricks & now hosting balls, markets & events.
Restored area of historic & modern buildings containing many of the city's finest museums.
Established in 1882, this huge, airy greenhouse with 3 pavilions showcases many exotic plants.
Public teaching & research institution, founded in 1365, with a campus & about 92,000 students.
Strauss & Lanner once played in this manicured public park with temples, fountains & rose gardens.
Roman-era walking street known for its bustling retail activity & ornate historic buildings.
Imposing 19th-century museum with lavish interiors housing art collections & antiquities.
19th-century park with statues, mature trees & fountains, plus summer cinema & winter ice rink.
Art nouveau palm house, home to hundreds of butterflies housed in a tropical rainforest setting.
Unfussy marketplace eatery with outdoor seating & DJs at night serving Turkish & Mediterranean fare.
Magnificent, statue-rich 1888 edifice with staircases painted by Gustav Klimt, vast stage & tours.
Stately 19th-century courthouse with statues & a grand atrium, plus a stylish rooftop restaurant.
Grand 1850s mansion used for events and a landmark cafe, once a hangout of Sigmund Freud & Trotsky.
This 17th-century Jesuit church has an opulent interior with marble columns & frescoes.
Small museum with  memorabilia from the film "The Third Man" which takes place in postwar Vienna.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Vienna, the city of music and imperial history, is a treasure trove of stunning photo opportunities just waiting to be discovered. From the vibrant colors of the Hundertwasser House to the majestic architecture of Schönbrunn Palace, every corner of this enchanting city offers a unique backdrop for your next Instagram post. Whether you're wandering through the meticulously maintained gardens of Belvedere Palace or capturing the intricate details of St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna's rich cultural heritage and artistic flair will leave you inspired.

As you explore the streets of Vienna, you'll find a delightful mix of iconic landmarks and hidden gems that showcase the city's charm. Snap a picture of the Baroque beauty of St. Charles's Church or the bustling atmosphere of the Naschmarkt Deli, where delicious food and vibrant energy collide. With so many picturesque spots to choose from, it's no wonder that Vienna is a favorite among photographers and travelers alike. So grab your camera and get ready to capture the magic of this beautiful city!

data.title: The 34 most romantic places in Salzburg

placeMetadata.name: Fortress Hohensalzburg

sources.snippet: The spectacular Hohensalzburg Fortress is one of the main landmarks of Salzburg and also the heart of the historic old town. A visit to this stunning place is an absolute highlight and definitely this impressive fortress is one of the most beautiful attractions in Salzburg. The 900-year-old Hohensalzburg Fortress is located at the top of the Mönchsberg and can either be climbed on foot, or you can comfortably take the fortress train, which is located next to the Stieglkeller and the Festungsgasse.
sources.shortName: 20 Amazing Things to Do in Salzburg (Austria)

sources.snippet: Salzburg is dominated by the picturesque Fortress Hohensalzburg (Festung Hohensalzburg), a stunning historic fortress that dominates the city skyline. Situated on the southeastern summit of the Mönchsberg, the original castle was built in 1077, and much of what's seen today dates from the early 1500s. You can reach the castle by a pleasant 20-minute walk from the Old Town center or via a funicular railway from Festungsgasse.
sources.shortName: 18 Top-Rated Things to Do in Salzburg

sources.snippet: Even as you enter Salzburg, catching the first glimpse of Hohensalzburg Fortress, you sense it immediately: the magnetism of a proud and fascinating city. On the stages of this City of Mozart Tristan and Isolde have fallen hopelessly in love, while Romeo and Juliet have left the City of Mozart will many a bitter-sweet memory. In other words, Salzburg is the perfect place in which to celebrate love!
sources.shortName: Salzburg for Lovers : Magazine

sources.snippet: Dating back to the 11th century, Hohensalzburg Fortress is one of the largest and best-preserved fortresses in Europe. A key landmark of Salzburg and an integral part of its skyline, the fortress is located high on Festungberg Hill. You can either walk to it or take a funicular from the old town, which is far quicker and much easier.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)
Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

sources.siteName: 4* Hotel Wolf-Dietrich in Salzburg, Austria, Old Town
sources.shortName: Romantic hotel Salzburg | romantic city break for 2
Salzburg tips: The Top 10 highlights for your romantic weekend

placeMetadata.description: Huge 11th-century fortress complex on a hilltop with views over city to the Alps, plus museums.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Perched on a hilltop with commanding views of the city and the Alps, Fortress Hohensalzburg is an impressive 11th-century complex that draws in over 1.4 million visitors annually. To avoid the crowds, it's best to arrive early and take a glass funicular or embark on a steep 20-minute walk up Festungsgasse in the Old Town to reach this iconic landmark.

reviews.reviewText: The outdoors is open for hours after indoor exhibits close in summer. This is the last place on my list for the day. My plan was to visit all the indoor exhibits before closing then enjoy the outdoors hopefully in the cooler hours. It's big and interesting with multiple buildings. High up on the hill, with great views of the city and surrounding areas. One would think this is a great location to defend the city. Ironically, it's not been battle tested after it was built in the 11th century. With the city pass, went up with the cable car and walked down. It would be a good climb to hike up. On a hot summer day, no thanks.

Huge fortress, imposing, impressive build.  The walk up from the town to the highest part of the turret is a workout.  The fortress approach walkway is significantly sloped, covered in fine rock and worn dirt, so wear a good pair of shoes that give good grip.  For anyone with mobility issues or if it's raining/wet, I'd highly recommend the funicular.   While the fortress has an interesting history, I was disappointed that there were not more objects of historical significance inside it.  It's actually pretty sparse inside.  There are some military items, but very few furnishings and no tapestries.  The staff were all very helpful.  The cost of a visit is very reasonable.  The view is unparalleled.  It is truly a commanding view of the surrounding countryside.  Worth doing for the view, but could use more historical/period artifacts inside and around the grounds.

Great view, we took the tram up but I think it would have been lovely to have a hike up. We got the basic card and we were able to finish all attractions well within 3 hours. View from observation deck was amazing.

Visiting the Hohensalzburg Fortress was an unforgettable experience. 🏰 The views over Salzburg and the surrounding mountains are absolutely breathtaking, and walking through the historic halls and courtyards feels like stepping back in time. The fortress is very well preserved, with fascinating exhibitions that tell the story of the city and its rich history. The funicular ride to the top is quick and enjoyable, and once you arrive, the atmosphere is simply magical. I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Salzburg – it’s a must-see landmark full of history, beauty, and charm. 🌟

Fortress Hohensalzburg is absolutely stunning and a must-visit when in Salzburg!
The views from the top are breathtaking — you get to see the entire city and the surrounding mountains.
The fortress itself is incredibly well-preserved and full of history, with fascinating exhibits that take you back in time.

If you’re fit and enjoy walking, try skipping the gondola and hike up instead — the journey on foot is spectacular and makes the experience even more rewarding.
It can get a bit crowded during peak hours, but it’s totally worth it for the views and history.

Overall, an unforgettable experience and one of the highlights of Salzburg!

This is one of the simplest castles I have ever visited in Europe. The cable car ride up is very nice, but the weather was extremely hot, so it felt like a sauna. The view from the top is beautiful, with Salzburg city surrounded by mountains. However, overall, the value for money felt quite low.

Great old castle, some lovely views and information
A little bit over the top on pricing but not excessive…. Steep walks so if a little hard on the health recommend the funicular
Recommend getting there as soon as it opens to avoid the crush
Amazing experience to see and tour the fortress.  The cable car was comfortable and quick, the restaurant on top was delicious and offered incredible views. Would highly recommend.

placeMetadata.name: Mönchsberg

sources.snippet: With its vaulted taverns and vast, 1400-seat beer garden set up under the shade of chestnut trees, this monk-founded brewery at the foot of Mönchsberg has given Salzburg rollicking good times since 1621. Fill your tankard at the foyer pump and visit the Schmankerlgang (deli stands) for hearty, beer-swigging grub like Stelze (ham hock), pork belly, and pretzels as big as your head. Beers swing from mildly hoppy lagers to amber-hued wheat beers.
sources.shortName: The 12 best things to do in Salzburg

sources.snippet: The spectacular Hohensalzburg Fortress is one of the main landmarks of Salzburg and also the heart of the historic old town. A visit to this stunning place is an absolute highlight and definitely this impressive fortress is one of the most beautiful attractions in Salzburg. The 900-year-old Hohensalzburg Fortress is located at the top of the Mönchsberg and can either be climbed on foot, or you can comfortably take the fortress train, which is located next to the Stieglkeller and the Festungsgasse.
sources.shortName: 20 Amazing Things to Do in Salzburg (Austria)

sources.snippet: Another place from which to enjoy exceptional city views in Salzburg is at the top of Mönchsberg hill. You can reach the viewing platform – also known as Winkler Terrace – by taking a short elevator ride from Gstättengasse street, near the river. The cost of the ride is also included in the Salzburg Card.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)

sources.snippet: The Mönchsberg dominates the cityscape because it is located in the middle of the old town and stretches about 1.7 km through Salzburg. From up here you have a perfect view over the whole of Salzburg and its surroundings from many vantage points.
sources.shortName: Salzburg tips: The Top 10 highlights for your romantic weekend

sources.snippet: On the northern part of the Mönchsberg, between the Augustiner Bräu brewery and Museum der Moderne art museum, awaits picturesque meadows & vistas of the city.
sources.siteName: 4* Hotel Wolf-Dietrich in Salzburg, Austria, Old Town
sources.shortName: Romantic hotel Salzburg | romantic city break for 2
Salzburg for Lovers : Magazine

placeMetadata.description: Rocky plateau above Salzburg with woods, meadows, castles & a modern art museum, reached by a lift.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mönchsberg, also known as Monks Hill, is a rocky plateau above Salzburg offering stunning views of the old town and the Alps. This wooded ridge features meadows, castles, and a modern art museum that can be reached by a lift. The area is home to notable attractions such as the Benedictine Abbey of St. Peter with buildings dating back to the 17th and 18th centuries, including a church remodeled in Rococo style.

reviews.reviewText: We visited the modern museum and were pleasantly surprised by the lovely views and forest walkways. You can even take your dog for a walk here. Nice castle view and interesting architectural construction where you can exercise your vocal cords and hear it echo.

Mönchsberg @ Salzburg 🌿🇦🇹
📍 Salzburg Old Town

Mönchsberg is a scenic hill and green parkland stretching along the western edge of Salzburg’s Old Town, offering some of the best elevated views over the city. The walking trail runs along the historic defence wall and is dotted with viewpoints, small gates, and cultural landmarks.

I explored Mönchsberg as part of my hike down from Fortress Hohensalzburg, first passing the Museum der Moderne Salzburg, then crossing Schartentor before reaching Humboldtterrasse. From here, panoramic vistas unfolded—the red and grey rooftops of the Altstadt, the green domes of Salzburg Cathedral, the Salzach River winding through town, and the Alps beyond.

It was surprisingly quiet along the trail, with only a few locals enjoying the park and the view, making the walk feel peaceful and unhurried. Eventually, I continued to Klausentor, took a short break at Café am Kai, crossed Müllnersteg footbridge, and returned to Mirabell Palace.

🧭 Tip: This is one of Salzburg’s best free activities. Come in the late afternoon for softer light and fewer people. Wear comfortable shoes—the trail is easy but involves some inclines and steps.
Either you go with Festungbahn (cable car) or by foot through stair, that's fine. The best place to see sunset in Salzburg you'll agree when you see it yourself.

We started our walking tour of Salzburg at the Mirabell Gardens, crossed the river walking around the Altstadt then got on the slopes of the Monchsberg climbing up the stairs at Toschaninhof & walked along the path past the modern art museum & various viewpoints all the way along the cliff edge & then down the hill crossing the river over back to the Mirabell gardens on the Mullnersteg bridge. Nice opportunities to get high various high views over the city from this walk.

A fantastic opporunity for a trip above a baroque city. Pleasant walks in the forest and from vantage points you can see the beautiful panorama of the Alpine town with its many towers. In the meantime, a restaurant, a buffet,... I rest on a bench. This is also one of the programs not to be missed when visiting Salzburg 🇦🇹
Slightly steep at the start of the walk, but you can reach hohensalzburg fortress via this route. Start of the route is at city centre, need to walk up few flights of stairs
Best place in town for views of the city and to walk in a protected landscape. Didi Niederkofler Austriaguide
Always a pleasure to walk ups and downs to check different views of Salzburg！

placeMetadata.name: Salzburg Cathedral

sources.snippet: A visit to Salzburg Cathedral is certainly one of the things to do in Salzburg because this building is absolutely impressive from the inside as well as from the outside. The imposing church dates back to the early Baroque period and shapes the cityscape of Salzburg with its mighty dome and towers. The cathedral square is also the site of the annual Christmas market in winter and the famous Salzburg Festival in summer.
sources.shortName: 20 Amazing Things to Do in Salzburg (Austria)

sources.snippet: A prominent building thanks to its twin 79-meter tall towers, Salzburg Cathedral (Salzburger Dom) was completed in 1657 and is famous for its Italian style and its role as the location of Mozart's baptism. The building's west front, facing the Domplatz, has four colossal marble statues, the outer ones representing St. Rupert and Virgil, patron saints of the province. The inner ones depict Peter and Paul.
sources.shortName: 18 Top-Rated Things to Do in Salzburg

sources.snippet: The impressive Cathedral is one of the most notable landmarks in Salzburg. Standing right in the heart of the old town and surrounded by the most beautiful and important town squares, you’ll inevitably pass here at least a few times during your visit. A cathedral was first built on this site in 774.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)
Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Twin spires top this baroque-style 17th-century cathedral, with a museum housing sacred treasures.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Salzburg Cathedral, with its twin spires and baroque-style architecture, is a monumental symbol of the city's religious significance and historical wealth. The cathedral houses a museum that displays sacred treasures, adding to its allure. The building has undergone several reconstructions over the centuries, with the current structure showcasing early Baroque ecclesiastical architecture at its finest. Visitors are captivated by the towering facade and turquoise domes of this 17th-century marvel.

reviews.reviewText: Salzburg Cathedral is so big and impressive! You have to get in! We went for the mass and light a candle on Easter Day and the atmosphere was divine and peaceful. The statues and the ceiling are so beautiful and well maintained. It’s in the center of Salzburg in the middle of a massive square. Overall amazing to visit and recommend it! There is an entrance fee of 5 euros.

Gorgeous cathedral, but not the best for choir concert. My son sang with a group of over 100 kids and you could barely hear them.

The massive, absolutely stunning interior is just not made for that. Otherwise, it was awesome.

The inside of this cathedral is absolutely stunning. The walls and ceilings are bathed in rich and intricate detail and the ceiling has eye catching murals and statues. It truly is something to see and worth a bit of your time in Salzburg. It doesn’t take long to just pop in and admire. I would encourage visitors to wear appropriate clothing and act appropriately considering this is a church.

One of the most beautiful churches I've ever been to! The size and grandeur of the Dom von Salzburg are truly impressive, and the architectural details are absolutely stunning. The interior is peaceful and serene, with intricate decorations and beautiful artwork that make it a must-see.

It’s also nice to see that visitors respect the quiet and sacred nature of the place, which adds to the calm atmosphere. Whether you’re there for a moment of reflection or simply to admire the history and beauty, this church offers a truly memorable experience.

Definitely a highlight of Salzburg, and a must-visit if you're in the city!
Beautiful cathedral.  And organist was playing/practicing with we were visiting.  Made the experience very nice.  Going down to the crypt was a nice addition to the visit.

Beautiful inside and out.  European cathedrals are always impressive and this one lives up to the reputation.  Elegant may be a better word for the decor inside.  While not overly ornate, it is the openness and brightness of the interior that was eye catching.  Really a beautiful place of worship.

An absolutely beautiful church! This stands out from many of the other churches we’d seen because of the stunning black and white design that makes the paintings pop. The organ was also beautiful. There is an entrance fee but the discount with the Salzburg card brings it down to €3.5 per person.
Strikingly beautiful cathedral.  Spend five minutes sitting in the quiet of the crypt.  We went back to an organ concert yesterday.  At 15 euros, it was well worth the money.

placeMetadata.name: DomQuartier Salzburg

sources.snippet: A visit to Salzburg Cathedral is certainly one of the things to do in Salzburg because this building is absolutely impressive from the inside as well as from the outside. The imposing church dates back to the early Baroque period and shapes the cityscape of Salzburg with its mighty dome and towers. The cathedral square is also the site of the annual Christmas market in winter and the famous Salzburg Festival in summer.
sources.shortName: 20 Amazing Things to Do in Salzburg (Austria)

sources.snippet: A UNESCO World Heritage site, DomQuartier Salzburg is a stunning attraction made up of a complex of baroque buildings built around three courtyards. It was created by the prince-archbishops of Salzburg more than 400 years ago. Originally it contained both their residential quarters and a Cathedral, as an expression of their claim to rule both the heavens and the earth.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)

sources.snippet: The Domquartier is a museum complex and a cultural highlight on a Salzburg city trip. You follow a predetermined path which leads you through the following areas:
sources.shortName: Salzburg tips: The Top 10 highlights for your romantic weekend

placeMetadata.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, this expansive Baroque complex offers art & cultural history tours.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The DomQuartier Salzburg is a UNESCO World Heritage Site that showcases the rich arts and cultural history of Salzburg. This expansive Baroque complex includes a cathedral, an Abbey, and five separate museums. One of the museums, the famous Dom Museum, houses the Kunst und Wunderkammer, which features a fascinating collection of stuffed animals, fossils, scientific devices, and rock crystal grinding works.

reviews.reviewText:
One of the best places to visit in Salzburg.
We spent a good couple of hours here.
Beautiful chandlers , painting, jewled items.
Curiosity cupboards.
Love the architecture.
The rooms are very big .
We used our Salzburg cards.

Basically a bunch of museums put together, you have the one connected to Salzburg Cathedral, residence gallery, state rooms and the museum of St Peter.

You can also get a better view on the fountain and the center in general while going though the tour.

Beatiful museum but the reason for the 2 stars is that they put contemporary art in the middle of multiple rooms which really harm the atmosphere of the particular rooms. Contemporary art should stay in the contemporary museum in my opinion where it's setting alings with other pieces. This mishmash was really saddening.

Visited on 9th December and this is probably the best value experience we have found over the last 9 months of travelling. The inclusion of historical palatial buildings, significant artwork, items of significance from the church, access to view the historical church from the upper level adjacent to the pipe organ, and some museum collections.
It is all very well maintained, pristine and tidy. There are also several locations where you have views over the marketplace where the Christmas Stalls are situated.
You could easily spend two hours or more reviewing it all.

Wonderful place from outside as well as inside. The cathedral is impressive and the museum part is very interesting too. There were several exhibitions available and we can only recommend visiting them.

This place is definitely worth a visit. Very palatial, wonderful exhibitions, access to the attic of the Dome organ and the adjacent terrace with a beautiful view. A very interesting museum, with centuries-old exhibits. You can see the representative chambers of the archbishop, an art gallery and works of sacred art. The most interesting thing for me was the opportunity to admire the cathedral’s interior from above, from the organ gallery.
The best museum in Salzburg. I had the chance to visit with the Salzburg card, half a day was not enough. You can go through several exhibitions and the Salzburg Cathedral. Very amazed!

The modern art statues were very interesting. There were some music festivals going on in the summer. There are a lot of shops and artists in the square. I bought two pieces of painting from an artist here. The old town streets are connected to here. There are a lot of small isles going through the courtyard and connecting two streets. It was kind of surprising; I thought it was a deadend then it showed the other end goes to another street. It is fun to walk through the old town.
Beautiful architecture with many historical sites to explore. The audio guide was helpful, but the connection was a bit slow at times.

placeMetadata.name: Mirabell Palace

sources.snippet: Another garden used in the filming of The Sound of Music is at Salzburg's lovely Mirabell Palace (Schloss Mirabell). This excellent example of Baroque landscape design was laid out in 1690 with numerous terraces, marble statues, and fountains. The palace itself was remodeled in Baroque style between 1721-27 before being restored in the simpler Neoclassical style after a fire in 1818.
sources.shortName: 18 Top-Rated Things to Do in Salzburg

sources.snippet: Built early in the 17th century by prince-archbishop Wolf Dietrich for his wife, Mirabell Palace and Gardens is one of the most beautiful places in Salzburg. The palace, the manicured gardens, the fountains, the views – everything is so beautiful. A visit here is like stepping into a fairytale!
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)

sources.snippet: End the day with a romantic dinner at Restaurant Ikarus, located at the Red Bull Hangar-7 and featuring innovative cuisine by top chefs from around the world.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Iconic, 17th-century palace with ornamental gardens, plus classical concerts in the lavish ballroom.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mirabell Palace, a 17th-century architectural gem located in Salzburg, is renowned for its ornamental gardens and opulent interior. The palace was featured in the iconic film 'The Sound of Music,' with its gardens serving as the backdrop for memorable scenes. Built by Archbishop Wolf Dietrich in 1606 and later redesigned in Baroque style, the palace boasts exquisite interior decorations including stucco and wall paintings.

reviews.reviewText:
Mirabell Palace is absolutely stunning and a must-see in Salzburg. The palace itself is elegant, but the real highlight is the Mirabell Gardens — beautifully maintained with colorful flower beds, sculptures, and fountains that make it feel like you’ve stepped into a fairytale. The view looking through the gardens towards the fortress is breathtaking and perfect for photos.

It’s free to enter the gardens, and they’re easy to walk through, so it’s a great stop even if you’re short on time. If you visit in spring or summer, the flowers are in full bloom and the atmosphere is magical. Music lovers will also appreciate that some of the “Sound of Music” scenes were filmed here.

Highly recommend visiting in the morning before the crowds arrive — it’s peaceful, romantic, and unforgettable.

The gardens are magnificent. Symmetry and colors are combined in beautiful compositions. Access to the gardens is free. The palace itself is also free, but there is nothing to see. Access is only to the staircase, which is magnificent, but it is disappointing that there is no access to the halls. We only managed to peek into one.

Mirabell Palace in Salzburg is straight out of a fairytale ✨. The gardens are full of colorful flowers, fountains, and little hidden corners that feel so peaceful. You can wander around, take in the mountain views, and feel like you’re in a scene from The Sound of Music. It’s charming, romantic, and a must-see if you’re in Salzburg 💐🏰

Beautiful palace with stunning gardens. Easy to walk around and free to enter. The views with the flowers, statues, and Salzburg backdrop are picture-perfect. Peaceful spot to relax, take photos, or just enjoy the scenery. Great for a short, calming visit.

Even though it was rainy a lot, the sculptures at the outskirts of the palace and the gardens inside were pretty. The cobblestone ground was a bit swampy and uncomfortable to walk, but anyway I bet it'd be fascinating to revisit there on sunny days.

Mirabell Garden was absolutely beautiful! We loved every moment there. The vibrant flowers and colors were stunning, and everything was so neat and well-maintained. It’s also where parts of The Sound of Music were filmed, which made it extra special. A perfect spot for amazing photos and a peaceful stroll. Highly recommend visiting

Centrally located, walking distance to railway, old town and major tourist attractions. Garden is well maintained and magnificent. We watched a Mozart concert at the Mirabell Palace at night which is an unforgettable experience.
Several spots within the garden are in the movie Sound Of Music. All are accessible for free. Beautiful flowers and landscaping. Short walk from train station.

placeMetadata.name: Salzach

sources.snippet: Unfurling from city to meadow and mountain, the banks of the Salzach River are a joy to cycle, especially when the city heaves in summer. Grab yourself a rental bike and pedal south, with views of the Altstadt’s riot of domes and spires slowly fading as you pass the Volksgarten park. Going for a pedal here allows you to give the city crowds the slip for a spell.
sources.shortName: The 12 best things to do in Salzburg
Salzburg for Lovers : Magazine
Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Salzach River offers a variety of experiences for visitors to Salzburg. One option is to take a cruise along the river, with different tour lengths available, providing stunning views of the city and surrounding alps. Another way to enjoy the river is by taking a leisurely stroll along its banks, offering picturesque vistas and photo opportunities of the city skyline and Hohensalzburg fortress. The northern point near Mirabell Gardens provides an especially beautiful view at sunset or in the early morning.

reviews.reviewText:
Great place. You can go for a morning / evening walk across the river. You can go for cycling as well!!
It has a park for children.
You would have one of the best views from here.
Wonderful place for all age groups.
This beautiful river runs through the heart of Salzburg. The landscaping on both sides is amazing. It also divides old and new towns. It’s worth walking along the banks in the morning or evening.

The Salzach river runs through the centre of the township, with the Alps as an amazing background. The ‘old city’ comprises original medieval and baroque buildings (on the left bank), looking across to the 19th century ‘new city’ (right bank).

reviews.reviewerName: Hygrobiology Co ltd Div7 CEO Nikolai Korkaew
reviews.reviewText: Nice River and it looks a quite good water quality. We will check it out. Best Regards from Hygrobiology Co Ltd Thailand
Had a beautiful day visiting the old town of Salzburg & walking along the Salzach River with the markets on its bank. The weather was cool with autumn in the air.
Pleasant and peaceful unlike any other Rivers in Europe

The main river runs through the heart of magical Salzburg! What a fascinatingly epic scenery and landscape of this fairytale city. We have been enchanted by its charms and authenticity. If you have seen The Sound of Music 🎵 The real picture will be more insanely beautiful than in the movie 🎥 Definitely impressive when visiting here
Simple beautiful panorama from here!

placeMetadata.name: St. Peter Stiftskulinarium

sources.snippet: End the day with a romantic dinner at Restaurant Ikarus, located at the Red Bull Hangar-7 and featuring innovative cuisine by top chefs from around the world.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria
Salzburg for Lovers : Magazine
Salzburg tips: The Top 10 highlights for your romantic weekend

placeMetadata.description: Creative dishes & drinks are served in the elegant ambience of reputedly Europe's oldest restaurant.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Peter Stiftskulinarium is a renowned restaurant that boasts being one of the oldest in Europe, with historical records dating back to 803 A.D. It was established by Benedictine monks and is steeped in history, with tales of famous figures such as Charlemagne and Columbus having dined or drank there. The restaurant offers an elegant ambiance and serves creative dishes and drinks, blending traditional Austrian standards with international specialties.

reviews.reviewText: We had a truly beautiful experience at this restaurant. The ambiance was unique and inviting, creating the perfect setting for a relaxing meal. The atmosphere stood out with its charming design and calming vibe. What made the evening even more special was the outstanding service from Waiter Cesar. He was incredibly helpful, kind, and attentive, offering excellent recommendations that turned out to be absolutely delicious. Thanks to him, we enjoyed a perfectly curated meal. Highly recommended for both the atmosphere and the impeccable service.

Food was nothing to shout about. Beautiful presentation but the taste is mediocre. Stunning environment and even more stunning interior! Wish the person serving us could do better? He’s absolutely gentleman, don’t get me wrong, but… we ordered asparagus for starters, he should’ve recommended something else without asparagus when we picked our mains? Who likes to have repeated ingredients when we can try them all?

Nockerl was fluffy, warm but too sweet. Perhaps it’s just the way this dessert is rather than the way this place prepares it.

I’d still recommend coming here but it’s really expensive… €40 just for baby veal with asparagus…

This was the best meal that I have had in Austria so far! It was incredible! From the atmosphere and being in the oldest restaurant in Central Europe, operating since 803 to the amazing dishes and great vibes, couldn’t ask for a better experience. Would highly recommend and it is a must! The grilled octopus and the duck were incredible and were very well balanced. We will be back!

A timeless experience in every sense 💣

Dining at St. Peter Stiftskulinarium was one of the highlights of our Salzburg visit. The historic setting alone is worth the visit, but the food truly elevates it to another level.

We started with a silky soup that was subtly seasoned and comforting. The green risotto with parmesan crisps and poached cheese was not only visually stunning but also incredibly flavorful with a perfect creamy texture. For the main course, the duck breast was beautifully seared, served over a rich grain base with perfectly cooked vegetables. And finally, the crème brûlée with sorbet was the ideal ending-light, refreshing, and perfectly balanced.

Everything from the service to the atmosphere was top-tier. You really feel the weight of history in the room while enjoying food that's modern, creative, and expertly prepared.

Highly recommended for a special evening in Salzburg 🖤🖤🖤

Located next to the St. Peter church, nice ambience and fine dinner setting with Excellent service.
Angelos was very friendly , well mannered, attentive and prepared separate serving plates for our sharing. I accidentally knocked off my wine glass and he replaced 1 for me.
Food was good, Beef soup and boiled beef very delish.
Great service and food!

AMERICAN REVIEW

Server was very professional, friendly, and knew the menu off the top of his head. Food was delicious as advertised, very pleased with my experience. I recommended the Austria dishes. Meal was served in a timely manner, took a tab bit long on the dessert menus.

11 out of 10. This restaurant was incredible and not miss if you’re in Salzburg. The oldest restaurant in Europe does not disappoint. It is carved out of rock with beautiful stone columns. The ambience is warm and inviting with lamp light, and greenery annd incredible artwork. The food is amazing. The service was perfect. Alessandro took exquisite care of us. He was attentive and made incredible suggestions. We started with the Tiger prawn tartare with smoked caviar, which was delicate and amazing. The gazpacho soup was fresh and flavorful. We had the duck which was served in a fois gras sauce with Lingonberry jam toast, which all blended perfectly and melted in your mouth. The frozen nougat dessert with fresh berries was incredible and unique. The coffee was rich in flavorful, served in warm, Demitasse cups. We ended with some apricot Austrian brandy. What a fabulous night to remember!  Highly recommend!!!

I had high expectations. Food was okay not wow.
They serve you bread with butter and my bf barely touch it but they charged us for both. We didn’t know it cost 🙃
The service was very nice and good recommendation of wine but they could have know more specially when they have a lots of wine in their menu.

placeMetadata.name: Viewpoint of Old Town

sources.snippet: There are several sites to see for free in the city’s Old Town. A UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site, it is one of Salzburg’s most romantic and charming areas. After strolling around the sites, grab a coffee and slice of cake to share at Café Tomaselli.
sources.shortName: 11 Free And Cheap Date Ideas To Try In Salzburg

sources.snippet: Salzburg Old Town is filled with stunning architecture, grand squares, and picturesque streets and alleys. It’s here that you’ll find most of the city’s historic buildings, landmarks, and museums. At the same time, it’s also a very lively place with lots of shops, cafes, and restaurants.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)

sources.siteName: 4* Hotel Wolf-Dietrich in Salzburg, Austria, Old Town
sources.shortName: Romantic hotel Salzburg | romantic city break for 2

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Viewpoint of Old Town in Salzburg is a UNESCO World Heritage site, featuring historical buildings with Medieval and Baroque architecture. It's a perfect place for leisurely walks, admiring the sights, enjoying coffee, and shopping. The area is home to major tourist attractions like Mozart's birthplace. Nearby districts like Elisabeth-Vorstadt offer convenient accommodation options while Lehen connects to the western edge of the Old Town.

reviews.reviewText: This vantage point offers some fantastic views over Salzburg.  Even on a rain filled or foggy day the sites are impressive.  Totally worth hiking up the hill to get a great view.

IMO , it has the best view in the whole of Salzburg . With mobility issues , you can take the paid lift from the Modern Museum, but we did not , we started our walk up the stairs from Humboldtterrasse Klausentor , along the path there will have benches for you to rest . It is a simple climb where you will get different great views along the way . It's well worth it . Highly recommended !

The view from this spot is truly enchanting. From the bench, under the shade of the trees, one can enjoy a panoramic scene of the city of Salzburg. In the background stands the impressive Hohensalzburg Fortress, proudly perched on the hill, while in the foreground stretch the distinctive domes and bell towers of the old town.

The tranquility of the place, combined with the greenery and the view of the historic landmarks, creates a sense of serenity and admiration for the beauty and history of the area. It is an ideal place to relax, enjoy nature, and let your gaze wander over the rooftops and monuments of the city.

Whenever you are in Salzburg and you have the time, I would recommend you coming up to this lookout to catch a view of the old town. Up there you will see the whole beauty of this lovely town, with the Cathedral and Fortress.
One of the top spots for a nice view over the old town.

You'll get an outstanding view of the old town (Aldstadt) from the viewpoint. It's definitely worth going/walking there if you have enough time to discover Salzburg city. However, I need to warn that the way going up there is a little bit steep; it could be helpful to keep that in mind.

Wow, a breath taking view of Salzburg old and new city. This is must visit for everyone visiting the Salzburg and I would recommend you to visit this place in the evening in summer. With the golden hour, you will see an unforgettable view of the Salzburg city.

There are few paths to reach this place and for me the easiest was from Reichenhaller Stra.

A close view of Saltzburg. Take the museum of modern art lift to the top for an instant shortcut or alternatively hike 20mins to the top from the backstreets! Benches and interesting stories at the top!

placeMetadata.name: St. Peter's Abbey

sources.snippet: Located beside DomQuartier is the Abbey of St. Peter, a Benedictine monastery and former cathedral. You can’t enter the Abbey itself, although a visit to the interior of its ‘Long Gallery’ is included as part of the DomQuartier tour. But you might want to stop and take a moment to appreciate the wonderful smell of fresh bread coming from Stiftsbäckerei St Peter, Salzburg’s oldest bakery.
sources.shortName: 17 BEST Places to See & Things to Do in Salzburg, Austria (+Map & Tips)

sources.snippet: On the western side of Salzburg's Kapitelplatz stands the Benedictine Abbey of St. Peter (Erzabtei St. Peter). Founded by St. Rupert in 690 CE, this impressive building complex served as the residence of the Archbishops until 1110. While the present buildings date mainly from the 17th and 18th centuries, they remain an impressive testament to the order's architectural skills.
sources.shortName: 18 Top-Rated Things to Do in Salzburg

placeMetadata.description: Catholic church & monastery dating to the 7th century, featuring a cemetery, catacombs & a museum.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Peter's Abbey, situated in Salzburg, Austria, is a renowned Benedictine monastery and Catholic church with a rich history dating back to the 7th century. Established by Saint Rupert, it stands as one of the oldest abbey-church and monastery complexes in the German-speaking world. The Romanesque St. Peter's Church, built in 1143 and later restored with Baroque and Rococo elements, showcases ornate altarpieces by Martin Johann Schmidt.

reviews.reviewText: The whole area was beautiful. I think I read that the interior of the church is Roccoco style - it was very dark in there. The surrounding of the cemetery and catacomb area offers really picturesque views.  Very historic church that was interesting to research !

St. Peter's Abbey is a breathtaking piece of history nestled in the heart of Salzburg. Dating back to the 7th century, this Catholic church and monastery exude an aura of timeless beauty and serenity. The Baroque architecture, intricate decorations, and peaceful atmosphere make it a must-visit for history lovers and spiritual seekers alike.

One of the highlights is the picturesque cemetery and catacombs, which offer a fascinating glimpse into the past. The surroundings are stunning, with the abbey seamlessly blending into the rocky landscape. Whether you're admiring the Rococo-style interior or exploring the historical graves, every corner of St. Peter's Abbey tells a story.

A visit here is not just about sightseeing—it's an experience that leaves you with a deep appreciation for Salzburg’s rich heritage. Highly recommended.

The cemetery was unlike anything that I have seen. Though the sound of music took the look of St. Peter's cemetery it was not filmed here. Still very much worth seeing. Walking around the Abby in the court there are some areas open to enter, however I was not dressed church appropriate to enter so I can't comment on the inside

It is considered one of the oldest monasteries in the German-speaking area, and in fact the oldest with a continuous history since its foundation in 696.The pictures from the inside are truly breathtaking.You can even light a candle for 80 cents for the church!

Magnificent abbey!
You should try to make time for it, but there are so many things to do in Salzburg that this might be difficult.
Having said that, if you have two full days in Salzburg, then it's a must-see, and missing this abbey would be a shame.
Lovely church grounds but don't bother with the catacombs.

Picturesque Abbey located in Old Town. The church was originally built in the 8th century. The gardens in the cemetery are very nice. There is a beautiful view of Altstadt from the top of the abbey. The catacombs are an interesting site but do not contain any bones.

The Abbey inside is no different than any other Abbey. But behind the Abbey is fantastic where you see the historical graves and the stone structure built in the mountain. Also the first right turn before the Abbey, if yiu go down that street and up the stairs you get a magnificent view of Salzburg. I assume it is where church people live.

placeMetadata.name: Salzburg Zoo Hellbrunn

sources.snippet: The Salzburg Hellbrunn Zoo is a real must-see, as it is definitely one of the most beautiful zoos in Austria. A large part was already from the 15th century the archiepiscopal game park, with the zoo today a popular destination for families. Nestled in a gorgeous landscape, this place is home to a variety of interesting animal species on 14 hectares, which are kept in enclosures that are as close to nature as possible.
sources.shortName: 20 Amazing Things to Do in Salzburg (Austria)
Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Family-friendly zoo with animals from Africa, Eurasia, Australia & the Americas, plus dining.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Salzburg Zoo Hellbrunn is a family-friendly destination featuring over 1,500 animals from various continents. Originally established in the 15th century as an archbishopric zoological park, it now showcases 150 different species. The zoo's unique topography, nestled next to a cliff leading to the large African savannah, adds to its charm.

reviews.reviewText: Lovely zoo. The zoo itself is not big, you could explore it all within 3 hours comfortably. Despite that, it hosts some animals you don't see very often and it offers nice viewpoints into all of the enclosures. It was clean, enclosures seem well-thought out, animals look healthy & happy. The zoo utilizes the natural rocky terrain in an interesting way.
Well it was much more then we expected. Good place to pass 3-4 hours with the kids. We gave them the map and follow them.. bring food and water with you and make it a great day!

Animals were very active.
We really enjoyed the time.
With the Salzburg card we can enter the zoo without additional payments.
Car parking is free for those who come to visit the zoo.

Don't forget to punch your car parking ticket before exiting from the Zoo. Else you have to pay parking charges

Pretty good restaurant available inside the zoo
Nice place to visit with kids. Rare animals such as puma and snow leopards are kept there. All animals are kept in their natural habitat. Takes 2-4 hours to complete the tour.

We were very happy with the visit in the ZOO garden. ZOO can be easily reached by the public transport from Salzburg and it's located in a very lovely area. We saw many animals except big cats :) Also the services available in the garden are nice and overall we had very good impression. If you have the Salzburg card, the public transport as well as entry are free of charge.
Incredibly diverse zoo with lots of attractions to see and it’s well maintained! I highly recommend going here if you’re also going for the Palace nearby. It pairs well together!

What shall I say? Salzburg Zoo is a must go. This was a highlight of my entire visit of the beautiful city of Salzburg. Animals have such a healthy lovely life there. The view of the mountains is astonishing! I am so glad I was able to visit this place. With Salzburg card the admission is free, otherwise is very affordable and worths the visit! Sofya
Smallish but lovely. Great spot to take the kids. Depending on your pace 2-3 hours is what you'll need.

placeMetadata.name: Steingasse

sources.snippet: The baroque Altstadt on the left bank of the Salzach River gets all the fuss, and yes, it is incredibly beautiful, but it’s also nerve-fraying when the tourist masses descend in summer. For our money, the loveliest lane in Salzburg is Steingasse on the opposite side of the milky-green river. Hard though it is to believe today, this narrow lane was the main north–south route between the city and Italy in the Middle Ages, its cobbles polished smooth by many a horse’s hoof and wagon wheel.
sources.shortName: The 12 best things to do in Salzburg

sources.snippet: While most of the galleries charge an entrance fee, find work by Salzburg’s most famous street artists, Jana & JS, along Steingasse. Alternatively, the Krauthügel Project offers different artwork every year during the summer.
sources.shortName: 11 Free And Cheap Date Ideas To Try In Salzburg

placeMetadata.description: Narrow medieval street, birthplace of the "Silent Night" poet & home to past & current brothels.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Steingasse is a charming medieval street located on the opposite side of the Salzach River from the famous baroque Altstadt in Salzburg. This narrow lane was once a major north-south route between the city and Italy during the Middle Ages, evidenced by its polished cobbles from horse hooves and wagon wheels. It is also known as the birthplace of the poet of 'Silent Night' and has been home to past and current brothels.

reviews.reviewText: A very picturesque street in the heart of Salzburg's Old Town.  Worth taking a leisurely stroll snapping some beautiful shots
nice

(Translated by Google) Hello, Very old alley. You can still see some very old wooden buildings.

Nice to just walk through.

MFG
Stephen

(Original)
Hallo, Sehr alte Gasse. Man erkennt teilweise sehr alte Gebäude aus Holz noch.

Schön einfach mal durchzugehen.

MFG
Stefan

(Translated by Google) I passed by because it was right next to the center and was a very old road. Because it was Sunday, other roads were crowded, but there was no one on this road. From the entrance of the street, you can feel that it is an old street. I think there are two or three stores in between, but most stores are closed in Austria on Sundays. It feels like a quiet alley.

(Original)
중심가 바로 옆에 있고 아주 오래된 길이라고해서 지나가봄. 일요일이라 다른길은 북적이는데 이 길은 사람하나 없네요. 길목 입구부터 오래된 구길이라는게 느껴집니다. 중간 중간 상점이 두세개 있는거 같은데 일요일 오스트리아는 거의 상점이 문을 닫아요. 고요한 골목 느낌입니다.

(Translated by Google) Interesting street! Few people go here! Still great for photography!

(Original)
Interessante Straße! Nur wenige gehen hier her! Trotzdem sehr schön zum Fotografieren!

(Translated by Google) A rather interesting route, nice return along the river side!

(Original)
Una via piuttosto interessante, bello il rientro lato lungo fiume!

(Translated by Google) Tucked into a small space between the main road and Capuchin Hill, almost hidden but still prominent, is Steingasse, an alleyway that has retained its charming medieval atmosphere. The inner stone gate is from 1280. You can also find several Salzburg brothels here, they have small red lanterns in front.

(Original)
Vtesnaná do malého priestoru medzi hlavnou cestou a kapucínskym kopcom, takmer skrytá, ale stále prominentná, nachádza sa Steingasse, ulička, ktorá si zachovala očarujúcu stredovekú atmosféru . Vnútorná kamenná brána je z roku 1280. Nájdete tu aj niekoľko salzburských bordelov, vpredu majú malé červené lampáše.

(Translated by Google) Quiet and shady place! In the summer heat

(Original)
Ruhiger und Schattiger Ort! In der Sommerhitze

placeMetadata.name: Bärenwirt

sources.snippet: There are a lot of fancy restaurants in Salzburg, with price tags to match, but sometimes all you want is schnitzel as big as a boot, cooked to golden perfection, and a side order of history. You’ll find precisely this at Bärenwirt, a warm, woody, hunting lodge-style tavern that has been juggling the pans since 1663. The inn forgoes all the new-fangled food trends in favor of good old-fashioned, gut-busting dishes like Bierbraten (beer roast) with lashings of dumplings and sauerkraut, beef goulash and Kasnocken (mini cheese dumplings with fried onions).
sources.shortName: The 12 best things to do in Salzburg
Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Woodsy, old-world inn known for fried chicken, bread dumplings & beer, plus an outdoor terrace.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bärenwirt is a traditional Austrian inn located in Salzburg City, dedicated to preserving the iconic culture and cuisine of the region. The restaurant is renowned for its fried chicken, which is considered the best in Austria, as well as other classics like Salzburger Nockerl. The cozy tavern offers a warm, woody atmosphere reminiscent of a hunting lodge and has been serving traditional dishes since 1663.

reviews.reviewText: A nice, quiet atmosphere. Friendly staff, cold beers and amazing food!  Schnitzel was incredibly tasty. The Fried Chicken was wonderful and the potato salad was superb! 10/10 would definitely eat here again

We stopped by for late lunch and got the spinach dumpling. It was divine!! That, paired with brown butter + cheese - 🤤 so satisfying, even for a meat lover. Aside from that, we had Apple strudel. It was perfectly balance with the cream and somehow tasted very homey. Not too sweet. And of course had beer - which is always nice and refreshing. Wanted to try their fried chicken as I saw many good reviews on it but sadly we were too full. Please do me a favour and try it ok? 😝
Service could be better as no one took our order for quite some time, even though there weren’t many customers at that time.

I had been looking forward to this for at least two weeks, and it was exactly what I expected—the fried chicken was SO FREAKING GOOD. The outside was perfectly fried, and the tender, juicy meat was just right. They even served a sour potato salad on the side. This was the first time I’d ever finished an entire potato salad; it was really good. I managed to finish both the chicken and the salad, even though the portion was huge for me.

The food is totally overrated. We ordered the pork ribs, schnitzel, and half fried chicken. The pork ribs were very dry, tough, and had a strong porky smell — not juicy at all, and I think they were overcooked. The schnitzel was average, and the rice that came with the dishes was rather tasteless. The fried chicken was not tender; the meat was dry and lacked flavor — honestly, even KFC or simple street-stall fried chicken tastes better.

The restaurant’s ventilation is also poor, and the smell of cooking oil lingered on our clothes after dining. On top of that, the prices are quite high compared to the quality. Overall, it’s really not worth a visit.

Great food. The fried chicken is something special very tasty and full of flavor. The potato salad and mixed salad were well balanced and delicious. The Waines schnitzel was also excellent, with the sauce served on the side. Would highly recommend.

Don't forget to reserve a table! We managed to have dinner at 3rd attempt.

Everything was great. Nothing was too salty too.
The original schnitzel comes 2 pieces which was a lot for us so I wish we ordered less.
Kids loved everything especially creamy mushroom and lemony potatoes which came with fried chicken.

If you're planning to have dinner here, please make a reservation ahead of time as it fills up rather quickly.  The food is excellent!  This is where you can eat some truly Austrian dishes.  The service was also friendly.

We came without reservation and were only looking for a quick dinner. While not tables were left, the service team made it possible to dine in a short window and with quick turnaround.
While this worked out properly, most of our orders were mixed up but fixed in the same speed as delivered - annoying anyhow. (Small instead of large beer‘s, wrong soup, missed side order)
In any case, the ordered meals and drinks paired with the atmosphere and location are kind of its own and made up for everything.

placeMetadata.name: Marko-Feingold-Steg

sources.snippet: Marko-Feingold-Steg—the bridge of love locks—will come into view, and if you didn’t bring a padlock to declare your undying affection, don’t worry. You can always mentally lock your love; after all, the sentiment is what counts, right?. (Besides, some of us are already padlocked to our phones, so we might as well spread the love around.)
sources.shortName: Romantic Escapes in Salzburg, Austria
Salzburg for Lovers : Magazine

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Marko-Feingold-Steg is a bridge in Salzburg that pays tribute to Marko Feingold, offering a serene walkway connecting the Old Town with Mulln across the Salzach River. Surrounded by historic landmarks like Hohensalzburg Fortress and Mirabell Palace, it provides picturesque views and a peaceful atmosphere. The bridge is known for its vibrant surroundings during the day and charmingly lit appearance at night, especially during Christmas.

reviews.reviewText: This is such a romantic part of Salzburg. Plan ahead to put your love lock on the bridge and make a wish. The bridge can get extremely busy. Try to go early. A walk along the river is a must if you want to experience the picturesque Salzburg houses and have a breather from all the tourists. Popular spot for great musicians to share their talent.

One of the best cities I’ve ever visited is Salzburg. I lived there for 7 months and completely fell in love with it. The city is full of music, amazing food, and kind, welcoming people. Here I am at the famous Marko-Feingold-Steg Love Lock Bridge such a beautiful spot.

A very beautiful bridge , with lots and lots of pad locks withe all kind of couple’s name on it ., you have a very beautiful view of the fort and the river from this bridge , you can also get down to the river bank and spend sometime soaking your tired feet in the ice cold water

There's a good reason why the Makartsteg Bridge in Salzburg is called the Love Lock Bridge! It is covered in locks that couples have left behind as a testament to their devotion and love. The Salzach River and the city skyline may be seen clearly from the bridge.
This area of Salzburg is quite charming. Make plans in advance to make a wish and place your love lock on the bridge. It can get very crowded on the bridge. Make an effort to arrive early. If you want to see the charming Salzburg houses and get away from the visitors, you must take a stroll along the river. A well-liked location for talented musicians to showcase their skills.
Great spot for photo opportunities and getting a panorama view of the city from the bridge. Bring a lock to leave if you want
So enjoy of walking along with the river and seeing acitivities here! It’s just so lovely moments!
Nice walking bridge with nice view on both side of the bridge.
The views from the bridge are quite good, especially towards the Castle. The bridge itself is quite uninspired and the love locks stuck to the sides are so last season.

placeMetadata.name: Friedhof St. Peter (Petersfriedhof)

sources.snippet: Right next to the cable car at the foot of the fortress mountain you will find the somewhat hidden and inconspicuous entrance to Petersfriedhof.
sources.shortName: Salzburg tips: The Top 10 highlights for your romantic weekend

placeMetadata.description: Picturesque cemetery with baroque tombs of nobility as well as 12th-century catacombs & chapels.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Friedhof St. Peter, also known as Petersfriedhof, is a charming cemetery in Salzburg with a rich history dating back to before 700 AD. The graveyard is adorned with baroque tombs of nobility and features 12th-century catacombs and chapels carved into the rock face. Notable graves include those of Wolfgang's sister Nannerl and his childhood friend Michael Haydn. The cemetery, surrounded by the Church of St.

reviews.reviewText:
Friedhof St. Peter is a peaceful and historic cemetery in downtown square of Salzburg. The ornate baroque tombstones and the cliffside catacombs create a unique and striking atmosphere. Walking through, you can’t help but feel the weight of its history.

Inside the nearby church, I lit a candle for a loved one who was very ill. It was a quiet and beautiful moment, made even more special because we used to watch “The Sound of Music” together. Being in a place so connected to the film added a layer of meaning to the experience.

This spot is serene and reflective, perfect for appreciating Salzburg’s rich past or finding a moment of connection and peace. It’s a visit I’ll always hold close to my heart :)

St. Peter’s Cemetery in Salzburg is a peaceful and picturesque spot nestled at the foot of the Festungsberg. The well-maintained grounds feature ornate wrought-iron crosses, colorful flowers, and shaded pathways, creating a serene atmosphere that’s perfect for a quiet stroll. The surrounding architecture adds to the charm, with the nearby church and rock-carved catacombs enhancing the unique setting. It’s a lovely place to pause and appreciate the tranquil side of Salzburg’s Old Town.

A peaceful and beautiful cemetery. We enjoyed the calm atmosphere and admiring the differences between this and cemeteries in the US, and appreciated how this felt more like a celebration of life and reunion of families after death. The area was very well maintained and not too crowded.

Was included with the Salzburg card so I checked out (it’s a nominal fee otherwise). Walking up the stairs, it offers some great views of St. Peter’s! Definitely worth spending about 10-15 minutes to check it out.
This was one of the prettiest and most well-kept places I visited in Salzburg. The tombs are very adorned and the vegetation and flowers make for a beautiful and peaceful setting.

Even though it's a cemetery, it's very well known and nice area to walk. Beautiful plants and flowers adorning the grave. There's many old grave but there's still new one too. Most of the graves are reserved as there's section for family graves as well. It's well laid out and there's a church in the centre of this cemetary.

Definitely the most beautiful and interesting part of the entire abbey! Believe me that it's not just about the tombs, that actually only those are wonderful, but the place itself is fantastic, also because you can also see some interesting glimpses of the city's monuments! It is completely free of charge

Never saw a cementery so pleasant. Beautiful. I walked around and admired the graves. Sounds creepy, but it is so peaceful and divine and delightful and pretty. Didn't like Salzburg at all, but this was worth seeing. I wish I stayed and strolled longer. My friend had also recognised it from a scene in The Sound of Music.

placeMetadata.name: Marko-Feingold-Steg

sources.snippet: Once you’ve left your mark on the bridge, wander towards Mirabell Gardens. This gloriously manicured oasis is the kind of place where you’ll find statues of cherubs looking smug because they know they’ve aced the romantic setting game. Flowers bloom in a riot of colors, providing the perfect backdrop for those “candid” selfies (you know, the ones with your partner looking lovably clueless while you artfully pose like an influencer).
sources.shortName: Romantic Escapes in Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: 21st century bridge for pedestrians & cyclists, the 3rd of its name, after painter Hans Makart.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Makartsteg, also known as the Love Lock Bridge, is a 21st-century pedestrian and cyclist bridge in Salzburg. Named after painter Hans Makart, it is adorned with countless love locks left by tourists for good luck. The bridge offers stunning views of the Salzach River, Salzburg Castle, and the colorful Medieval homes along the waterfront.

placeMetadata.name: Mozarteum University Salzburg

sources.snippet: You’ll find yourself in venues as atmospheric as they come, from the historic Mozarteum to the lavish Marble Hall at Schloss Mirabell. And let’s be honest, ‘Marble Hall’ just sounds fancy enough to earn you serious romantic brownie points.
sources.shortName: Romantic Escapes in Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Venerable conservatory & dramatic-arts school with 2 concert halls, a student orchestra & choir.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mozarteum University Salzburg is a renowned conservatory and dramatic arts school located in the newer town of Salzburg. It houses two concert halls, a student orchestra, and choir. The university is part of the city's rich musical history and offers free concerts by students as well as special events throughout the year. Visitors can explore the building to learn more about Salzburg's musical heritage or attend one of its prestigious concerts. Additionally, it is situated near several landmarks such as St.

reviews.reviewText: Very energetic school. Good to see young people on their start of the music career
Stopped by for a quick look — almost everyone has an instrument. The artistic atmosphere is everywhere.

This is the part of the university of Salzburg that deals with the teaching of music (hence the name). It is a world class facility attracting students from all over the world. It's also an excellent piece of modern architecsture in its own right. It's possible to visit during the day and indeed it's possible to attend for free concert by the students studying at the University. You can pick up a programme of performances from the main lobby.
One of the world's best universities offering great music education! It's located next to Mirabelgarten. I'm adding a photo of the backyard of it.
Nice university with good environment
I visited to eat launch that was cheap and delicious. After meal I went to the library and staff was friendly.
One of the best music departments in the world. Also if you are into free classical concerts, this is the place.
Terrible, awful, rude, inconsiderate, annoying, offensive; both staff and students (with some notable exceptions). Stay as far away from this hell hole as possible.

placeMetadata.name: Museum der Moderne Salzburg

sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A 3 day romantic trip to Salzburg, Austria

placeMetadata.description: Baroque-style museum with a courtyard, showcasing graphics & photographs by modern Austrian artists.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Museum der Moderne Salzburg, located in the New Residential Palace (Neue Residenz), is a must-visit for art and cultural history enthusiasts. The museum showcases modern Austrian artists' graphics and photographs within its Baroque-style architecture. With 3,000 square meters of renovated space, visitors can immerse themselves in multimedia-enhanced exhibitions that range from Bronze Age artifacts to rare 16th-century musical instruments.

reviews.reviewText: Built to the side of the cliff, the entrance is quite interesting to go into the mountain. Though not the biggest art museum, the scale is not too bad and adequate to see variety of exhibits. Well curated shows.

This review is only about the one downtown, also known as the Rupertinum. They have an interesting exhibition of Daguerreotypes, showing many old pictures of people and of Salzburg as it was long ago. What struck me most, though, was the Hundertwasser decoration on the facade of the building. An unexpected and daring combination with the baroque building.

⛔️ CAUTION TO ALL TOURISTS! Do not take the elevator down from the museum as it 3.2 euros per pax!!! The counter ticket lady with specs (seen in this pic) was 100% racist and superrr arrogant. She had such an attitude chiding us about their "rules" on taking the elevator.

Very weird btw, the elevator button is bigger than their prices and in no way self explanatory.

They could better
1) Caution about the price to take the lift down
2) Not have such a despicable attitude towards paying patrons

Absolutely RUINED our day at salzburg. Such a shame she is someone customer facing.

The staff is really helpful! There are two modern museums and they are not far away from each other, but the new one is on the top of the mountain so it will take people at least 10 mins to walk there. The museums are not very big, but the themes are very nice and meaningful!
